questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is seen in the condition affecting the child shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image of a child showing dark peeling patches over edematous limbs (flaky paint dermatosis) points to the diagnosis of kwashiorkor. The child will have a flag sign. 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterised by oedema. The oedema is most likely to appear first in the feet and then in the lower legs. It quickly develops into generalised oedema, affecting also the hands, arms, and face (moon face). Other signs of kwashiorkor are skin changes, which typically occur over the swollen limbs and include dark, crackled, peeling patches with pale skin underneath that is easily infected, known as flaky paint dermatosis.

The hair is sparse and easily pulled out and may lose its curl. Alternate bands of hypopigmented and normally pigmented hair patterns are seen when the growth occurs in spurts, known as flag sign. Children with oedema are apathetic and often refuse to eat.

Simian or monkey facies and loose, wrinkled skin, with marked wasting of fat and muscle, are characteristic features of marasmus. The eyes may be sunken from loss of retro-orbital fat.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

questions.text: The image below shows a gunshot wound on the skull. Identify the type of wound and its features.

choices.text: Exit wound - bevelling of outer table and punched out hole on inner table
Entry wound - bevelling of inner table and punched out hole on outer table
Entry wound - bevelling of outer table and punched out hole on inner table
Exit wound - bevelling of inner table and punched out hole on outer table

questions.solution:
The given image shows bevelling of the outer table and a punched-out hole on the inner table. Hence, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, then the same pattern occurs, but this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints as shown below in the image. On examination, her BP is low. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The image shows clitoromegaly, and the likely cause is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a disorder of cortisol synthesis. It has an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Cortisol deficiency increases the secretion of the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), causing adrenal hyperplasia with the overproduction of intermediate metabolites. This child has clitoromegaly due to increased androgen synthesis. The enzyme 21-hydroxylase helps in the downstream synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. A deficiency of aldosterone causes salt wasting that presents as low blood pressure.

The presentation depends on the enzyme that is deficient, which could result in mineralocorticoid deficiency or excess, incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in affected males, and virilization or sexual infantilism in affected females.

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:

Females with aromatase deficiency at birth have signs of virilization like enlargement of the clitoris and posterior labial fusion at birth. Failure to synthesize estrogen during puberty due to ovarian failure results in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. However, salt wasting and low BP is not seen.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of 3 spontaneous abortions, all of which occurred at <10 weeks gestation. Laboratory tests show the presence of anticardiolipin antibodies. Which of the following is the cause of recurrent pregnancy loss?

choices.text: Placenta overlying the internal cervical os

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is indicative of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The mechanism of recurrent pregnancy loss in this scenario is due to thrombosis of the uteroplacental vascular bed.

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder that is one of the common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss. Antiphospholipid antibodies cause oxidative damage to the endothelium, which leads to thrombosis of the vascular bed.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion:

  • Clinical criteria
    • Obstetric
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • Vascular
      • One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue 
  • Laboratory criteria: Presence of any of following
    • Lupus anticoagulant
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

In cases with recurrent pregnancy loss and confirmed diagnosis, low-dose aspirin with unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin is given. These drugs are started at the time of diagnosis and given until 6 weeks postpartum.

Other Options:

Option A: Cervical insufficiency is characterized by painless cervical dilation in the second trimester.

Option B: Overt hypothyroidism also causes recurrent abortion. The patient would have symptoms such as dry skin, cold intolerance, hair loss, constipation, weight gain with poor appetite.

Option D: Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is implanted at the lower uterine segment. The patient presents with painless, apparently causeless vaginal bleeding after the 28th week. The early pregnancy loss (<10 weeks) in this case rules out placeta previa.

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria, is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text:
A researcher conducting multiple genetic studies observes that targeted mutations within certain genes can induce defects in DNA repair and dramatically increase susceptibility to cancer. Which of the following diseases is incorrectly matched with the DNA repair mechanisms?

SCID- Severe combined immunodeficiency.

choices.text: Xeroderma pigmentosum - Defective nucleotide excision repair
Lynch syndrome - Defective base excision repair

questions.solution:
Lynch syndrome, or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), occurs due to a defective DNA mismatch repair mechanism. Defective DNA base excision repair is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost, leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with jaundice and pruritus. He has been on treatment for ulcerative colitis for many years. MRCP showed beading in the bile ducts. The biopsy image given below shows the appearance of the bile duct. Which of the following structures is/are involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the MRCP findings of bild duct beading, is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis, in which both the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are involved.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments. It is more common in men and associated with Riedel thyroiditis and ulcerative colitis, but proctocolectomy does not stop disease progression. 

It presents with generalized symptoms like fatigue and pruritis or asymptomatic abnormal liver function tests on routine tests. It is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

MRCP showing multifocal diffuse dilation and stricturing of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary trees called beading or chain of lakes is sufficient for diagnosis. Biopsy is only done for equivocal MRCP and suspected malignancy. It is associated with elevated p-ANCA levels.

Ursodeoxycholic acid shows some improvement but does not alter course of disease. ERCP is done to dilate prominent strictures and liver transplantation is done for progressive disease.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male patient was diagnosed with varicose veins a few months back. He now comes to the outpatient clinic with the finding shown in the image. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines?

CEAP- Clinical etiology anatomy pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders.
questions.solution:
The given image in a patient with a known case of varicose veins is atrophie blanche. It is classified as C4b under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and pigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as follows:

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Corona phlebectatica is the presence of abnormally visible cutaneous blood vessels. Lipodermatosclerosis is a chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, that appears as a ‘woody’ leg on examination.

Image A shows tortuous dilated veins (C2), Image B is atrophie blanche (C4b), and Image C shows fan-shaped telangiectasia (C4c).

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is an exception for using the MELD score in determining liver transplant?
questions.solution:
Hepatopulmonary syndrome is an exception for MELD and is awarded an upgrade in MELD points to accurately represent the mortality risk.

Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation. However, there are certain diseases that impair patient survival and are not accounted for in the MELD score. Patients with these diseases may be given an upgrade in MELD points to accurately represent the mortality risk, and these conditions are called MELD exceptions. 

MELD exceptions

  • Portopulmonary hypertension
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy
  • Primary hyperoxaluria (necessitating liver-kidney transplantation)
  • Cystic fibrosis with liver disease
  • Highly selected cases of hilar cholangiocarcinoma
  • Hepatopulmonary syndrome

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: A 17-year-old intellectually challenged teenager was brought for evaluation. His IQ was 49. Examination showed a long face with a large mandible, everted large ears, a high-arched palate, and large testicles. Which of the following diseases also has the same pathogenesis as the condition this boy has?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of fragile X syndrome. It occurs due to trinucleotide expansion mutations in the FMR1 gene on the long arm of the X chromosome. Of the options above the other disease that occurs due to trinucleotide repeats in the non-coding region is myotonic dystrophy.

Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family. The affected males are intellectually disabled. Neuropsychiatric features include aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Macro-orchidism (large testicles)
  • Hyperextensible joints
  • High-arched palate
  • Mitral valve prolapse

Myotonic dystrophy is caused by expansions of CTG triplet repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene. 

It presents with 

  • Muscle weakness
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Cataracts
  • Endocrinopathy

Option A: Klinefelter's syndrome is a genetic disorder that results from a 47, XXY karyotype. 

Options B: Edwards syndrome is associated with trisomy 18, in which a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 is inherited as a result of meiotic nondisjunction.

Option D: Down syndrome is the most common of the chromosomal disorders and is a major cause of intellectual disability. Most commonly it occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 which is due to meiotic nondisjunction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with rapidly progressing symmetric ascending paralysis for 2 days. Findings of nerve conduction studies are consistent with demyelination. He is found to have an elevated protein level in his CSF. A provisional diagnosis of autoimmune polyradiculoneuropathy is made. Which of the following is not useful in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Guillian-Barre syndrome (GBS). High-dose steroids have no role in the management of GBS in spite of it being an autoimmune disease.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It contains anti-idiotypic antibodies against autoantibodies. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight.

Mechanical ventilation is reserved for those who develop respiratory insufficiency or patients who develop early bulbar weakness. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Neuropathies associated with prominent autonomic dysfunction

  • Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy
  • Amyloidosis (familial and acquired)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Idiopathic pandysautonomia (may be a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome)
  • Porphyria
  • HIV-related autonomic neuropathy
  • Vincristine and other chemotherapeutic agents

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a child is given below. Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium, giving rise to a massive box-shaped cardiac shadow. This is suggestive of Ebstein anomaly, which is caused by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve.

Infants with severe disease present with marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, and long holosystolic murmurs. Death may result from cardiac failure, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypoplasia.

Other options:

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is due to anterior deviation of the infundibular septum. It has been classically characterized by the following components:

  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Overriding of the aorta, and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks occur during the 1st year of life and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. The child can have shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips which is relieved by squatting. Chest X-ray shows "coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart.

Option C:  A pulmonary venous connection to the superior vena cava (SVC) is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). It is a cyanotic congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins drain directly into the right atrium. On chest x-ray, supracardiac TAPVR presents with the snowman appearance of the heart.

Option D: An ostium secondum defect in the fossa ovalis is the most common site of atrial septal defects (ASD). Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A widely fixed and split S2 is characteristic. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: Skirrow’s medium is selective for  _______.
questions.solution:
Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria.

Macleod's medium is selective for Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Potassium tellurite in McLeod's medium is reduced to metallic tellurium by C. diphtheriae to produce black colonies. Additionally, tellurite (0.04%) inhibits the growth of most other bacteria, acting as a selective agent.

BCYE agar or buffered charcoal, yeast extract agar is selective for Legionella species. Legionellae are nutritionally fastidious. Their growth is enhanced with iron salts and depends on the supplementation of media  L-cysteine. 

Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmonella typhi reduces sulfite to sulfide in the presence of glucose and produces jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S. It is also a differential media. While S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen Salmonella paratyphi produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text:
You are studying the lung volumes of a patient with a spirometer. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding lung volumes?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first second

FVC - Forced vital capacity

choices.text: Residual volume can be directly measured by spirometry
Functional residual capacity is the sum of expiratory reserve volume and residual volume
Vital capacity is the sum of inspiratory capacity and expiratory reserve volume
In obstructive disease, FEV1/FVC will be <0.7

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement is the residual volume (RV) can be directly measured by spirometry. RV is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, it cannot be directly measured by spirometry.

To measure RV, we need to first measure functional residual capacity (FRC) by the helium dilution technique. Functional Residual Capacity is the sum of expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and residual volume (FRC= ERV+RV). RV is then calculated by subtracting expiratory reserve volume from FRC. RV = FRC - ERV.

In obstructive disease, FEV1/FVC will be <0.7 and will be >0.7 in restrictive disease.

Examples of obstructive pulmonary disease are COPD, asthma, bronchiectasis, etc. 
Examples of restrictive pulmonary disease are asbestosis, sarcoidosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, etc. 

The tidal volume is defined as the volume of air inspired or expired with each normal breath. The normal value is about 500 mL in an average healthy man.

Vital Capacity (VC) is the sum of Inspiratory capacity (IC) and Expiratory reserve volume (ERV). VC=IC+ERV.

 

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

questions.text:
A 21-year-old pregnant lady comes with dysuria and urethral discharge for 3 days. NAAT for gonorrhea was negative. What is the true statement regarding the condition the patient is most likely to have?

NAAT: Nucleic acid amplification test

choices.text: The elementary body is the infectious form of the causative organism.
Applying erythromycin to the newborn’s eyes prevents the disease.
Infection in pregnant women is treated with doxycycline.
Genital disease is caused by serotypes A, B, and C

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to have chlamydial urethritis, and the elementary body is the infectious form of the causative organism, Chlamydia trachomatis.

C. trachomatis is the most common non-gonococcal cause of urethritis.

Chlamydia specials are obligate intracellular organisms that do not grow on blood agar or routine culture medium. Since they are dependent on host cells for ATP synthesis, they can be grown in McCoy cells.

They can exist in two states: an extracellular elementary body, which is the infectious form, and an intracellular reticulate body, which forms an inclusion body that can be visualized by iodine or Giemsa stain. 

Different serovars affect different diseases: serovars D to K cause genital tract diseases; serovars A, B, and C cause trachoma; and serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum.

In babies born to infected mothers, it causes neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis, which can be prevented by treating the mother. Instillation of erythromycin or tetracycline into the newborn’s eyes will not prevent the development of chlamydial conjunctivitis. 

The investigation of choice is the nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT). Treatment in pregnant women is with azithromycin. Doxycycline is used in non-pregnant women and men. Systemic therapy should be used for inclusion conjunctivitis. Sexual partners should also be treated.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with gross hematuria. He has had sensorineural hearing loss for the past 2 years. Defect of which of the following is present in this case?

choices.text: Alpha chain of type VI collagen.
Alpha chain of type IV collagen.
Beta chain of type IV collagen.
Beta chain of type VI collagen.

questions.solution:
Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the COL4A5 gene, which codes for the alpha chain of type IV collagen.

The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is needed. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of epithelial metaplasia?
questions.solution:
The most common type of epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous metaplasia. It is commonly seen in the respiratory tract of smokers. 

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways

Squamous metaplasia: It is seen in chronic smoking. The normal ciliated columnar epithelial cells of the trachea and bronchi are replaced by stratified squamous epithelial cells.

Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.

Salivary glands, pancreas, bile ducts

Squamous metaplasia: The presence of stones in the excretory duct may trigger metaplasia, where the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium.
Cervix

Squamous metaplasia: Due to the low pH of the cervix, the normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium.
Esophagus

Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus).
Muscle

Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

GERD: Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Image showing squamous metaplasia in endocervical glands of the cervix.

The image below depicts the histopathology of Barret's esophagus, showing the internalized epithelium with goblet cells as opposed to the normal stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus and pseudostratified columnar epithelium of the fundus of the stomach. The submucosa displays an infiltrate including lymphocytes and plasma cells, constituting an underlying chronic inflammation.

questions.text: Epidemic typhus is caused by _______.
questions.solution:
Epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. Clinical features are fever, chills, and a characteristic rash that starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

The infection can be transmitted by

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed into abrasions by scratching or directly into the conjunctiva
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients of older age.

Other options:

Option A: R. typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces are rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to those of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal. Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

Option C: R. akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites, and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

Option D: R. conorii causes Indian tick typhus. The parasite is transmitted by ticks, and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: Risk of which of the following is not reduced with the use of antenatal corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Antenatal corticosteroids do not protect against meconium aspiration syndrome.

Antenatal corticosteroids reduce the incidence of

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
  • Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC)
  • Neurodevelopmental impairment
  • Overall neonatal mortality

They are given to mothers who are at risk of preterm delivery before 34 weeks. Intramuscular injections of either 2 doses of 12 mg betamethasone are given 24 hourly or 4 doses of 6 mg dexamethasone are given 12 hourly.

Contraindications include frank chorioamnionitis.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with painless, gross hematuria. He was evaluated for the same, and a cystoprostatectomy was done. The specimen image is shown below. Which among the following is not a risk factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows fungating growth from the bladder wall involving the entire bladder; the likely diagnosis would be bladder cancer. Benzene is a risk factor for leukemia and not bladder carcinoma.

Cigarette smoking is the main etiological factor. Other risk factors include exposure to aniline dyes like benzidine and naphthylamine, schistosomiasis, and cyclophosphamide. The majority of it is transitional cell carcinoma (90%), with squamous and adenocarcinoma being rare forms.

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Subsequent clots and urinary retention can occur. Increased frequency and discomfort during urination may be seen. It can lead to pelvic pain due to extravesical spread, loin pain due to hydronephrosis, and suprapubic pain if the nerve is involved.

Management is as follows:

  • Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer - Endoscopic resection and intravesical instillations of mitomycin C/ epirubicin, immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  • Muscle invasive bladder cancer - Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection, with/without neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Related Pearl: Etiological Factors for Bladder Carcinoma

Histological subtype Risk factors
Transitional cell carcinoma (urothelial) Smoking
Exposure to aniline dyes
Cyclophosphamide
Pelvic irradiation
Squamous cell carcinoma Schistosomiasis (S. haematobium)
Chronic irritation caused by stone disease
Bladder diverticula
Chronic UTI
Smoking
Adenocarcinoma

Persistent urachus or trigone of the bladder
Congenital bladder exstrophy

Inherited cancer syndromes:

  • Lynch syndrome
  • Hereditary retinoblastoma
  • Costello syndrome

Acquired genetic mutations:

  • Gain of function mutation in FGFR3
  • Activating mutations in RAS and PI-3 kinase
  • Disruption of p53 and RB genes in muscle-invasive cancers

questions.text: During the delivery of a lady with polyhydramnios, an intern pulls the umbilical cord before the separation of the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals an intact placenta with the uterus partly outside the introitus. Initial resuscitative measures are taken for shock. Which of the following findings does not correlate with the diagnosis?

choices.text: The fundus is inverted into the uterine cavity.
The uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina.
The fundus is inverted into the uterine cavity and the cervical os lies at the introitus.
The whole uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus.

questions.solution:
The fundus inverted into the uterine cavity, and the cervical os lying at the introitus is a feature of uterine prolapse and does not correlate with the diagnosis of uterine inversion in this patient.

Uterine prolapse is associated with the descent of the cervix into the vagina, to the level of introitus, or outside the vaginal orifice. In an inversion, the uterus is turned inside out without any descent of the cervix.

The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic shock after attempts of removal of the placenta before placental separation is suggestive of uterine inversion. It is a hemorrhagic complication encountered in the puerperium. Polyhydramnios in this patient contribute to overdistension of the uterus and uterine atony.

Risk factors for uterine inversion:

  • Fundal attachment of the placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Attempts at cord traction before placental delivery
  • Adherent placenta

There are 3 degrees of uterine inversion:

  • First-degree - the fundus of the uterus inverts into the uterine cavity
  • Second-degree - the uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina
  • Third-degree - the whole of the uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus

Since uterine inversion presents with profuse bleeding and a severe degree of shock, it requires prompt diagnosis and management. It is managed by promptly repositioning the uterus by exerting a firm and constant pressure on the inverted uterine fundus. The placenta should not be removed until after the replacement of the uterus if it is still attached to the uterus.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The test shown is the alternate cover test, where the cover alternates from one eye to the other and both eyes move each time. This reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate and helps differentiate between concomitant and paralytic squints.

Other options:

Maddox test is a subjective test used to detect and measure horizontal, vertical, latent, or manifest squint. It uses a series of fused red cylindrical glass rods that convert a white spot of light into a red streak of light.

The following is an image of Maddox rod and pen torch:

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon is performing a tympanoplasty on a patient with a fixed footplate, where he places the graft on the window created on the horizontal semicircular canal. Which type of tympanoplasty is being performed according to Wullstein's classification?
questions.solution:
Type 5 tympanoplasty, also known as fenestration operation, is being performed in the given patient.

Type 5 tympanoplasty is done in patients with fixed footplate of stapes but having a normally functioning round window. In such patients, another window is created on the horizontal semicircular canal, and it is covered with graft.

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate exposed
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

Image showing different types of tympanoplasty:

SCC: Semicircular canal.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of a bilateral, non-pulsatile headache of tightening quality. She describes it as wearing a tight cap. She has no nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia. She also gives a history that she has had similar headaches for about 10 days in the past month. All the following treatment methods can be used in this patient, except__________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of episodic or infrequent tension-type headache (TTH). Amitriptyline is used in the management of chronic TTH, i.e. TTH which occurs >15 days per month.

Diagnosis of  TTH is made in cases of headaches that are not associated with throbbing, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, osmophobia, phonophobia, or aggravation with movement. TTH usually starts slowly and fluctuates in severity. It can be episodic or chronic (persist for >15 days).

Treatment of TTH includes simple analgesics such as acetaminophen, aspirin, or NSAIDs. Relaxation techniques as a part of behavioral therapy can also be useful. Triptans, selective serotonin receptor inhibitors (SSRIs), and benzodiazepines are not useful in the treatment of this condition. 

Amitriptyline is the only drug that is useful in chronic TTH.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distension. On further evaluation, the beta-hCG levels were persistently elevated, and cannon-ball foci were found on the chest x-ray. Which of the following is true regarding staging and management in this case?

choices.text: Calculate the WHO prognostic score to decide on management
It is FIGO Stage IV disease
Always treat with combination chemotherapy - EMACO regimen

questions.solution:
The true statement about the management in this case is to calculate the WHO prognostic score and classify it as a low or high-risk case to decide on management. (Option A)

This woman with a history of dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy presenting with abdominal pain, distension, and persistently elevated beta HCG levels has gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). The presence of cannonball foci on the chest x-ray suggests metastasis to the lung, which falls under Stage III of FIGO classification. (Option B)

Management of a case of GTN is based on the WHO prognostic scoring system that classifies it as low or high-risk GTN.

  • Low-risk GTN (score <7): Single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate (MTX) or dactinomycin (less commonly used). Methotrexate is supplemented with folinic acid on alternate days as it is a folic acid antagonist.
  • High-risk GTN (score ≥7): Combination chemotherapy is the treatment of choice as such patients are likely to develop drug resistance to single-agent chemotherapy. The preferred multiple-agent chemotherapy regime is the EMACO regime. (Option C)
    • Etoposide
    • Methotrexate
    • Dactinomycin (actinomycin D)
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Vincristine (Oncovin)

Patients with stage I disease infrequently have a high-risk score, while those with stage IV disease invariably have a high-risk score.

Radiotherapy may only be required as a part of aggressive multimodality therapy in cases with metastasis to the brain (Option D).

Scoring is based on the WHO prognostic scoring system, as adapted by FIGO. It is as follows.

 Prognostic Factor Score
0 1 2 4
Age < 40  >40 - -
Antecedent gestation Mole Abortion Term -
Interval in months <4 4-6 7-12 >12
Pretreatment serum hCG (IU/L) < 103 103 to < 104 104 to < 105 > 105
Largest tumor size (including uterus) <3 3-4 ≥ 5  -
Site of metastases Lung Spleen, kidney GI tract Brain, liver
Number of metastases - 1-4 5-8 >8
Previously failed chemotherapy  - - single drug ≥ 2 drugs
  • Low-risk GTN: Score <=6
  • High-risk GTN: Score >=7

 

FIGO Anatomic Staging of GTN is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. A hysterosalpingogram revealed a uterine abnormality. Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography was done to confirm the diagnosis, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following is a false statement?

choices.text: Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can also be used to confirm the diagnosis
The condition occurs because the medial segments of the Müllerian ducts fail to regress
Hysteroscopic septal resection is the treatment of choice
This is a case of uterus didelphys

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette in this case points to a diagnosis of septate uterus.

The clinical scenario of a young woman with a history of recurrent abortions and uterine anomaly on a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) points to a Mullerian anomaly of the uterus. With respect to the Mullerian anomalies, HSG cannot differentiate between a septate uterus and a bicornuate uterus, and a transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV USG), MRI, or hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy (Option A) can be done to differentiate between them.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity because the medial segments of the Müllerian ducts fail to regress (Option B). This creates a permanent septum within the uterine cavity. The septum can project partially from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os.

Hysteroscopic septal resection is a preferred treatment option for the septate uterus as it avoids uterine scarring and the need for elective cesarean that is required in case of abdominal surgery.

The 3D TV USG image below, which shows a smooth external fundal contour, an internal indentation at the fundal midline exceeding 50% of the uterine wall thickness, and a narrow intercornual angle (<90 degrees), confirms the diagnosis of the septate uterus. On the contrary, a bicornuate uterus would have an external indentation at the fundal midline exceeding 50% of the uterine wall thickness.

Note: Uterus didelphys is an anomaly that arises from the incomplete fusion of the Mullerian ducts, resulting in two entirely separate hemiuteri, two cervices, and a longitudinal vaginal septum running between the two cervices in most cases. The HSG is confirmatory, showing two different endocervical canals opening into separate noncommunicating fusiform endometrial cavities.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is under therapeutic hypothermia for treatment. Which of the following is not an indication for therapeutic hypothermia?

choices.text: More than 6 hours of age at the time of initiating therapeutic hypothermia
Apgar scores of <5 at ten minutes

questions.solution:
More than 6 hours of age at the time of initiating therapeutic hypothermia is a criterion of exclusion for therapeutic hypothermia in neonates.

The criteria to start therapeutic hypothermia in an infant with HIE are given below. Infants are sequentially assessed using these criteria:

Criterion 1: Infants at >36 weeks of gestation with one out of the following four criteria

  • Apgar scores <5 at ten minutes
  • Positive pressure ventilation is required at ten minutes
  • Umbilical cord pH or any arterial pH <7, within 1 hour of life
  • Base deficit of more than 16 mmol/L in cord blood or arterial blood within 1 hour of life

Criterion 2: If the infant meets the above criterion, assess for the modified Sarnat stage. Therapeutic hypothermia can be started for infants classified with Stage 2 or 3 encephalopathy, as per the modified Sarnat score.

  • In Sarnat Stage 2 encephalopathy, the neonate is lethargic and hypotonic, with strong distal flexion and overactive tendon reflex. Seizures are common in stage 2. 
  • In Sarnat Stage 3 encephalopathy, the neonate may be in a stupor and may be flaccid, with decerebrate posturing. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished.   
If the infant meets criteria 1 and 2, therapeutic hypothermia can be started.

The exclusion criteria for therapeutic hypothermia in neonates are as follows: 

  1. Gestational age <36 weeks 
  2. Birth weight <1.8 kg (some units consider less than 2000 grams)
  3. More than 6 hours of age at the time of initiating therapeutic hypothermia
  4. Life-threatening conditions of the respiratory or cardiovascular system. ( e.g., diaphragmatic hernia requiring ventilation or complex congenital heart disease)
  5. Chromosomal anomaly such as trisomy 13 or 18
  6. Death appears inevitable
  7. Life-threatening coagulopathy with significant active bleeding 
  8. Significant head trauma or skull fracture, causing major intracranial hemorrhage
  9. Imperforate anus
  10. Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) is a relative contraindication

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient came with sharp, severe, constant, burning pain over his right back. On examination, a rash is seen, with lesions as seen in the image below. The area is also tender to light touch. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with burning pain and the image showing a localized, unilateral rash consisting of grouped red papules and a few vesicles are suggestive of herpes zoster. Oral acyclovir 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days is the treatment of choice.

Herpes zoster is due to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) from the dorsal root ganglia of a sensory nerve following initial infection with varicella (chickenpox) during childhood. The risk of VZV reactivation is greatest in those with advanced age due to waning cell-mediated immunity. Recent trauma also increases the risk due to traumatic sensory nerve stimulation.

It manifests as dermatomal pain (burning, throbbing, stabbing, pruritic) that precedes the rash by days or weeks followed by a unilateral dermatomal rash. The rash begins as erythematous papules, grouped vesicles, and crusts within 7-10 days. The characteristic feature is cut-off at the mid-line. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatome are also involved. The lymph nodes are tender and enlarged.

Treatment involves starting oral acyclovir 800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days or valacyclovir 1 g three times a day for 7 days when the patient presents with one or two days of rash.

The commonest and most intractable sequel of zoster is post‐herpetic neuralgia, generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than a month after the onset of zoster, but better considered after 3 months.

Other Options:

Option A- Oral amitryptiline, a tricyclic antidepressant, is used to treat postherpetic neuralgia. It is not used in the acute phase of herpes zoster.

Option B- Rest and analgesics can be advised in young individuals with mild attacks.

Option C- Intravenous acyclovir is used in immunosuppressed patients and is the second line of treatment.

questions.text: A patient with heart failure had a heart transplant done last month. On his follow-up visit, the physician massages one side of his neck near the bifurcation of the common carotid. Theoretically, which of the following can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Stimulation of baroreceptors in a denervated heart causes a decrease in blood pressure.

During rest, sleep, or emotional tranquility, the parasympathetic nervous system predominates and controls the heart rate at a resting rate of 60-75 bpm. Most blood vessels lack parasympathetic innervations and their diameter is regulated by the sympathetic nervous system. It is a decrease in sympathetic stimulation or tone that allows vasodilatation. The transplanted heart is devoid of parasympathetic innervation (vagal supply) that is involved in decreasing the heart rate following baroreceptor stimulation. Hence, there is no change in the heart rate. However, the blood vessels that are under sympathetic control undergo vasodilation following baroreceptor stimulation due to a decrease in sympathetic tone.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and blood vessels including the aortic arch and carotid sinus. The carotid sinus is supplied by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) and the aortic arch by a branch of the vagus nerve (X CN).

When the carotid sinus is stimulated by massage, it discharges at an increased rate and excites the nucleus tractus solitarius, further leading to increased vagal stimulation. Down the lane, the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is inhibited decreasing sympathetic discharge.

These neural changes produce vasodilation, venodila­tion, hypotension, bradycardia, and a decrease in cardiac output. Since this patient has a transplanted heart that is devoid of vagal supply (denervated heart), the expected decrease in heart rate is not seen.

In addition to autonomic control, cardiovascular function is also influenced by numerous endocrine hormones one such being catecholamines from the adrenal gland. Hence, the effect of inotropes that are released into the bloodstream can still be seen.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

Related Pearl: Humoral Regulation of BP

questions.text: An infant with growth retardation and hydrocephalus is found to have pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly on examination. He also has features of cranial nerve entrapment. What is the most probable radiographic sign seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the infantile form of osteopetrosis, in which the rugger jersey sign is seen on spine x-ray.

Osteopetrosis is due to defective osteoclastic activity. Excessive new bone formation with defective resorption leads to abnormal development of the skull, especially causing narrowing of the foramina of the skull. This leads to various complications such as hydrocephalus, cranial nerve compression leading to deafness and facial palsy, and sinus blockage. 

Failure of bone resorption results in a poorly formed medullary cavity. This leads to defective hematopoiesis in the medullary cavity and stimulation of extramedullary hematopoiesis. Hence, the infant presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly.

Radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae lead to rugger jersey appearance of vertebrae on the radiograph.

Note: Rugger jersey spine is also seen in renal osteodystrophy.

Option B: Squaring and bridging of the vertebral body, leading to a bamboo spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis

Option C: A diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity is referred to as the ivory vertebra is seen in Paget's disease.

Option D: Codfish vertebra refers to the biconcave deformity of the vertebral body and is seen in osteoporosis or osteomalacia.

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of neck swelling as shown. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the swelling?

choices.text: It is due to persistence of the thyroglossal tract.
Medullary  carcinoma is  commonly associated with this condition.
Sistrunk’s operation is done to excise the swelling.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a thyroglossal cyst. The incorrect statement is that medullary carcinoma is associated with this condition. Malignant transformation is rare, and the most common type of cancer associated is papillary (85%).

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. It represents the persistence of the thyroglossal tract. It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct: 

Beneath foramen cecum → Floor of mouth → Suprahyoid → Region of thyroid cartilage → Subhyoid (most common site)

Clinically, the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), non-tender, mobile, and often transilluminate.

The most common complication is infection. Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and the suprahyoid tract.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves are involved in the corneal reflex?
questions.solution:
The afferent of the corneal reflex is the trigeminal nerve (ophthalmic division), which is marked as 4 in the image, and the efferent is the facial nerve, which is marked as 2. Hence, option D is the right answer.

The nerves marked in the image are as follows:

1. Oculomotor nerve

2. Facial nerve

3. Abducens nerve

4. Trigeminal nerve

The image below shows the anterior surface of the pons and the cranial nerves.

questions.text:
An HIV-positive mother who is not on ART gave birth to a girl child. She is planning to exclusively breastfeed the baby. Which of the following ARV prophylaxis is indicated for this baby?

ARV - Antiretroviral therapy

choices.text: Syrup nevirapine or syrup zidovudine from birth to 6 weeks
Syrup nevirapine or syrup zidovudine from birth to 12 weeks
Syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine from birth to 6 weeks
Syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine from birth to 12 weeks

questions.solution:
A baby born to an HIV-positive mother who is not on ART is classified as a high-risk infant. The recommended ARV prophylaxis is syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine from birth to 12 weeks for exclusively breastfed infants.

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count, and clinical stage and should be continued lifelong.

Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) is recommended for all HIV-exposed infants. At 6 months of age, these infants should be offered complementary foods along with breast milk.

Infants should receive ARV prophylaxis. A single drug or dual drug regimen is followed depending on the risk of transmission which can be low or high risk.

  • Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 
  • High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks, or mothers newly diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.
HIV Risk  ARV prophylaxis Duration
Low-risk infants Syrup nevirapine or zidovudine

 Birth to 6 weeks of age irrespective of feeding 
High-risk infants Syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine
  • Exclusive replacement feeding: Birth to 6 weeks
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: Birth till 12 weeks

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with vomiting. He was prescribed metoclopramide, following which he developed spasms of facial muscles, difficulty in speech, and torticollis. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the treatment of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has developed symptoms of dystonia due to metoclopramide. Diphenhydramine is used in drug-induced dystonia.

Metoclopramide has dopamine receptor antagonist, 5HT4 agonist, and 5HT3 antagonist properties. It is indicated in patients with gastroparesis and is also used in reducing nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

Dopamine receptor antagonist property is responsible for extrapyramidal symptoms. The dystonic reaction is one of the extrapyramidal symptoms. Features include spasms of muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back. It can be treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine.

Other extrapyramidal symptoms include parkinsonian-like symptoms that may occur several weeks after initiation of therapy. It responds to treatment with anticholinergic or antihistaminic drugs and reverses on discontinuation of metoclopramide. Tardive dyskinesia can develop in patients treated for a prolonged period with metoclopramide.

Other options:

Option A: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. It inhibits MAOA and MAOB to prevent the breakdown of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin. It is used in the treatment of major depression. The major adverse effects include weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and hypertensive crisis if taken along with tyramine-containing foods/ beverages.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist and is classified under typical antipsychotics. They are noted to improve the positive symptoms of schizophrenia and acute mania. The major adverse effects are extrapyramidal side effects, sedation, weight gain, hypotension, metabolic adverse effects, and photosensitivity.

Option D: Prochlorperazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist which is used as an anti-emetic. It is mainly used in motion sickness. The main adverse events are extrapyramidal symptoms including dystonia, cardiac effects, and hypotension.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text: A young male with a history of drug abuse is brought to casualty in an altered state. His 8-year-old sister has ADHD. His parents show an empty pill bottle that he might have taken. Which of the following is likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a substance abuse history and access to ADHD medication now probably has stimulant intoxication. He is most likely to have tachycardia.

Methylphenidate, dextroamphetamine, and dextroamphetamine/amphetamine combination products are stimulant medications that are used for the treatment of ADHD in children. These drugs are often used by drug abusers.

Symptoms of intoxication include agitation, irritability, aggression, impulsive and potentially dangerous sexual behaviour, increased psychomotor activity, and potentially, symptoms of mania. The major associated physical symptoms are tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, and mydriasis.

Management in terms of airway, breathing, and circulation as with any other poisoning is done first. Benzodiazepines are used to treat cardiovascular side effects.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: Which of the following services would be provided under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) scheme?

choices.text: Quality antenatal care free of cost on 9th of every month
Free transport service between home and institution
Safe motherhood services under the Vande Mataram scheme
Improve quality of care in labor room and maternal OTs

questions.solution:
The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) scheme provides safe motherhood services under the Vande Mataram scheme.

Janani Suraksha Yojana is a safe motherhood intervention launched under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

Services provided by the JSY:

  • Cash is disbursed to the mother at the institution for having an institutional delivery.
  • Safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, TT vaccination) under the Vande Mataram scheme 
  • Village health and nutrition day
  • Maternal death review
  • Pregnancy tracking: ASHA worker/Anganwadi Worker (AWW) or any other link worker help in monitoring antenatal check-ups, and post-delivery care.
  • Safe abortion services: Mifepristone followed by misoprostol and manual vacuum aspiration

Other options:

Option A: Quality antenatal care (including investigations and drugs) is provided free of cost on the 9th of every month under Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA).

Option B: Free transport service from home to institution, between facilities in case of referral, and back to home is provided free of cost under the Janani-Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK). The main aim of JSSK is to provide no-expense delivery, including a cesarean section, to all pregnant women delivering in public health services.

Option D: LaQshya program mainly aims to improve the quality of care in the labor room and maternal OTs.

questions.text: A patient with HIV comes with complaints of dysphagia and odynophagia. He is not on any medications. Examination of the oral cavity shows a normal mucosa. What will you give as the the next best step?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an HIV patient not on treatment presenting with dysphagia and odynophagia is suggestive of esophagitis. The common cause of esophagitis in an immunosuppressed patient is Candida; hence, next step for this patient is giving oral fluconazole.

Esophagitis due to Candida albicans is common in immunocompromised patients taking steroids, chemotherapy, and HIV. The most common symptoms are dysphagia, odynophagia, and retrosternal chest pain. Odynophagia is a hallmark of esophageal candidiasis. Thrush in the oral cavity or throat may be seen, but not in all cases, and endoscopy would show numerous white plaques. 

Patients who are immunosuppressed and have symptoms of odynophagia or dysphagia can be empirically treated with a course of antifungal therapy. Unlike oropharyngeal candidiasis, esophageal candidiasis should always be treated with systemic agents and not topical agents hence topical nystatin can be ruled out (option B).

The other organisms that cause esophagitis in immunocompromised persons are cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes. If no improvement in symptoms is seen after 72 hours of starting antifungal therapy, then an upper endoscopy should be performed. Oral valacyclovir and ganciclovir (options C and D) can be used for the treatment of herpes and cytomegalovirus infection, respectively, after being confirmed by endoscopy and biopsy and not treated empirically.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, with a history of burn injury a few years back, presented with the finding as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: The most common presentation is basal cell carcinoma.
Biopsy is contraindicated in this condition.

questions.solution:
The image shows a Marjolin ulcer. The true statement is that it is a painless condition.

It is a squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic scars like burn scars or from scars of venous ulcers. It is a slow-growing and locally malignant disease. The scar does not contain nerves, hence it is painless.

The tumor may initially present as

  • Ulceration
  • Nodules 
  • Rolled or everted wound margins
  • Excessive granulation tissue
  • A rapid increase in size
  • Bleeding on touch.

For the diagnosis, an edge-wedge biopsy can be done. MRI of the part and regional node area is done to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves wide local excision and in case of a large ulcer, amputation is required.

Vacuum therapy is contraindicated for malignant wounds.

questions.text: You are a resident observing an intern resuscitate a newborn in the labor room. After half a minute of bag and mask ventilation by the intern, the infant is still pale and hypoxic. What would be your advice to the intern?

choices.text: Readjust the mask and head position

questions.solution:
The next step in this newborn with ineffective bag and mask ventilation (BMV) is to readjust the mask and reposition the head.

Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) by BMV is given when infants fail to breathe at birth. The infant's neck is slightly extended to make sure the airway is open. The care provider is at the head end of the baby and a face mask of appropriate size is chosen to cover the mouth and nose. The adequacy of ventilation is indicated by visible chest rise and when normal chest rise is observed, ventilation should be started.

Increasing heart rate; spontaneous respiration; and improvement in color, saturation, and tone help to assess the infant's improvement.

When there is no improvement after 30 seconds of BMV(according to Nelson textbook of pediatrics) or 15 seconds of BMV (according to the Indian Association of Pediatrics), ventilation corrective steps should be taken. It is as follows - MRSOPA

  • Mask has to be reapplied 
  • Reposition the infant's head
  • Suction the secretions
  • Open the mouth
  • Increase the Pressure
  • Use an Alternative airway.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man with diabetic retinopathy and macular edema presents with redness and pain in his eyes. On investigation, his IOP was 36 mm of Hg. Which of the following drug classes would not be preferred to reduce the IOP in this patient?

IOP - Intraocular pressure

choices.text: Drugs that decrease aqueous humor formation

questions.solution:
Prostaglandin analogs reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) by increasing uveoscleral outflow and must be used with caution in patients with cystoid macular edema; therefore, this class of drugs would not be preferred in this patient who has macular edema.

Adverse effects of PGF2α analogs:

  • Blurring of vision
  • Macular edema (especially in aphakic patients)
  • Eyelash hypertrichosis
  • Iris pigmentation (heterochromia iridis)
  • Peri-orbital fat depletion

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms are not associated with the poisoning of the substance shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows elemental mercury. Burtonian line is not associated with mercury poisoning, but with lead poisoning. 

Mercury poisoning can result in the following conditions:

  • Minamata disease (organic mercurial poisoning due to ingestion of fish poisoned by mercury)
  • Metal fume fever (through inhalation while heating metal in a closed room)
  • Infantile acrodynia/pink disease/hydrargyria/erythroderma polyneuropathy/ Calomel disease

The pearl given below lists the clinical features associated with mercury poisoning:

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument given in the image below?

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Reduction of the fracture of nasal septum
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is Asch forceps. It is mainly used to reduce nasal septum fracture.

Walsham forceps are mainly used in disimpacting and reducing fractures of the nasal bones.

The following are the images of Walsham and Asch forceps, respectively:

Luc forceps is used in Caldwell-Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

Kerrison punch forceps is used in punching out the bone in the DCR procedure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls. What is the site of the lesion of this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario of the elderly man presenting with resting tremors, difficulty in initiating movements, poor balance, and frequent falls is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, and the site of the lesion is substantia nigra.

Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans. It shows an accumulation of synucleins. Bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremors, and postural instability are classic features of Parkinson's disease.

Other options:

Option B: Thalamus plays a role in memory, emotions, the sleep-wake cycle, and in the processing of sensory information and relaying it to the cortex. Lesions in the thalamus are seen in a multitude of disorders including vascular diseases, metabolic disorders, inflammatory diseases, and infections.

Option C: A lesion in the subthalamic nucleus causes sudden violent involuntary, and flinging movements confined to one side of the body, commonly affecting the proximal muscles of the limbs, a condition called hemiballismus. The movements are seen contralateral to the side of the lesion.

Option D: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

The image below shows hemiballismus.
