questions.text: A lady developed hypopigmentation over her scalp as shown below. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Crocein scarlet MOO and solvent yellow 3

questions.solution:
This is most likely a case of hair dye depigmentation caused by p-phenylenediamine (PPD), which is present in hair dyes.

This is called contact leukoderma or chemical leukoderma in which the chemical increases sensitivity and induces apoptosis of the melanocytes in the area of contact. There is also evidence that azo dyes, by virtue of structural similarity to tyrosine, can directly inhibit melanogenesis by competing with that amino acid for binding with the tyrosinase enzyme.

Chemical leukoderma Causative chemicals
Bindi leukoderma Para-tertiary butyl-phenol (PTBP)

Synthetic leather, rubber slippers, latex condoms, rubber gloves

Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBH)-Rubber antioxidant

Hair dye

 p-Phenylenediamine (PPD)

Alta (red color like henna)

 Crocein scarlet MOO and solvent yellow 3 (azo dyes)

The image below shows synthetic leather/ rubber-related leucoderma.

 

The image below shows Alta depigmentation.

 

The image below shows bindi leukoderma.

questions.text: Test A is used to screen a patient for a particular disease. Test B is done to confirm the diagnosis of the same disease. Which of the following would be true for Test B?

choices.text: Used as a basis for treatment

questions.solution:
Test B is a diagnostic test used to confirm the diagnosis of a disease, and it is used as a basis for treatment.

Test A is a screening test that is done on groups of apparently healthy people to screen for the presence of the disease. It is usually less accurate and less expensive.

The difference between screening and diagnostic tests is given below:

Screening test Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on patients with signs and symptoms

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients

Based on one criterion or cut-off point

Based on the evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings

Less accurate

More accurate

Less expensive

More expensive

Not a basis for treatment

Used as a basis for treatment

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Macintosh laryngoscopic blade. It is the most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for endotracheal intubation in adults.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Curved blade, Macintosh
  • Straight blade, Miller

The Macintosh blade is preferred for adults, and the Miller blade for infants.

The advantage of a curved blade is that greater room is available for the passage and manipulation of an endotracheal tube.

questions.text: A patient with an outbreak of cold sores 2 days ago now presents with non-pruritic lesions on his elbow, as seen below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of cold sores, a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, followed by the appearance of pathognomic target lesions, as seen in the image, is suggestive of erythema multiforme.

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, self-limited, skin condition that is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers. Precipitating factors commonly include HSV strains 1 and 2, EBV, and drugs like sulfa drugs. This is consistent with the patient history of having had cold sores.

It presents as a localized eruption of the skin with minimal or no mucosal involvement. The papules then evolve into pathognomonic target or iris lesions that appear within a 72-hour period and begin on the extremities. Lesions remain in a fixed location for at least 7 days and then begin to heal.  

Other options:

Option A: Viral exanthem is an eruptive skin rash that is often related to a viral infection. It can have various types of rash based on the virus associated.

Option B: Acute exanthematous pustulosis is associated with drug reaction and presents as small non-follicular pustules on an erythematous base that undergo spontaneous resolution.

Option D: Drug eruptions are cutaneous manifestations that are often related to a drug used. It can have various types of rash based on the drug used.

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

<10%

 <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to your clinic following seizures. He has had a persistent dry cough for 6 months, and he has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is confused and oriented only to person. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 119 mEq/L and a glucose concentration of 102 mg/dL. The hilar mass in the x-ray shown below is biopsied and reveals small cell carcinoma. Which of the following laboratory findings will not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a chronic smoker presenting with seizures, lethargy, and altered mental status in the setting of hyponatremia and the x-ray showing an irregular, poorly demarcated mass at the right hilum is suggestive of a Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) secondary to underlying small cell lung cancer. SIADH results in a high urine osmolality (concentrated urine) rather than a low osmolality.

SIADH can be associated with several different tumors such as that of the lung, ovaries, pancreas, and bladder. In this condition, ectopic vasopressin is produced by small-cell lung cancer, which is a neuroendocrine tumor.

Ectopic vasopressin increases the anti-diuretic property of the kidney, decreasing renal clearance and leading to SIADH. This causes increased free water retention, leading to hyponatremia (low serum osmolality) and concentration of urine, resulting in elevated urine osmolality. Water retention reduces serum osmolality, causing a transient volume expansion. This stimulates a release of ANP and BNP and reduces levels of aldosterone. Together, these processes increase urinary sodium and water excretion, thereby causing euvolemic hyponatremia.

Treatment involves the administration of conivaptan or tolvaptan (vasopressin receptor V2 antagonist), demeclocycline, and fluid restriction to less than 500 mL (although this can be difficult).

In severe cases, correction of hyponatremia is done by administering IV fluids with hypertonic normal saline along with diuretics such as furosemide (to increase free water clearance). In tumor-associated SAIDH, treatment of the underlying malignancy also helps in resolving hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks of gestation through cesarean section passed away due to an amniotic fluid embolism. Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion?

choices.text: Clinical onset during labor or within 30 minutes of placental delivery
Sudden onset of cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise

questions.solution:
Fever (temperature ≥38°C), i.e. Option D, is not a diagnostic criterion for amniotic fluid embolism (AFE). 

AFE is a condition where fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enters into the maternal pulmonary circulation. It presents with sudden-onset dyspnea, hypoxia, hypotension, and cyanosis. It can progress to encephalopathy coagulopathy and severe hemorrhage.

It is diagnosed clinically using the following criteria:

  • Clinical onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • Sudden-onset cardiorespiratory arrest or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Absence of fever (temperature ≥38°C)

Management includes supportive measures to maintain maternal hemodynamic instability and transfusions to correct coagulopathy.

Autopsy findings, as shown in the image below, include the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease

questions.text: A young man presents with a leg lesion as shown in the image below. On examination, the lesions are painful and the edges are well-demarcated and raised. He also complains of blisters over his body. He is otherwise normal and does not have any other disease. This infection is most likely to be caused by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of erythematous skin lesions with well-demarcated borders. The edge is raised. This is the hallmark of erysipelas. In immunocompetent patients, it is caused by group A Streptococcus.

Erysipelas is a bacterial infection of the superficial dermis.

Causative organisms:

  • Group A Streptococcus - Common cause
  • Group B Streptococcus - May cause infection under the age of 3 months and pelvic erysipelas after surgery
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b - causes facial cellulitis

Patients will have erythema, heat, swelling, and pain or tenderness over the affected site. The edge of the lesion is well-demarcated and raised. Blistering can also be seen. The most common site is the leg followed by the face. It can also affect the ear. Involvement of the ear is called Milian's ear sign.

It is treated with antibiotics like flucloxacillin, clarithromycin, clindamycin, and benzylpenicillin.

Another infection similar to erysipelas is cellulitis. It is the infection of loose connective tissue. It is also commonly caused by group A Streptococcus. Important differentiating features are

  • The edges of the lesions are diffuse in cellulitis
  • The ear is not involved as there is no subcutaneous tissue and deeper dermis in the ear.

Other options:

Staphylococcus aureus infection is caused when there is a breach in the continuity of epithelium or mucosa manifesting as folliculitis, impetigo, secondary infection of underlying inflam­matory skin diseases (dermatitis), boils/abscesses, or cellulitis.

Haemophilus influenzae type b is an important cause of facial cellulitis in young children especially up to the age of 2 years

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is caused by herpes simplex virus?
questions.solution:
Among the above conditions, herpes simplex virus (HSV) is associated with herpetic whitlow.

Herpetic whitlow is an infection of the finger caused by HSV. It occurs due to inoculation of the virus through a break in the epidermis by direct occupational exposure or following primary oral or genital herpes. It presents as vesicular or pustular lesion of the fingertip with edema, erythema, and tenderness of the infected finger.

The common clinical manifestations of herpes include

  • Oropharyngeal herpes
  • Genital herpes
  • Keratoconjunctivitis
  • Skin Infections like -herpetic whitlow, herpes gladiatorum, and eczema herpeticum
  • Meningitis/Encephalitis
  • Neonatal herpes

Other options:

Option A: Herpangina caused by coxsackie group A virus in children. The characteristic lesions are small vesicles and ulcers on the fauces and posterior pharyngeal wall.

Option C: The Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which is caused varicella-zoster, is a rare form of zoster affecting the facial nerve, with eruption on the tympanic membrane and the external auditory canal and, often, a facial palsy.

Option D: Kissing disease is another name given for infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr (EB) virus. It is characterized by fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and abnormal lymphocytes in the blood.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Dawson's fingers, which are suggestive of multiple sclerosis; hence, the likely diagnosis is multiple sclerosis. Dawson's fingers are periventricular demyelinating plaques perpendicular to the body of the lateral ventricles appearing as hyperintensities in T2-weighted MRI. 

Other options:

Option B: Sturge-Weber syndrome shows tram track calcification. Gyriform calcifications can be seen on the skull radiographs and are classically described as the tram-track sign. The image below shows tram-track calcification.

Option C: Hot cross bun sign is due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy. It is shown in the image below:

Option D: MRI in Joubert syndrome shows hypoplastic cerebellar vermis, with hypoplasia of the superior cerebellar peduncle, resembling the molar tooth—molar tooth sign in the mid-brain.

 

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows budding yeast cells. The clinician prescribes a single-dose oral medication. Which of the following is/are true about the drug that has been prescribed?

choices.text: It acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis
It is used in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis

questions.solution:
Fluconazole is the most likely drug that has been prescribed, and all the given statements are true about fluconazole.

The clinical symptoms of curdy white vaginal discharge and the KOH smear showing budding yeast cells suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis. The oral medication given in this condition is a single dose of fluconazole, which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

Fluconazole belongs to the azole group of antifungal drugs. The azole group of drugs is classified into two types:

  • Imidazole: clotrimazole, ketoconazole, and luliconazole
  • Triazole: itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

The azole group of drugs inhibit the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase, resulting in an impaired conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol. These drugs also inhibit hepatic cytochrome P450 (CYP2C9, CYP2C19, CYP3A4, CYP3A5, CYP3A7) and thus interact with various drugs.

Fluconazole is used in the initial 8 weeks of the consolidation phase in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. It is also useful in treating candidemia in non-immunocompromised individuals and cryptococcosis in HIV-positive individuals.

Side effects of fluconazole include nausea, headache, skin rash, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and reversible alopecia may occur with prolonged therapy. Fluconazole is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presented at 22 weeks of gestation with the results of the anomaly scan. The sonographic report showed a singleton fetus with normal amniotic fluid volume. There was a sudden termination of the spine above the level of the iliac wings and abnormal positioning of the lower extremities. Which among the following is likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg with proteinuria

questions.solution:
The clinical case described with the mentioned ultrasound findings suggests caudal regression sequence/ sacral agenesis, which is associated with overt or pregestational diabetes with high HbA1C levels ≥ 6.5.

Caudal regression sequence is a rare anomaly, characterized by the absence of the sacral spine and sometimes portions of the lumbar spine as well. It is 25 times more prevalent in pregnancies complicated by diabetes. Poorly controlled diabetes is the underlying factor for this malformation risk.

Sonography shows an abnormally short spine lacking normal lumbosacral curvature, which terminates abruptly above the level of the iliac wings. Since the sacrum does not lie between the iliac wings, they may appear shield-like because they are abnormally close together. Abnormal positioning of the lower extremities and lack of nor­mal local soft tissue development may also be seen.

The image below shows a case of sacral agenesis.

Overt diabetes may be pre-existing or detected for the first time during the present pregnancy. The following criteria are used to diagnose it according to the American Diabetes Association:

  • Random plasma glucose level of >200 mg/dL plus classic signs and symptoms such as polydipsia, polyuria, and unexplained weight loss
  • Fasting glucose level of >126 mg/dL
  • First-trimester glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level of ≥6.5%

Other options:

Option B: Blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg with proteinuria points to preeclampsia, which can lead to intrauterine death, intrauterine growth restriction, asphyxia, or prematurity of the fetus.

Option C: Use of valproate in pregnancy leads to neural tube defects, cardiac anomalies, and developmental delay. 

Option D: Lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly if taken during pregnancy. Ebstein's anomaly is characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to severe tricuspid regurgitation and marked right atrial enlargement.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. On examination, the cervical dilation is 6 cm, and uterine contractions are regular, at an interval of 3 to 5 minutes and lasting for 45 seconds each. Which stage of labor is she in?
questions.solution:
The patient is in the active phase of the first stage of labor.

The first stage of labor is characterized by dilation and effacement of the cervix and can be divided into the latent phase and active phase.

  • The latent phase extends from the onset of true labor pains up to cervical dilation of 3-4 cm. The latent phase is said to be prolonged if it extends beyond 20 hours in nullipara and beyond 14 hours in multipara.
  • The active phase begins from cervical dilation of 6 cm according to ACOG guidelines. Cervical dilatation of ≥5 cm in the presence of uterine contractions can be taken to reliably represent the threshold for active labor. Uterine contractions initially come at an interval of 15 to 30 minutes and last for 30 seconds, but later gradually increase in intensity and duration and come at an interval of 3 to 5 minutes lasting for up to 45 seconds.

The second stage of labor begins with complete cervical dilatation and ends with fetal delivery.

The third stage of labor is characterized by the delivery of the placenta.

The fourth stage is a stage of observation for at least an hour after the full expulsion of the placenta.

 

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty ward following a road traffic accident. His GCS score was 3, and he was intubated. The CT scan was found to be normal. MRI of the brain was performed and the findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and a susceptibility-weighted MRI image (SWI) demonstrating hypointense foci of microhemorrhages are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from a rotational acceleration of the brain within the rigid cranium.

This causes damage in microvasculature and disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, fornix, and internal and external capsule.

Most commonly it occurs in automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain.
  • MRI, especially SWI, demonstrates small regions of susceptibility artifact or hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 10-year-old child comes to the emergency ward after a fall on an outstretched hand. The x-ray of the left arm is shown below. Which of the following nerves would be commonly injured?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows a posterior displaced (extension-type) supracondylar fracture of the humerus that commonly affects the anterior interosseous nerve. Supracondylar fracture of the humerus may injure either the median nerve or radial nerves. But, on meta-analysis, it was found that the frequency of nerve injury is as follows: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve

The anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) of the median nerve is the commonly injured nerve in supracondylar fractures in children. It presents with the same symptoms as high median nerve injury but without any sensory loss. Patients with anterior interosseous nerve injury have a characteristic pinch defect and are unable to make the OK gesture due to weakness of the flexors of the thumb and the index finger.  

There is loss of abduction of the thumb and paralysis of the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles. So, when asked to make a fist, the patient flexes the ulnar fingers and extends the index finger resulting in the pointing index sign. In an isolated anterior interosseous nerve injury, there is no sensory loss.

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of unprotected intercourse 3 days ago. Which of the following methods of hormonal emergency contraception is preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ulipristal acetate 30 mg single dose is the preferred hormonal contraception for this patient. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It can be taken up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. Side effects include headache, nausea, and mood changes.

Other options:

Option A: CuT is a non-hormonal method of contraception. It can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected sexual intercourse. It is cheap and can remain an ongoing contraception method for 3 to 5 years. The failure rate is 0.1%.

Option B: Centchroman is effective only if taken within 24 hours of unprotected sexual intercourse. 60 mg tablet taken twice in 24 hours can be effective in preventing implantation in 99% of women.

Option D: Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg, i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg, can be used as a single-dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75 mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered for up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in the interval between coitus and drug intake.

Advantages of LNG:

  • It does not contain estrogen and therefore precludes the associated side effects.
  • It can be used in hypertensive, cardiac, and diabetic patients.
  • It is suitable for lactating women.
  • It can be given up to 120 hours after unprotected intercourse.
  • It can be given as a single-dose therapy. 

 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text:
An asthmatic patient complains of wheezing and shortness of breath most days of the week. He is currently on medium-dose maintenance ICS+formoterol but continues to have exacerbations. Which of the following is the preferred drug to be used as a reliever in this patient?

LABA- Long-acting β2 agonist

ICS- Inhaled corticosteroids

LAMA- Long-acting muscarinic antagonist
questions.solution:
As per Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, formoterol + low-dose ICS is the preferred reliever in all cases of asthma irrespective of what controller the patient is on.

In this question, the patient continues to have exacerbations despite being on medium-dose maintenance ICS+formoterol -controller therapy. The preferred reliever in this patient is still formoterol + low-dose ICS. 

Formoterol+medium-dose ICS+LAMA (Option 4) is the controller that can be used in the next step of his management.

Controllers are the drugs that reduce asthma exacerbations and improve long-term control, decreasing the need for intermittent use of bronchodilator therapies. In comparison, relievers are drugs that relax smooth muscles and produce rapid relief of acute symptoms.

Short-acting β2 agonist is an alternative reliever that can be used to manage all cases of asthma.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: A forensic examiner was examining a skull and pelvis. The pelvic brim was circular,  the cavity was broad and round, the sub-pubic angle was U-shaped,  and the greater sciatic notch looked large. The ischial tuberosity was everted and widely separated. The skull looked smooth with rounded orbits, a small mandible, and large frontal and parietal eminences. What will be his conclusion after examining these bones?

choices.text: Pelvis of a male, but skull of a female
Pelvis of a female, but skull of a male
Both the skull and pelvis appear to be of a female
Both the skull and pelvis appear to be of a male

questions.solution:
Both the skull and the pelvis belong to a female skeleton. 

The female pelvic brim is circular, the cavity is broad and round, the sub-pubic angle U-shaped, and the greater sciatic notches are large. The skull is smooth with round orbits, a small mandible, and the frontal and parietal eminences are larger in a female skull. 

Differentiating features between male and female skulls:

Trait Male Skull Female Skull
General size Large Small
Architecture Rugged Smooth
Supraorbital ridges Prominent Less prominent
Mastoid process Prominent Less prominent
Occipital region Marked muscle markings No marked muscle markings
Frontal eminences Small Large
Parietal eminences Small Large
Orbits Square with round margins Round with sharp margins
Mandible Large, broad ramus Small, small ramus
Chin shape U-shaped Rounded

Note: The features given above develop after puberty and are modified by senility. So, they are applicable only between the 20th and the 55th year.

In the image below, the red arrow indicates frontal bossing, which is more apparent in the male skull. The nasal radix (green arrow) is consequently deeper in the male skull. The yellow arrow demonstrates greater prominence of the chin in the male skull. The blue arrow shows a greater mandibular height in the male as well.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe and is scheduled for a right hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments have to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In right hemi-hepatectomy (also called right hepatectomy), segments V, VI, VII, and VIII are removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right Hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII (Option A)
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII (Option B)
  • Right anterior sectionectomy- V, VIII (Option C)
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII (Option D)
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left medial sectionectomy- IV

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to your clinic with complaints of stiffness of the joints in her fingers for the past 6 years. Identify the hand deformity shown in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the swan-neck deformity, which is seen in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Swan neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis with pain, stiffness, and swelling of the fingers being the early symptom. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought with a rash. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions are noted, with no cardiovascular abnormality. CT head shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this infant with periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly is congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

CMV is the most common congenital infection. The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness. Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Other options:

Option A- Congenital rubella syndrome is due to the rubella virus. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease. Patent ductus arteriosus is a common cardiac defect. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option B- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. Early features include hepato-splenomegaly, jaundice, diffuse lymphadenopathy, maculopapular or vesiculobullous rash involving hands and feet, persistent rhinitis (snuffles), and condylomatous lesions. 

Skeletal changes like saber shins, dental abnormalities like Hutchinson's teeth, and saddle nose - depression of the nasal root are some late findings.

Option C- Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to Toxoplasma gondii. A classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications is seen. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this. Calcifications occur randomly throughout the brain in congenital toxoplasmosis while periventricular calcification is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the structures marked as A and B?
questions.solution:
The structures marked A and B are the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, respectively. They articulate and form the cricothyroid joint which is a synovial joint.

The inferior horns of the thyroid cartilage and the cricoid cartilage form the cricothyroid joint. It is surrounded by a capsule and is reinforced by associated ligaments. The primary movement of the joint is rotation around a transverse axis that passes transversely through both cricothyroid joints. The effect of this movement is to effectively lengthen the vocal folds.  

Other options:

Option B: Bones in fibrous joints are joined by fibrous connective tissue. Three subtypes are sutures, gom­phoses, and syndesmoses, which allow a little movement. 

Option C: Primary cartilaginous joints also known as synchondroses are almost exclusively associated with growth plates.

Option D: Secondary cartilaginous joints also known as symphyses are present in manubriosternal, pubic symphysis, and intervertebral joints.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. The lower border of the swelling is not palpable. Chest x-ray shows the following finding, and a diagnosis of retrosternal goiter is made. All the following additional features might need an open sternotomy approach, except _____.

choices.text: Goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of retrosternal goiter, open sternotomy is not indicated if the goiter is located above the aortic arch. Extension of the goiter below the aortic arch is an indication of open sternotomy.

A majority of retrosternal goiters can be removed through the transcervical approach. It might need to an open sternotomy approach in case,

  • Malignant cases.
  • Goiters that extend into the posterior mediastinum.
  • Diameter of the goiter exceeds that of the thoracic inlet.
  • Goiters that reach the carina.
  • Goiters that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch.

Midline sternotomy is preferred if the gland is fixed and immobile or too large to deliver through a cervical approach. 

Retrosternal goiter is usually asymptomatic and does not require surgery. Surgery is indicated if the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet. The pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient presents with complaints of recurrent periods of prolonged sleep with intervening periods of normal sleep. He says that he sleeps up to 20 hours at a time and has increased appetite and libido. He does not have any pre-existing disorder and is not on any medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Kline-Levin syndrome.

Kleine-Levin syndrome is a disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of excessive sleep, called hypersomnia, along with cognitive and behavioral changes.

Affected individuals may sleep for up to 20 hours per day during an episode. These episodes usually last for a few days to a few weeks. It is also associated with excessive food intake, irritability, and an abnormally uninhibited sex drive. Affected individuals are symptom-free between episodes.

The syndrome primarily affects adolescent males but also females and individuals of other ages. The underlying cause of this condition is unknown. Possible etiologies are a psychologic disturbance, trauma, toxins, infection, serotonergic or dopaminergic neurotransmitter abnormalities, and underlying hypothalamic pathology. Viral infections due to Epstein-Barr virus, Asian influenza virus, and enterovirus; typhoid vaccine; and Streptococcus have been implicated, on the basis of the frequent flu-like symptoms at onset. Episodes tend to decrease with advancing age.

Other options:

Option A:  Hypersomnia due to drug or substance use is characterized by sleepiness that occurs due to abuse of drugs like sedative-hypnotics, opioid analgesics, and sedating antihistamines. This cannot be the answer as the features mentioned are specific and suggestive of Kleine-Levin syndrome.

Option B: Idiopathic hypersomnia manifests as nocturnal sleep that is prolonged, undisturbed, and unrefreshing. There is difficulty waking up, amnesia, and autonomic nervous system dysfunction. It is characterized by migraine-like headaches, syncope, and orthostatic hypotension. The age of onset is 15-30 years.

Option D: Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone to sudden strong emotions), hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis (Brief episodes of total paralysis at the beginning or end of sleep). The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency. Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is a secondary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Image C represents crust lesions, which are secondary skin lesions.

The crust is a collection of inflammatory cells, red blood cells, plasma, and fibrin in the superficial portion of the epidermis.

Other options:

Image A shows purpura.

Image B shows a bulla.

Image D shows a pustule.

The following image shows the classification of skin lesions:

Related Pearl: Primary and Secondary Lesions of Skin

Primary lesions of the skin include:

  • Papule
  • Plaque
  • Wheal
  • Vesicle
  • Bulla
  • Nodule
  • Macule
  • Patch
  • Purpura
  • Pustule

For mnemonic lovers, the following mnemonic might help!

'Predatory Poisonous Wasps Viciously Bit on the Nose of My Patient causing Purulent Pus'

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

Mnemonic- 'LEAF SUCKS water'

  • L — Lichenification
  • E — Erosion / Excoriation
  • A — Atrophy
  • F — Fissure
  • S — Scale
  • U — Ulcer
  • C — Crust
  • K — Kind-of-hard to feel (Induration)
  • S — Scar

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy develops unbearable acute-onset pain in his scrotum, while playing football. Doppler shows absent blood flow to the right testis. Which of the following would not be seen during the examination?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and Doppler findings point to a diagnosis of testicular torsion. On examination of a case of testicular torsion, Prehn's sign is not seen.

Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis, and it is seen in epididymo-orchitis.

Testicular torsion commonly occurs in adolescents between 10 and 25 years of age and presents with nausea, vomiting, and sudden onset of severe scrotal pain. A high-riding, swollen, and tender testis with a tender twisted cord can often be palpated above it. The scrotum is erythematous with an absent cremasteric reflex.

The management is mainly based on clinical findings. In case of uncertainty, ultrasound can confirm the absent blood supply to the affected testis; however, radioisotope scanning is the most specific diagnostic test. 

Urgent scrotal exploration is indicated even in the case of a doubtful diagnosis. It is absolutely necessary to get consent for orchidectomy before the scrotal exploration.

Epididymo-orchitis is usually a differential of testicular torsion due to the redness of skin and pyrexia associated with both conditions. But, lifting the testis relieves pain in epididymo-orchitis, but worsens it in testicular torsion. Also, epididymo-orchitis is associated with dysuria.

Ultrasound shows increased blood flow and increased uptake in acute epididymo-orchitis due to the inflammation. Treatment is by antibiotics.

questions.text: In which of the following stages of puberty does estrogen not have a major role?
questions.solution:
Pubarche, or the development of pubic hair, is not mediated by estrogen.

In both sexes, adrenal androgen secretion is responsible for adrenarche—the development of axillary and pubic hair. The eventual phenotypical result of adrenarche is pubarche, increased oiliness of hair and skin, and acne.

Puberty refers to the period of transition from childhood to adult sexual maturation. On average, puberty typically begins between the ages of 8 and 13 years in females and 9 and 14 years in males. 

The following changes occur in puberty:

  • Thelarche refers to breast development, which signifies the start of puberty in girls. It is due to the action of estrogen and progesterone.
  • Pubarche occurs after thelarche, and refers to the appearance of pubic hair. Adrenarche refers to the increased secretion of adrenal androgens which leads to pubarche.
  • Growth spurt occurs due to a rise in sex steroids, which leads to an increase in growth hormone levels and IGF-1.
  • Menarche refers to the beginning of menstruation due to an increase in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).

questions.text: The pre-anesthetic evaluation of a 33-year-old male who has been posted for surgery is conducted, and the oral cavity examined is as depicted in the image given below. This would be______________ according to Mallampati classification.
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, fauces, and part of the uvula are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class II.

Mallampati classification: Here the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity is assessed. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult the intubation.

Mallampati class III and class IV are considered risk factors for difficult ventilation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with a history of intense itching in the elbows and knees. The examination findings are shown in the given image. Similar lesions are also present on his knees. He also says that whenever he starts eating whole wheat in his diet, he has severe diarrhea, abdominal pain, and bloating sensation. The doctor takes samples from the lesion and perilesional skin and sends them for direct immunofluorescence. It is likely to show the deposition of which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis. There are multiple erythematous papules over the elbows and knees, and the history of the patient suggests that he has gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Direct immunofluorescence will show the deposition of IgA antibodies.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. It can also be associated with autoimmune thyroid disease. It is associated with HLA‐DQ2.

It typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. They may also have symptoms associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea and other gastrointestinal complaints.

On examination, multiple erythematous macules and papules can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

Diagnosis can be made by clinical features, histopathology, direct immunofluorescence testing, and serology.

The histopathology of an intact vesicle in dermatitis herpetiformis will show subepidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae. Perivascular infiltrates can also be seen.

Direct immunofluorescence can be done to the skin samples taken from the lesion and perilesional skin. It will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. Complement 3 may also be found along with the IgA deposits.

Serology many show the presence of IgA anti-endomysial autoantibodies that target epidermal transglutaminase 3.

Management- Having a gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment. Because the response to a gluten-free diet takes time, dapsone is used for medium to short term in the treatment of the symptoms. 

The below image shows the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular pattern. These antibodies are epidermal transglutaminase 3.

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus

  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

  • Other disorders

According to Site
