questions.text: A delivery procedure used in a primigravida is shown below. Which of the following is not a prerequisite for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a vacuum-assisted delivery, and the presence of intact membranes is not a prerequisite for this procedure.

The prerequisites for operative vaginal delivery (forceps or vacuum application) are as follows:

  • Fetal head engaged (head ≤1/5 palpable per abdomen) (Option B)
  • Cervix fully dilated (Option A)
  • Membranes ruptured
  • Fetal head position exactly known 
  • Pelvis deemed adequate (Option C) 

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery; it facilitates delivery by creating a vacuum between itself and the fetal scalp. During vacuum-assisted delivery, the suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point. A flexion point is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanelle or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle. The flexion point and, hence, the cup is closer to the posterior fontanelle.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks POG)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

Below is the image of a vacuum extractor. 

Traction should be abandoned if

  • There is no descent of the presenting part with each pull.
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

The traction should not exceed more than 30 minutes under any circumstance. An artificial caput succedaneum-chignon is produced due to the sucking and usually disappears within a few hours. Vacuum delivery has reduced maternal pelvic floor injury, and it is the instrument of the choice in assisted delivery.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: Which of the following is not a benefit of combined estrogen-progestin oral contraceptive pills?

choices.text: Reduces menstrual blood loss and anemia

questions.solution:
Combined contraceptive pills do not increase carbohydrate tolerance. They may lead to a reduction in carbohydrate tolerance due to which combined oral pills are contraindicated or given cautiously to a diabetic woman. 

Non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptives (COCs):

A. Improvement of menstrual abnormalities such as:

  • Menorrhagia (Option A)
  • Dysmenorrhea (Option C)
  • Premenstrual tension syndrome (PMS)
  • Mittelschmerz syndrome

B. Protection against health disorders

  • Iron-deficiency anemia (Option A)
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Fibroid uterus
  • Hirsutism and acne (Option B)
  • Functional ovarian cysts
  • Benign breast disease
  • Osteopenia and postmenopausal osteoporotic fractures
  • Autoimmune disorders of the thyroid
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

C. Prevention of malignancies

  • Endometrial cancer
  • Epithelial ovarian cancer
  • Colorectal cancer

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A middle-aged man is found to have elevated levels of liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. The gene responsible for this condition is present on which chromosome?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin (α1AT) is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. α1AT deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding. The liver is affected due to the accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes and presents as chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, or hepatocellular carcinoma. Liver biopsy shows round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. 

Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase, causing panacinar emphysema. This occurs at an earlier age and is of greater severity if the individual smokes. In this type, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of a standard ultrasound examination done in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Fetal weight estimation is not a component of a standard ultrasound examination done in the first trimester. It is included in the standard ultrasound examination done in the second trimester.

The main objectives of the first-trimester ultrasound are to 

  • Identify the location and number embryo or yolk sac with sac size,
  • Assess gestational age from the crown-rump length, 
  • Confirm fetal number, including amnionicity and chorionicity of multifetal gestations,
  • Document cardiac activity, 
  • Assess fetal nuchal translucency and fetal anatomy.

In addition to confirming the findings of first trimester, the second-trimester ultrasound helps in

  • Estimating fetal weight and presentation
  • Measuring amniotic fluid
  • Identifying the location of the placenta and assessing the condition of the cord.
 

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
A newborn with a family history of hearing loss was subjected to BERA testing. The waves produced were as shown below. Wave III in the following image represents activity in which of the following?

BERA - Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry
questions.solution:
Wave III in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is due to the neural activity of the cochlear nucleus.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A primigravida with 38 completed weeks of gestation has gone into labor. Oxytocin was started to augment labor. The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is _____
questions.solution:
The second messenger system through which oxytocin acts is the phospholipase C system.

It activates the enzyme phospholipase C which breaks down some phospholipids in the cell membrane into IP3 (phosphoinositol triphosphate) and DAG (diacylglycerol). DAG then activates protein kinase C and IP3 mobilises Ca2+ from mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum to bring about smooth muscle contraction and other cellular responses.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with gastroparesis. Which of the following drugs cannot be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Gastroparesis can be treated with prokinetic agents such as metoclopramide, cisapride, and motilin. Loperamide is an orally active antimotility and antisecretory agent and cannot be used to treat gastroparesis.

Loperamide acts by increasing the mouth to the caecum and small intestine transit times and increases the tone of the anal sphincter.

Prokinetic agents enhance coordinated GI motility and the transit of material in the GI tract. They do not interfere with the normal physiological pattern and rhythm of motility. They act through the following mechanisms of action:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonists: Metoclopramide and domperidone
  • Serotonin receptor agonists: cisapride and prucalopride
  • Mimicking motilin action: Erythromycin and other macrolide antibiotics

Indications for use of prokinetic agents such as metoclopramide include gastroparesis, in medical or diagnostic procedures such as upper endoscopy or contrast radiography of the GI tract and ameliorate nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

questions.text: While performing a hernia surgery, the surgeon notices that the sac contains two loops of the bowel and that the central portion of the loop is strangulated. The diagrammatic representation of the hernia is given below. Name the hernia based on the clinical scenario and image.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image points to the diagnosis of Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-in-W. 

Maydl hernias have two small bowel loops within a single hernial sac forming a "W" shape. The center portion of the 'W' loop is strangulated and it lies within the abdominal cavity.

Other Options:

Option A: In Richter's hernia, only part of the bowel wall or portion of the circumference is the content. Strangulation can occur without any signs of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. 

Option C: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized weakness for 6 months. She has also had a 5-kg weight loss, frequent headaches, and mild fever. She has avoided eating solids because of severe jaw pain. She does not complain of any vision abnormality.  She appears pale, but examination does not reveal any other abnormalities. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ESR, CRP, and ALP. Peripheral smear shows normochromic anemia. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Oral prednisone and temporal artery biopsy
Intravenous prednisone and temporal artery biopsy
Low-dose aspirin and temporal artery biopsy

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient >50 years with fever, weakness, anemia, jaw claudication, and high ESR and CRP levels is suggestive of a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis. The best next step in management would be initiating treatment with oral steroids and a temporal artery biopsy for confirming the diagnosis.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

GCA is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. Mononeuropathies or peripheral neuropathies can also be seen. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore, patients with a clinical diagnosis of GCA, especially with headaches or visual symptoms, should be started on steroids immediately. 

This patient has no established ischemic damage or visual symptoms, so high-dose oral prednisone is preferred as the initial treatment. Oral prednisone 40–60 mg/day for 1 month is given, which is followed by gradual tapering. As the diagnosis may be done clinically, treatment is started immediately rather than delaying it after the biopsy.

Option B: On the presence of ocular signs and symptoms, high-dose intravenous steroids are preferred. Methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days is given to protect the remaining vision.

Option C: Although this patient has anemia, she has normocytic normochromic anemia in the setting of an elevated ESR and CRP, suggesting an underlying systemic disease as the cause for her anemia rather than iron deficiency. 

Option D: Aspirin reduces the occurrence of cranial ischemic complications and can be given in addition to steroids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with a fever and productive cough. On examination, bronchial breath sounds were heard and dullness on percussion was present in the right infra-scapular region. He was found to be HIV positive, with a CD4 count of 55 cells/mm3. Given below is his chest x-ray. What is the most likely underlying organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the x-ray showing consolidation in the right lower lobe are suggestive of lobar pneumonia. The most common causative organism causing lobar pneumonia even in an AIDS patient is Streptococcus pneumonia.

Patients with HIV infection are particularly prone to infections with encapsulated organisms. S. pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are responsible for most cases of bacterial pneumonia in patients with AIDS. Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. On examination, involved lobes are dull to percussion, and bronchial breath sounds and crackles are heard on auscultation.

Other options:

Option A: Pneumocystis jirovecii causes pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm3 and usually presents with fever, dry cough, and dyspnea. Inspiratory crackles are heard on auscultation. The most common finding on chest x-ray if the disease is suspected early is either a normal film or a faint bilateral interstitial infiltrate. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

The chest radiograph given below shows ground-glass opacities in PCP.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus causes bacterial pneumonia with features similar to pneumococcal pneumonia but it is not the most likely organism causing bacterial pneumonia in HIV. In adults, nosocomial S. aureus pulmonary infections are common among intubated patients in intensive care units. The differentiating feature is that chest X-ray in S. aureus infection shows pneumatoceles (cavitation).

The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air-filled cysts within lung parenchyma).

Option D:

Mycoplasma causes atypical pneumonia or walking pneumonia (as symptoms may be mild in many cases). Patients present with dry cough, fever, chills, malaise, and upper respiratory tract symptoms. On auscultation, wheezes or rales are heard later in the condition. Chest X-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with prominent bronchial markings, interstitial infiltration, and atelectasis. 

The below chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with tularemia, and the physician prescribes streptomycin for the condition. In the given image, identify the site at which this drug acts.
questions.solution:
Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside, is the drug of choice for the treatment of tularemia. Aminoglycosides bind to the 16S rRNA and S12 protein within the bacterial 30S ribosomal subunit; hence, Option B is the correct answer.

Streptomycin is bactericidal, and the killing is concentration dependant. Aminoglycoside binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit. It interferes with the initiation of protein synthesis by fixing the 30S-50S ribosomal complex at the start codon (AUG) of mRNA. Streptomycin can be administered by deep intramuscular injection or intravenously. Intramuscular injections can develop a hot, tender mass at the site of injection.

Streptomycin is also recommended for severe forms of plague and endocarditis in combination with a cell wall active agent. It is a second-line agent for the treatment of active tuberculosis and should be used in combination with at least one or two other drugs to which the causative strain is susceptible.

Streptomycin produces ototoxicity, characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. The administration of streptomycin may produce dysfunction of the optic nerve, including scotomas, presenting as an enlargement of the blind spot. Peripheral neuritis is amongst the less-common toxic reactions seen to streptomycin.

Other options:
 
Option A: Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase, which corresponds to 1 in the given picture. Dihydrofolate reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate.
 
Option C: 3 in the image corresponds to 50S inhibitors, which include macrolides, linezolid, clindamycin, and chloramphenicol.
 
Option D: 4 in the given image corresponds to fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis was started on methotrexate 3 months ago. The patient now comes for a follow-up visit. Which of the following investigations will not be performed during this visit?
questions.solution:
Serum electrolyte levels are not recommended in the monitoring of methotrexate therapy.

Methotrexate is the disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drug (DMARD) of choice for rheumatoid arthritis. It is given at 15-25 mg/kg orally or subcutaneously. It is prescribed in combination with folic acid at 1 mg/day to reduce the potential side effects.

Before a DMARD is started some investigations are done as a part of the initial evaluation to get a baseline value. Later, monitoring is done to measure the subsequent therapeutic effects and side effects of the drug. 

In the case of methotrexate, CBC, LFTs, viral hepatitis panel, and chest x-ray tests are done as a part of the initial evaluation.

Monitoring of the methotrexate therapy is done every 2-3 months with CBC, LFTs, and serum creatinine.

The following table shows the tests done for the initial evaluation and monitoring of the DMARD drugs: 

Drug Initial evaluation Monitoring

Hydroxychloroquine

Eye examination in >40 years old or h/o ocular disease

 Visual field testing and Optical coherence tomography
Sulfasalazine  CBC, LFT, G6PD level CBC

Methotrexate

CBC, LFTs, Viral hepatitis panel, Chest x-ray

CBC, creatinine, LFT

TNF-α inhibitors

 TB screening

Monitor injection site 

 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: You are an intern observing a surgery where the stones from the bile duct are removed. The instrument given below is used. Name the instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image is Desjardins choledocholithotomy forceps. It is used for the removal of stones from the common bile duct.

This is a long and slender instrument. The shaft is curved and there is a fenestra at the tip. It does not have a lock hence, accidental damage to CBD mucosa or crushing of the CBD stone is avoided.

Other options: 

Option A: Lane tissue-holding forceps have a stout and thick distal blade, with an oval fenestra in each blade. It has a lock in the proximal part. It is used to hold bulky and tough structures and lymph nodes.

Option B: Kocher forceps have an opposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades. It is used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. It is also used for holding ribs during rib dissection and for holding the resected bowel.

Option D: Lister sinus forceps are used for draining pus from the abscess cavity in Hilton's method. Initially used for inserting or removing packing in the sinus cavity. It has a long straight blade with serrations in the tip.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy developed pain in the ears and reports decreased hearing and popping sensations in both ears. Otoscopy revealed air-fluid level and bubbles. What type of curve is obtained on tympanometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the child suggests serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion or glue ear. Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in serous otitis media.

Serous otitis media is the collection of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft due to malfunctioning of the eustachian tube or increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa. It presents as conductive hearing loss, leading to delayed and defective speech in children.

Otoscopy reveals a fluid level, bubbles, and varying degrees of retraction, as shown below:

Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in serous otitis media. The fluid accumulation causes decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve, as shown below:

 

Management includes the use of decongestants, antiallergic measures initially, and myringotomy and aspiration of fluid if unresolved. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required to treat the cause of serous otitis media.

Other options: 

Option A: Type A curve is a normal tympanogram.

Option C: Type As curve is seen in fixation of ossicles such as otosclerosis.

Option D: Type C curve is seen in negative middle ear pressure and retracted tympanic membrane.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text:
A two-month-old baby presents to the OPD with noisy breathing during feeding or crying. History taking reveals that the father of the patient is a known case of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. The bronchoscopy findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Image A- Bronchoscopy image of the normal trachea.

Image B- Bronchoscopy image of the patient's trachea.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the bronchoscopy image point to a diagnosis of tracheomalacia.

Tracheomalacia is an anatomical defect of the trachea characterized by increased trachea collapsibility due to the trachea's structural abnormality.

More than half the cases of tracheomalacia are congenital and associated with connective tissue disorders, like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and cutis laxa, and are classified as primary tracheomalacia. 

Tracheomalacia can also be caused secondarily due to acquired causes that apply extrinsic pressure on the trachea like a goiter or neoplasm and causes that weaken the tracheal structure like tracheobronchitis.

The symptoms of primary tracheomalacia first develop between 4-6 weeks. It presents with high-pitched expiratory stridor, which develops when the airflow in the trachea increases due to crying, feeding, or physical activity. 

Bronchoscopy shows narrowing of the tracheal lumen with loss of semicircular shape and bulging of the posterior membranous wall.

Tracheomalacia can be treated conservatively with medical and surgical methods, based on the extent of the disease and other associated conditions.

Other options:

Option A: Reinke's edema is a condition of bilateral diffuse polyposis due to the collection of fluid in Reinke's space mainly due to vocal abuse and smoking. On bronchoscopy, bilateral diffusely swollen vocal cords can be seen.

 

 

Option B: Malignancy is characterized by symptoms of hoarseness and pain during swallowing. Patients are typically male who smokes tobacco or with a history of smoking in the past. On bronchoscopy, growth can be seen and biopsy of the lesion or fine-needle aspiration of metastatized nodes may help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option C: Laryngeal papilloma is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is characterized by the proliferation of benign squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract. On bronchoscopy, laryngeal papilloma is observed as pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core.

questions.text: An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presents with easy fatigability and pallor. The peripheral smear of this patient shows characteristic findings as shown in the image. Which of the following options best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

choices.text: Increased destruction of red blood cells

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils, which are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. This is due to impairment of DNA synthesis.

Megaloblastic anemia is commonly caused by vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency and drugs that inhibit DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism. 

Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) and folic acid are co-factors required for thymidine synthesis. Deficiency of these vitamins or impairment of their metabolism results in defective nuclear maturation due to impairment of DNA synthesis. This leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

 Peripheral smear shows:

  • Macro-ovalocytes and occasional nucleated erythroid progenitors  
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.
  • Low reticulocyte
  • Macrocytes that may appear hyperchromic due to ample hemoglobin (but the MCHC is not elevated)

Bone marrow would show all cell lineages being affected as:

  • Markedly hypercellular due to increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Megaloblasts contain finely distributed chromatin instead of clumped pyknotic chromatin.
  • Giant metamyelocytes and band forms due to dysmatured granulocytic precursors
  • Megakaryocytes with abnormally large and bizarre, multilobate nuclei.

The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) which can lead to pancytopenia.

Option A- Defective globin synthesis causes thalassemia. The peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, microcytic and hypochromic anemia. Target cells that have an accumulation of hemoglobin in the center are present. Basophilic stippling, fragmented red cells, and mild reticulocytosis are also seen.

Option C- In hemolytic anemias increased destruction of red blood cells is seen. The peripheral smear findings vary depending on the cause but hypersegmented neutrophils are not seen.

Option D- Anemia due to reduced erythropoietin production is seen in renal failure and chronic inflammation. The peripheral smear shows either normocytic, normochromic anemia or microcytic, hypochromic anemia as in iron deficiency.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Type of anemia

Microcytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Thalassemia trait

Basophilic stippling, target cells 

Iron-deficiency

Elliptocytes, target cells

Sideroblastic anemia

Pappenheimer bodies, RBC dimorphism, ringed sideroblasts (Perl’s stain) 

Macrocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Myelodysplastic syndrome

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis 

Megaloblastic anemia

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Polychromasia (purple reticulocyte) +/- spherocytes 

Chronic liver disease

Target cells 

Normocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Haemolytic anemia 

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells 

Hereditary spherocytosis

RBC lack central zone of pallor, reticulocytosis

Glucose-6-Phosphate-Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency 

Heinz bodies (revealed by special staining),‘Bite’ cells

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the proteasomal degradation of proteins?

choices.text: Misfolded proteins are degraded in this process.
Ubiquitin is the key molecule involved.

questions.solution:
Option D is the false statement. Proteasomal degradation of proteins is an ATP-dependent process.

The proteasome consists of a macromolecular, cylindrical complex of proteins. It consists of four rings with a hollow core containing the protease active sites, and one or two caps or regulatory particles. The regulatory particles recognize the polyubiquitinated substrates and initiate the degradation of the protein.

Ubiquitin is the key molecule in protein degradation. Degradation of regulatory proteins with short half-lives and of abnormal or misfolded proteins occurs in the cytosol, and this process requires both ATP and ubiquitin.

Bortezomib, carfilzomib, and ixazomib are proteasome inhibitors. They inhibit proteolytic degradation of multiple cellular proteins and are used in the treatment of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A patient presents with profuse nose bleeding that is not controlled by nasal packing. The ENT surgeon ligates the maxillary artery to arrest bleeding. Which of the arteries shown in the diagram would stop bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ligation of the maxillary artery would arrest bleeding from the sphenopalatine artery (marked B) and the greater palatine artery (marked D) in the given image.

The sphenopalatine artery and the greater palatine artery are branches of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery.

Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows:

  • A: Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • C: Posterior ethmoidal artery 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery.

The blood supply of the nasal septum is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric department with severe pain in the hands and feet. On examination, corneal opacities and telangiectatic skin lesions on the thighs were observed. On further investigation, he is found to be deficient in α-galactosidase A enzyme. Accumulation of which of the following lipids is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Fabry disease. It results in excessive intracellular accumulation of globotriaosylceramide.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism due to deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme.

Features of Fabry disease:

  • Angiokeratomas - telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area
  • Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities
  • Painful acroparesthesias 
  • Fabry crisis - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities
  • Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent called maltese cross
  • Renal failure, cardiac disease, or stroke are the major causes of mortality in patients with Fabry disease.

Below is the image of angiokeratomas distributed along the bathing trunk area.

Other options:

Option A- Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive of infancy. It results from the deficient activity of galactocerebrosidase and leads to the accumulation of galactosylceramide in the white matter. Peripheral and central myelin is affected in this disease, which results in spasticity and cognitive impairment.

Option B- Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the reticuloendothelial system. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells, a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

Option D- Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

questions.text: A patient undergoes indirect laryngoscopy as a part of his routine ENT examination. The laryngoscopy image is given below. Identify the structure marked as X.
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the image is the pyriform fossa.

 

Pyriform fossae are present between the aryepiglottic folds medially and the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane laterally. These fossae serve as channels that direct solid and liquid food from the oral cavity into the esophagus.

Clinical significance: Branches of the internal laryngeal nerve lie beneath the mucous membrane of the piriform fossa. Hence, this site can be used for the infiltration of the local anesthetics.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. The fundoscopy findings are shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and fundoscopy findings of pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) are suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics, and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

Diabetic retinopathy describes retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:

  1. Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  2. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  3. Diabetic maculopathy
  4. Advanced diabetic eye disease

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is marked by NVD or NVE (neovascularization elsewhere), which is the hallmark of the condition. Condensation of connective tissue surrounding the newly formed vessels results in the formation of a fibrovascular epiretinal membrane. Vitreous detachment and hemorrhage may also occur. Preretinal hemorrhages are considered a high-risk characteristic. In addition, changes seen in NPDR may also be present.

The condition usually develops 25 years after the onset of the disease. Hence, it is more commonly seen in patients with type I diabetes. 

PDR with high-risk characteristics is managed with pan-retinal photocoagulation. Laser treatment helps by inhibiting the release of vascular endothelial growth factors (VEGF). Anti-VEGFs are recommended before pan-retinal photocoagulation in patients with PDR.

Fundoscopy in NPDR reveals hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and microaneurysms. Hard exudates are small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with crenated margins. 

Other options:

Option A: Focal laser photocoagulation is the treatment of choice for focal diabetic macular edema (DME) that does not involve the fovea.

Option C: Grid laser photocoagulation can be used in diffuse DME not responding to anti-VEGFs and intravitreal steroids.

Option D: Scleral buckling can be used in cases of advanced PDR with tractional retinal detachment.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient is diagnosed with stage 3, luminal A breast cancer. Which among the following adjuvant treatments will you provide apart from radiotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman with stage-3, luminal A breast cancer should be given Letrozole + chemo-radiation as adjuvant treatment.

Breast cancers can be classified into subtypes based on their molecular characteristics. Luminal A is one such type that is estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive and human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) negative.

 The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  1. Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors aims to prevent recurrence by suppressing the action of estrogen on hormone-responsive tumors. It is given to patients with tumors that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+). It depends on the menstrual status of the woman.
  • Premenopausal women are given selective estrogen receptor modulators-SERMs like tamoxifen.
  • Postmenopausal women are given aromatase inhibitors like letrozole

   b. Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given to patients with tumors that are HER2 overexpressing.

   c. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are given for all stage III breast cancers.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A 30-year-old chronic alcoholic patient presented with acute abdominal pain. An erect abdominal x-ray of the patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given erect abdominal x-ray shows the colon cut-off sign, which is suggestive of acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign describes gaseous distension seen in the proximal colon associated with the narrowing of the splenic flexure. Though originally described in abdominal radiographs, this sign has also been demonstrated in contrast enema and computed tomography.

This appearance results from an inflammatory process extending from the pancreas into the phrenico-colic ligament via the transverse mesocolon.

Other options:

Option B: Toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm and loss of haustrations. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis.

Option C:  Sigmoid volvulus shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign and the absence of rectal gas. On the x-ray abdomen, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus extends towards the right upper quadrant and the haustrations are usually lost.

Option D: Barium enema radiograph in colonic diverticulitis shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine?
questions.solution:
Among the following Transforming Growth Factor β(TGF-β )is an anti-inflammatory cytokine.

TGF-β secreted by fibroblasts, epithelial cells and macrophages, has anti-inflammatory effects and is responsible for tissue repair, and fibrosis.

It stimulates the production of collagen, fibronectin, and proteoglycans and inhibits collagen degradation by decreasing matrix metalloproteinase(MMP). This results in scar formation after injury and drives fibrosis in the lungs, liver, intestines, and kidneys in the setting of chronic inflammation.

Interleukin-1, Interleukin-6, and TNF-α are pro-inflammatory cytokines.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron toxicity, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine). 

Dimercaprol, also known as British anti-Lewisite (BAL), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease. Deferiprone and deferasirox are oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to their corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken.

Treatment is by whole bowel irrigation for large ingestions, IV hydration, and sodium bicarbonate for academia. IV deferoxamine is an iron chelator indicated in patients with metabolic acidosis, worsening symptoms, systemic toxicity, or a serum iron level predictive of moderate or severe toxicity. Side effects of IV deferoxamine include hypotension and acute respiratory distress syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Specific antidotes for poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD because of repeated attacks of dermatitis. On examination, ulceration and scarring can be seen on the sun-exposed areas like his face and limbs. He also has reddish-brown discoloration of teeth. On investigation, urine discoloration is observed, as shown in the image below. What is the mode of inheritance of this disease?
questions.solution:
The image showing the reddish port-wine appearance of urine and the clinical scenario of photosensitivity and erythrodontia (reddish-brown discoloration of teeth) are suggestive of congenital erythropoietic porphyria. While most porphyrias are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, congenital erythropoietic porphyria is inherited in an autosomal recessive mode.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP) occurs due to the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen III synthase. There is an accumulation of type 1 porphyrins that cause the symptoms.

The given image shows ulceration and scarring of sun-exposed areas:

The given image shows brownish discoloration of teeth with pinkish/ reddish fluorescence under Wood’s light.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

(Words) Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
  
Other conditions: Menke's disease, Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency

questions.text: A 34-year-old man was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhea and a lesion over his neck, as shown in the image below. Which among the following is false about the vitamin that is deficient in this case?

choices.text: It is used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia.
Toxicity of this vitamin may cause macular edema.
Carcinoid syndrome can cause deficiency of this vitamin.

questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/ vitamin B3 deficiency. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan. 

Tryptophan gets converted into N-formyl kynurenine, which gives rise to niacin. 5-hydroxytryptophan (Option D) is derived by hydroxylation of tryptophan and produces serotonin, melatonin, and 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Maize contains niacin in bound form and is unavailable for absorption. Jowar has high leucine content, which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra, which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

Casal’s necklace pattern classically seen in pellagra is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar.

Pellagra occurs despite an adequate intake of tryptophan and niacin in the case of

  • Carcinoid syndrome as tryptophan will be used up in the production of serotonin (Option C)
  • Hartnup disease due to a defect in the tryptophan transporter resulting in intestinal malabsorption and failure of renal reabsorption.

Niacin significantly decreases concentrations of all apoB-containing lipoproteins like VLDL, IDL, LDL, and lipoprotein a. It also increases HDL cholesterol.
Niacin toxicity occurs when it is taken in excess quantity for the treatment of hyperlipidemia and manifests as

  • Prostaglandin-mediated cutaneous flushing
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Fulminant hepatitis (the most serious complication)
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular edema and macular cysts (Option B)

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the surgery rotation. You are using the qSOFA score to assess the risk of sepsis. All the following are components of the score, except_____.

qSOFA: quick Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment
questions.solution:
Bilateral pupillary reflex is not a component of the quick Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score.

qSOFA is a bedside assessment score. It is used to identify patients who are at risk of dying from sepsis.

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • Low blood pressure (SBP ≤100 mmHg)
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min)
  • Altered mental status

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. A qSOFA score of ≥2 points indicates organ dysfunction.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine
Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

Cardiovascular

Hypotension

 No hypotension

MAP <70 mmHg

Dopamine <5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ 

 Dopamine >5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ Dopamine >15 or epi/norepi >0.1¤ 

Coagulation

Platelets (×103 per μL)

 >150 ≤150 ≤100 ≤50  ≤20

Respiration

(PaO2/FIO2) (mm Hg)

 >400 ≤400 ≤300 ≤200 with respiratory support ≤100 with respiratory support

Mentation

GCS

 15 13–14 10–12 6–9 <6

Liver

Bilirubin(μmol/L)

 <20 20–32 33–101 102–204 >204

Kidney

Creatinine (μmol/L) or urine output

 <110 110–170 171–299 300–440 or <500 mL/day  >440 or <200 mL/day

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A young primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted since her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. All the following will be included in the diagnostic criteria of pre-eclampsia, except ________.
questions.solution:
A platelet count of 1.5 lakh/cu.mm is not a criterion to diagnose pre-eclampsia.

Pre-eclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery. It is characterized by blood pressure of >140/90 mmHg on two occasions 4 hours apart with proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage.

Criteria to diagnose pre-eclampsia:

  • Proteinuria of ≥ 300 mg (0.3 g) in 24 hours or urine protein:creatinine ratio of ≥0.3
  • Platelet count of <1 lakh/cu.mm
  • Serum creatinine level of >1.1 mg/dL
  • Serum transaminase levels twice the normal concentration
  • Headache, visual disturbances, or epigastric pain
  • Pulmonary edema

Clinical types of pre-eclampsia:

  • Nonsevere pre-eclampsia: Blood pressure >140/90 mmHg but <160/110 mmHg without significant proteinuria
  • Severe pre-eclampsia: Persistent increase of systolic blood pressure above 160 mmHg or diastolic above 110 mmHg with any of the following, proteinuria, oliguria (<400 mL in 24 hours), platelet count <1 lakh/cu.mm, serum creatinine level of >1.1 mg/dL, persistent severe epigastric pain, marked elevation of liver enzyme levels, cerebral (convulsions) or visual disturbances, intrauterine growth restriction of the fetus, and pulmonary edema.

Complications of pre-eclampsia:

  • Eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cerebral hemorrhage
  • Preterm labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Shock
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of diarrhea, step-ladder fever, and palpable spleen. Which of the following is used in the preparation of the vaccine for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The child has features of typhoid, and typhoid vaccines are prepared using the Vi antigen.

Vi vaccine is an injectable vaccine prepared using purified capsular polysaccharide antigen. It is given as a single-dose subcutaneous or intramuscular injection. Boosters can be given after 3 years. 

Ty21a is a live-attenuated oral vaccine given in 3 doses on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day.

Typhoid caused by Salmonella typhi can present gradually with headache, malaise, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort, with either constipation or diarrhea. Step-ladder pattern of fever, with relative bradycardia and toxemia, are typical findings in enteric fever. Other findings include hepato-splenomegaly and rose spots.

O antigen is a somatic antigen present in the cell wall, and H antigen is present on the flagella. H and O agglutinins are measured in the Widal test to detect typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's blood.
