questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after an accident. He feels the urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood at the urethral meatus and a high-riding prostate are seen. What is the common site involved in this type of injury?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of trauma, urinary retention, blood at meatus, and a high-riding prostate has a proximal urethral injury. Proximal urethral injuries most commonly occur distal to the urogenital diaphragm and involve the membranous urethra, which is represented by 2 in the image.

Urethral injuries can be classified as follows:

 Type Proximal urethral injury Distal urethral injury
Site of injury
  • Prostatic urethra
  • Membranous urethra
  • Bulbar urethra
  • Penile urethra
Mechanism Secondary to pelvic fracture

Occurs due to a blow to the perineum by:

  • Straddle injury
  • Loose manhole covering
  • Gymnastics accidents
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Deep perineal hematoma
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal hematoma (Butterfly hematoma)

questions.text: A 5-year-old unimmunized child suddenly develops a high fever, noisy breathing, and drooling of saliva. He sits in a tripod position with a hyperextended neck. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
In this child with acute epiglottitis, the next best step is to secure the airway by performing intubation. 

Acute epiglottitis is a rapidly progressive inflammation due to infection with Haemophilus influenzae type B (HIB), leading to airway obstruction. It affects children of 3-6 years and develops acutely. It presents with high fever, sore throat, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting with the neck hyperextended (tripod position) to maintain the airway. Inspiratory stridor is a late finding and suggests near-complete airway obstruction.

The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. In the presence of respiratory distress, diagnostic procedures and radiography are not indicated, and securing the airway by tracheal intubation should be prioritized before a complete airway obstruction.

Antibiotics like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone are used to treat HIB infection. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. 

Neck radiographs reveal the thumb sign  - an enlarged edematous epiglottis (shown below).

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis or croup is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. It usually affects children of 6 months - 3 years and evolves gradually. It presents as low-grade fever biphasic stridor, barking cough due to laryngeal mucosal edema.

Chest x-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign (shown below). Croup is a clinical diagnosis and does not require a radiograph of the neck, and treatment of respiratory distress should be prioritized over testing.

Mild croup is treated with oral or IM dexamethasone which reduces laryngeal mucosal edema. Nebulized racemic epinephrine is used for moderate or severe croup. It may act by decreasing laryngeal mucosal edema from constricting the arterioles through β-adrenergic receptors. Antibiotics are not indicated in croup.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the graphical representation of data given below?

choices.text: Represents the trend of events with the passage of time
Can be simple, multiple or component types
Depicts the relationship between two variables

questions.solution:
A scatter plot is a statistical map used to study the correlation between two given variables.

In scatter plots or scatter diagrams, the pattern made by plotted points along the two axes indicates the possible relationship. If the dots cluster along a straight line, then the relationship is of a linear nature. If there is no cluster, then there might be no relationship. Below is an example of a scatter diagram without a linear relation.

Option A: A line diagram or line graph represents the trend of events with the passage of time.

Option B: A histogram is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains class intervals along one axis and the frequencies along the other axis showing the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.

Option C: A bar graph is a pictorial way of presenting a set of numbers, the magnitudes of which are proportional to the length of the bars in the graph. It can be simple, multiple, or component bar graphs and enable values to be compared visually. They are used to compare a single variable value between several groups.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: All the following are steps of post-transcriptional modification of eukaryotic mRNA, except ______.
questions.solution:
Dephosphorylation does not take place during post-transcriptional modification.

After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications, including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly A tail, and splicing.

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre-mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backwards to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage that is resistant to nucleases.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. This helps stabilize the mRNA, facilitates its exit from the nucleus, and aids in translation. The poly-A tail terminates eukaryotic transcription.
  • Maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns and joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. This is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

questions.text: After a recent event of severe floods in a metropolitan city, the local government has planned to implement certain measures to control and prevent the transmission of communicable diseases. Which of the following is true about vaccination in disaster management?

choices.text: The WHO recommends typhoid and cholera vaccines for routine use in endemic areas
Supplying safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta is not very effective in preventing transmission of cholera and typhoid
The newer typhoid and cholera vaccines have poor compliance
Mass vaccination of population against tetanus is the first step to be done

questions.solution:
Option C is the true statement. The newer typhoid and cholera vaccines have poor compliance. This is because although their efficacy is better than that of earlier versions, they are to be administered in multiple doses, whereby compliance is likely to be poor.

The WHO does not recommend typhoid and cholera vaccines for routine use in endemic areas (Option A). Apart from poor compliance, these vaccines have not yet been proven effective as a large-scale public health measure. These vaccinations are, however, recommended for health workers. Supplying safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta is the most practical and effective strategy to prevent transmission in the general population (Option B).

Mass vaccination of the population against tetanus is usually unnecessary (Option D). Instead, a booster is given if the last dose was 5 years ago and the patient has sustained an open wound. The best protection is by maintaining a high level of immunity in the general population through routine vaccination before the disaster occurs, and adequate wound cleaning and treatment.

Disruption of ongoing national or regional eradication programs against polio and measles should be monitored closely as natural disasters may negatively affect their maintenance.

questions.text: During a routine motor examination, a physician asked his patient to abduct his arm completely overhead. Which of the following muscles helps to initiate the abduction of the arm?
questions.solution:
The supraspinatus helps in the initiation of abduction of the shoulder (first 15°). It is supplied by the suprascapular nerve (C5, C6).

Muscles involved in the abduction of the shoulder:

  • The first 15° of abduction is initiated by the supraspinatus muscle (Both deltoid and supraspinatus help in initiation).
  • The next 15° to 90° of abduction is carried out mainly by the middle fibers of the deltoid muscle.
  • Abduction of the arm beyond 90° is carried out by the movement of the shoulder girdle caused by the action of the trapezius and serratus anterior.

Other options:

Option A: Subscapularis helps in medial rotation and adduction of the arm. It is supplied by upper and lower subscapular nerves.

Option B: Trapezius helps in retraction and elevation of scapula, and abduction of the shoulder beyond 90°. It is supplied by the spinal part of the accessory nerve. 

Option C: Serratus anterior helps in pulling the scapula anterior (punching and pushing movements); along with the trapezius, it helps in the abduction of the shoulder beyond 90° and helps in stabilizing the scapula during weight carrying. It also helps in forced inspiration. It is supplied by the long thoracic nerve.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by vaginal delivery. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. After the delivery of the placenta, she started to bleed profusely. On examination, the uterus is atonic. Which among the following should not be used to control bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in a primigravida with bronchial asthma. Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha, which is contraindicated in bronchial asthma patients.

Contraindications of carboprost:

Absolute  Relative
  • Asthma
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Suspected amniotic fluid embolism
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Renal disease
  • Liver disease
  • Heart disease

Other options :

Option B: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH according to WHO guidelines. Carbetocin, which is a long-acting analog of oxytocin, can also be used.

Option C: Misoprostol (PGE1 analog) is useful, especially in resource-poor settings. As per WHO, 400 to 600 μg is given orally as a single dose. It is contraindicated in the case of previous cesarean section.

Option D: Methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in hypertensive patients. It is given as an intramuscular injection or slow intravenous to avoid sudden hypertension.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female is diagnosed with osteoporosis. She is given an oral drug but taking that drug increases the chance of developing esophagitis. What advice should you give the patient regarding the most appropriate way to take the drug?

choices.text: Drug should be taken at night
Drug should be taken in the evening with a glass of water
Drug should be chewed in the morning, and the patient should stay upright for at least 30 minutes
Drug should be taken in the morning with a glass of water, and the patient should stay upright for at least 30 minutes

questions.solution:
The drug prescribed to a 55-year-old woman diagnosed with osteoporosis, which increases the chance of developing esophagitis, is a bisphosphonate. The most appropriate advice is to take the drug in the morning with a glass of water and stay upright for at least 30 minutes (Option D).

Bisphosphonates inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They get concentrated at sites of active remodeling and remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Bisphosphonates may be administered orally (etidronate, alendronate, risedronate) or intravenously (zoledronate, ibandronate, pamidronate) when oral formulations cannot be taken due to side effects like esophagitis.

The tablet should not be chewed but taken with water, and the patient should stay upright for 30 minutes after taking the drug. These measures are needed to prevent contact of the drug with esophageal mucosa, which can result in esophagitis, erosions, and ulcers.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
Old age
Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

Related Pearl: Classification of Bisphosphonates (mainly based on potency)

First generation

  • Etidronate ( least potent)
  • Clodronate
  • Tiludronate

Second generation: 10-100 times more potent than the first generation  

  • Alendronate
  • Pamidronate
  • Ibandronate

Third generation: 10,000 times more potent than the first generation  

  • Risedronate
  • Zoledronate

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with headache, fatigue, malar rash, and arthralgia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. Urinalysis revealed hematuria, proteinuria (4 g/dL), and RBC casts. She has high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies. A renal biopsy was done, and light microscopy showed sub-endothelial deposits, resembling wire-loop lesions. Findings of immunofluorescence staining are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Hemodialysis and maintenance therapy with azathioprine
Therapeutic plasma exchange and high-dose steroids
Low-dose steroids and azathioprine for 3-6 months
High-dose steroids and mycophenolate mofetil for 2-6 months

questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigation findings are diagnostic of lupus nephritis. The image shows a characteristic full-house pattern of positive staining for all immune reactants. The next best step in the management is to induce remission by administering high-dose steroids, in combination with mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide for 2-6 months. 

This is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine. (Option C)

Evaluating the clinical case given in the question:

  • The presence of malar rash and arthralgia is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Urinalysis shows hematuria (>5 RBCs/HPF), and nephrotic range proteinuria (>3.5 g/dL), RBC casts. These findings, along with the presence of high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies, are indicative of lupus nephritis.
  • Light microscopic examination of the renal biopsy revealed characteristic 'wire-loop' lesions, which are seen due to sub-endothelial immune complex deposition. The presence of wire-loop lesions is suggestive of diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (class IV).
  • Further, immunofluorescence staining, as shown in the image, revealed positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa, and lambda light chain), commonly known as the "full-house" effect, characteristic of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis:

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of SLE and is seen in about 30-50% of patients with the disease. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Depending on the biopsy findings, lupus nephritis is classified into six classes. The details of the classification by the international society of nephrology are provided in the pearl attached below. 

Therapeutic plasma exchange (Option B):

  • It is indicated in patients with severe lupus nephritis who do not respond to conventional therapy.
  • It is also indicated in patients with lupus nephritis who present with anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome.

20% of patients with lupus nephritis will reach end-stage disease and may require dialysis (Option A) or transplantation. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text:
Changes in the serum values of calcium, parathormone, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase are given below. Which of the following options points to the diagnosis of rickets?

PTH- Parathyroid hormone

ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The biochemical parameters of rickets are calcium ↓, PTH ↑ , Phosphate ↓ , ALP ↑

questions.text: Which of the following statistical tests will you use to compare the C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in 3 patient groups treated with different drugs: remdesivir (Group 1), hydroxychloroquine (Group 2), and systemic steroids (Group 3)?
questions.solution:
An analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups. 

The t-test and analysis of variance (ANOVA) are statistical methods used in the testing of hypotheses for the comparison between the means of groups.

The independent t test, also called the unpaired t-test, is a statistical test that determines whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. A comparison between BMI in males and in females of a population is an example of a case where an unpaired t-test is used.

The paired t-test compares paired data, or pre-intervention and post-intervention data, of the same group. If a study were to compare BP in a group of patients before and after treatment, then a paired t-test would be used.

Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data. In the given study, if CRP levels in each group were categorized as high and low and the three groups were then compared, then the chi-square test would be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 lady with uterine fibroid did not show a response to hormonal therapy for 8 months. She asks for information on other treatment options, one of which is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the procedure shown?

choices.text: Synthetic particulate emboli delivered into both uterine arteries.
There is no risk of complications with future pregnancies post this procedure.
Endometrial malignancy is the absolute contraindication.
Permanent amenorrhea can develop in older reproductive-age patients.

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is uterine artery embolization (UAE), and option B is the incorrect statement.

UAE is an angiographic procedure where synthetic particulate emboli are injected into both uterine arteries. This hampers the uterine blood flow through the larger vessels supplying leiomyomas, producing ischemia and necrosis of fibroids, while sparing the surrounding myometrium. 

Uterine artery embolization can be done prior to definitive surgery, in order to reduce vascularity and fibroid size. It is a management option for women who would undergo a hysterectomy or myomectomy and have no desire for future pregnancy.

Post-embolization pregnancy is associated with the risk of uterine rupture, postpartum hemorrhage, miscarriage, and cesarean delivery. Occasionally, some patients, often older reproductive-age patients, may develop permanent amenorrhea. This is seen due to the concurrent embolization of the ovaries.

Absolute contraindication includes pregnancy, active uterine or adnexal infection, and suspected reproductive tract malignancy.

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: A newborn child presented with the finding as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given image is omphalocele.

It is a midline abdominal wall defect in which the bowel and solid viscera are covered by peritoneum and intact amniotic membrane. The umbilical cord inserts into the sac. Failure of physiological hernia to return to the body cavity by the 11th week causes omphalocele.

The defect can be small, containing only the gut, or can form a giant omphalocele (4 cm or more in diameter) containing the gut, liver, and other organs.

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies such as,

  • Trisomies 13, 15, 18, or 21
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.
  • Exstrophy of the bladder or cloaca.
  • Pentalogy of Cantrell.

Treatment of omphalocele involves covering it to reduce fluid loss. Prophylactic antibiotics can be given, in case of rupture. If the baby is stable, surgical correction is done.

Other options:

Option A: Gastroschisis is a condition where the intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies on one side of the umbilicus (Right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion. It is associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels.

Option C: The vitelline duct remains patent over its entire length in a persistent vitellointestinal duct. This results in the formation of direct communication between the umbilicus and the intestinal tract. A fecal discharge may then be found at the umbilicus.

Option D: Ectopia vesicae/bladder exstrophy is a congenital abnormality that occurs when the lower abdominal wall does not form properly and the bladder is open and exposed.

The clinical features of bladder exstrophy include:

  • Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis
  • Epispadias
  • Males have a broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal hernia 
  • Females have a bifid clitoris

Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text:
A 21-year-old, 32-week pregnant woman presents with complaints of right-sided flank pain and fever for 1 day. She also has chills and vomiting. Her temperature is 39°C, and BP is 120/66 mmHg. Examination reveals costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side. The abdomen is soft and non-tender without any contractions. The results of laboratory tests are given below.
CBC 
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Platelet count 1,35,000/mm3
Urine analysis 
Nitrites Positive
WBC  200/hpf

What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of acute pyelonephritis.

Acute pyelonephritis is the infection of the renal parenchyma. It is more frequent in the second half of pregnancy and presents as fever, chills, aching pain in the lumbar region, and costovertebral angle tenderness.

Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism. Klebsiella pneumoniae, Enterobacter and Proteus species, group B Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus aureus are other rare causes.

Urinalysis would be positive for nitrite and show increased WBCs. Treatment involves hospitalization for the administration of intravenous fluids with antibiotics. 

Other options:

Option B - In appendicitis, persistent abdominal pain and tenderness are the most common findings. Right lower quadrant pain is the most frequently seen, but pain migrates upward with appendiceal displacement due to the gravid uterus. Costovertebral angle tenderness and abnormal findings of urinalysis, which are seen in the given case, are not associated with appendicitis.

Option C - HELLP syndrome is a rare complication of pre-eclampsia. This refers to hemolysis (H), elevated liver (EL) enzyme levels, and low platelet (LP) count (<100,000/mm3). Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is the hallmark of the triad of HELLP syndrome. In the given case, the patient has normal BP and platelet count, which rules out this option.

Option D - Abruptio placentae refers to the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus. Placental abruption may be either concealed (when blood accumulates behind the placenta) or revealed (when blood escapes through the cervix). Patients with placental abruption present with abdominal pain and a tense, tender uterus with contractions, which is not consistent with the findings in the given case.

questions.text:
A patient who was diagnosed with MDR-TB came for an expert review. Which of the following is not an exclusion criterion for the use of newer drugs such as bedaquiline?

MDR-TB - Multidrug resistant tuberculosis

choices.text: History of additional risk factors for torsade de pointes
Uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia that requires medication

questions.solution:
Controlled stable arrhythmia is not an exclusion criterion for the use of bedaquiline in MDR-TB, and use of the drug may be considered after obtaining a cardiac consultation.

Newer drugs like bedaquiline have been made accessible to DR-TB patients through expanded access under NTEP. It is used as part of the all-oral longer MDR TB regimen.

The exclusion criteria for the use of bedaquiline are as follows:

  • Uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia that requires medication
  • Pregnancy and lactation
  • QTcF ≥500 at baseline in two ECGs done 6 hours apart
  • Any history of additional risk factors for torsade de pointes such as heart failure, hypokalemia, or family history of long QT syndrome

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

questions.text: A 12-year old boy fell down while playing and sustained a supracondylar fracture of humerus leading to vascular injury. Which of the following would be the least affected?
questions.solution:
The vascular injury following a supracondylar fracture of humerus will least affect pain sensation.

In this case, the boy's fracture and injury to the brachial artery could result in hypoxic injury to the nerves. An arterial injury would affect regions of nerves supplied by it. Pain sensation would be least affected following a hypoxic injury.

The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to hypoxia is type B>type A>type C. Thus type C fibres are most resistant to hypoxic injury and least affected by it.

C-type of nerve fibres are present in the dorsal root and are responsible for pain and temperature sensation. They are also present in postganglionic sympathetic fibres.

Proprioception would be affected in cases of Aα nerve fibre injury.

Pressure sensation would be affected in cases of Aβ nerve fibre injury.

Touch would be affected in cases of Aβ nerve fibre injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who has regular menstrual cycles presents with amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is done and found to be positive. She recalls that the first day of her last menstrual period was October 9. What would her expected date of delivery be based on Naegele's rule?
questions.solution:
Based on Naegele’s rule, the expected date of delivery (EDD) of this woman is July 16.

Naegele’s rule is based on a 28-day regular cycle and states that the EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the 1st day of the last menstrual period (LMP). In this case, the first day of LMP was October 9, the due date is 10-3(months) i.e. 7th month of the following year- July, and add 7 days to the date i.e. 9+7=16. Hence, the EDD will be on July 16.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in pregnant women with normal cardiovascular function?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia is not seen in pregnancy. Resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min during pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypervolemic state, so S3 is heard due to the rapid diastolic filling. (Option-B)

Because the diaphragm is elevated in pregnancy, the heart is displaced towards the left and pushed upwards. As a result, the apical impulse is shifted laterally. (Option-C)

Mammary murmur is a continuous hissing murmur heard over the tricuspid area, and it is due to increased blood flow through the internal mammary vessels. (Option-D)

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to your clinic due to recurrent episodes of cough productive of large amounts of sputum for 2 years. She is a non-smoker. Lung examination reveals wheezes with crackles bilaterally. A transverse section of the CT lung is given in the image below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: CT of chest shows tram-track appearance
Surgical resection of the affected organ forms the mainstay of management
It can be caused by aspiration of foreign body
Poor mucociliary clearance is one of the mechanisms of pathogenesis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette along with the CT scan showing the signet ring sign is diagnostic of bronchiectasis. Surgical management of this condition is considered in only select cases and does not form the mainstay of treatment.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of bronchi due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired mucociliary clearance (e.g. impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Focal bronchiectasis can be caused due to the pressure effects of a foreign body or tumor or neighboring lymphadenopathy on the airway.

Clinically, patients present with persistent productive cough and production of thick tenacious sputum. On examination, there will be clubbing, wheezing, and crackles.

A chest X-ray shows a tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. Chest CT is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

CT findings include

  • Tram-track appearance
  • Signet-ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

The image given below shows the signet ring sign (arrows) seen in bronchiectasis:

Management includes antibiotic therapy, improved secretion clearance, bronchial hygiene, and anti-inflammatory therapy.

Surgery is only indicated in select cases where the bronchiectasis is confined to a single lobe or segment. Lung transplantation is considered in severe bronchiectasis cases, predominantly when associated with cystic fibrosis. In a case of bronchiectasis presenting with massive hemoptysis, intubation is done to stabilize the patient, the source of bleeding is identified, and the nonbleeding lung is protected. Bronchial artery embolization is often needed to control the bleeding.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

Related Pearl: Types of Bronchiectasis

Cylindrical/Tubular Saccular/Varicose Cystic
  • Mildest form of bronchiectasis
  • Loss of normal airway tapering
  • Bronchi have a uniform calibre, have parallel walls tram track sign and signet ring sign
  • Further distortion of the airway wall along with more mucous and sputum production
  • Beaded bronchi with interspersed sites of relative narrowing
  • Most severe form of bronchiectasis and least common
  • This form has large air spaces and a honeycombed appearance
  • Air fluid levels present

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) are true, except ______.

choices.text: CD59 is the most important GPI-linked protein deficient in PNH
Thrombosis is the leading cause of death related to PNH
Nocturnal hemolysis is due to slight decrease in pH during sleep
PNH occurs due to inherited mutation

questions.solution:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is due to acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan A gene (PIGA), leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-linked proteins.

Blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity making them susceptible to lysis or injury by complement. These are

  • Decay-accelerating factor or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59 (most important)
  • C8-binding protein
 

Clinical features include paroxysmal intravascular hemolysis that occurs nocturnally in 25% of cases. This is explained by a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep, which increases the activity of complement. It is associated with development of aplastic anemia and myelodysplastic syndrome. Thrombosis is the leading cause of death related to PNH.

Diagnosis is by detecting red cells deficient in CD59 and CD55 using flow cytometry. 

Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that prevents hemolysis by inhibiting C5. Hemopoietic stem cell transplantation is the definitive treatment of PNH.

questions.text: Bone marrow suppression is least severe with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow suppression is least severe with vincristine.

Vinblastine, vinorelbine, and methotrexate cause prominent bone marrow depression.

Bone marrow–sparing cytotoxic drugs:

  • Vincristine
  • Bleomycin
  • L-asparaginase

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for the treatment of glaucoma. Subsequently, the same drug was prescribed to a different patient who came with complaints of hypotrichosis. Which of the following drugs is being mentioned here?
questions.solution:
An anti-glaucoma drug that is also used in the treatment of hypotrichosis is bimatoprost.

Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin analog that acts by increasing aqueous drainage, without affecting the aqueous humor production. It is used as a first-line drug in glaucoma. Bimatoprost is also approved for topical treatment of hypotrichosis of the eyelashes as it increases their growth, including length, thickness, and darkness.

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs used as anti-glaucoma drugs are latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone. The adverse effects of these drugs include blurring of vision, iris pigmentation, thickening and darkening of eyelashes, and macular edema (especially in aphakic patients).

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Anti-glaucoma drug The adverse effects
Beta-blockers

Corneal hypoesthesia

Systemic side effects
Sympathomimetics

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)
Prostaglandin analogs

Eyelash hypertrichosis

Macular edema

Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)

Peri-orbital fat depletion
Miotics

Retinal detachment

Cataract
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Systemic side effects

Corneal edema

questions.text: Infection of which of the following helminths, commonly transmitted by skin penetration, is characterized by​ the presence of eggs in stool that appear as shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a non-operculated, yellowish-brown egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end, which is suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni infection. 

Adult worms live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria. Pruritic rash known as cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally following skin penetration by cercariae.

After 4-8 weeks, antigenic stimulation by egg and high worm load lead to the formation of immune complexes, resulting in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, and hepatosplenomegaly. When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop chronic abdominal pain and blood dysentery called intestinal bilharziasis.

The drug of choice is praziquantel. Oxamniquine is also an effective alternative.

Other options:

Option B- In Schistosoma haematobium, the egg has a terminal spine.

Option C- In Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

Option D- Schistosoma mekongi is similar to S. japonicum but is slightly smaller and round.

The life cycle of schistosomes with the intermediate snail host is represented below:

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: After the chemotherapy session for breast carcinoma, your senior asks you to discard empty vials of paclitaxel. Which of the following bins will you discard them in?
questions.solution:
Used, discarded, and expired cytotoxic drugs, whether in plastic vacutainers, syringes, glass vials, ampoules, or glass bottles, along with the items used during the administration of cytotoxic drugs, like IV sets, gloves, dressing, and cotton swabs, are discarded into the yellow bin with cytotoxic label.

Paclitaxel is a cytotoxic drug used as a part of a regimen in breast cancer chemotherapy.

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, except those contaminated with cytotoxic wastes are discarded in blue bins.

questions.text: The victim and accused in a rape case were brought to the forensic medical expert for examination by the police. Which of the following is false regarding the examination of the accused in a rape case?

choices.text: Presence of smegma in an uncircumcised accused is definitive proof against rape
Papanicolaou test is performed as a part of penile examination
Clothes, hair, saliva, penile swab, or blood stains are collected as specimens
DNA from victim can be recovered from penile swabs up to 24 hours after intercourse

questions.solution:
The presence of smegma is not definitive proof against rape. 

Smegma usually collects in 24 hours and is rubbed off during intercourse. Hence, its presence indicates that the person was not engaged in sexual activity in the last 24 hours. Nevertheless, it has no medicolegal significance since smegma may be preserved in cases of mere penetration of the vulva, which also legally constitutes rape.

Absence indicates sexual activity might have occurred in the last 24 hours.

Other options:

Papanicolaou test and Lugol's iodine test are performed as a part of the penile examination to identify vaginal cells 

Clothes, hair, saliva, penile swab, or blood stains are collected as specimens and are preserved.

DNA from victims can be recovered from penile swabs up to 24 hours after intercourse by short tandem repeat (STR) analysis.

questions.text: A patient with fever, subcutaneous nodules over the extensor surfaces, migratory polyarthritis, and chest pain had a throat infection 2-3 weeks back.  A biospy of the heart showed the below lesion. What is the lesion composed of?

choices.text: T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and plasma cells
T lymphocytes, plasma cells, and activated macrophages
Streptococci, T lymphocytes, and activated macrophages
Streptococci, T lymphocytes, and B lymphocytes

questions.solution:
The clinical features in this patient are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. The most likely lesion shown in the biopsy specimen of acute rheumatic carditis is Aschoff's body, which are composed of T lymphocytes, plasma cells, and activated macrophages.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections. The antibodies to streptococcal cell-wall antigen cross-react with myocardial antigen, resulting in complement activation and recruitment of neutrophils and macrophages. Cytokine production by the stimulated T cells leads to macrophage activation.

questions.text: Which of the following does this dose-response curve represent?
questions.solution:
The given dose-response curve represents potentiation. 

Potentiation is a type of allosteric effect that occurs when an allosteric ligand binds to a different site on the receptor and potentiates the response. This is indicated by the left shift in the dose-response curve. This allosteric effect is saturable and potentiation reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied.

In competitive antagonism (Option C), the dose-response curve shows a parallel rightward shift. Competitive antagonism occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor. The response curve for the agonist shifts to the right in a concentration-related manner by the antagonist as shown below.

In non-competitive antagonism (Option B), there is a flattening of the agonist dose-response curve. Non-competitive antagonism effects occur when the agonist and antagonist binding to different sites on the receptor (allosteric site) and inhibits the response. The response curve progressively shifts in a right and downward direction until it reaches a limiting value when the allosteric site is fully occupied as depicted below.

In partial agonism (Option D), the partial agonist which has an affinity for the same receptor also competes with and antagonizes a full agonist, while producing a submaximal response.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a gradually progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. He is diagnosed with osteoclastoma after evaluation. What is the characteristic x-ray appearance seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The characteristic X-ray appearance seen in osteoclastoma or giant cell tumors is a soap bubble appearance. The other characteristic x-ray appearances are seen in the following conditions:

  • Onion-peel appearance - Ewing's sarcoma (Option A)
  • Sunburst (sunray) appearance - Osteosarcoma (Option B)
  • Multiple punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma (Option D)

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults in the age group of 20-40 years. The most common location of the tumor is the distal femur followed by the proximal tibia. Involvement of the distal end of the radius is also seen and the tumor is more aggressive in this location.

Radiographic findings in GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance
  • No calcification within the tumor
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Treatment :

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting. 
  • En-bloc wide resection and reconstruction are done for advanced stages, local recurrence, and tumors not responding to other methods.
  • Resection without reconstruction is done for lesions in expandable bones like distal ulna, clavicle, etc.
  • Irradiation and/or embolization are used for inoperable lesions in the spine and pelvis.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Denosumab is approved for use in unresectable tumors in skeletally mature patients.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with painless lesions on the vulva and around the anal region, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image showing multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal is characteristic of condyloma acuminata, also known as venereal warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV strains 6 and 11) is the organism responsible for this condition.

Condyloma acuminata presents as verrucous growths that may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. They are mainly sexually transmitted and seen in women of childbearing age. In 20% of the cases, condyloma is associated with vulval, vaginal, and cervical cancers.

A colposcopic study of these lesions with 1% toluidine blue washed off with 3% acetic acid, one minute after the application is used to diagnose the vulval lesions. The normal skin allows the dye to be washed off, while the abnormal skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. Abnormal areas that are stained are biopsied. Histopathology will show koilocytes, perinuclear halo, multinucleation, and acanthosis. 

Treatment includes local application of 25% podophyllin or 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil repeated weekly. This treatment is, however, contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy and in vaginal and cervical lesions. Surgical excision of localized growth is another alternative option.

The pearl enlists the various types of genital lesions and their causative organisms.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A male patient presented with a knee dislocation. The nerve at the level of the fibular neck is injured. All of the following can be used for the treatment of this condition, except ______.

choices.text: Transfer of tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.solution:
The common peroneal nerve is generally injured at the level of the fibular neck. It leads to a foot drop. Bohler-Braun splint is used in the fracture of the femur. It is an immobilizer frame, which is not suitable for transportation and hence cannot be used for nerve injuries.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula
  • Knee dislocations.

Toe-raising splint and ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) brace are used for conservative treatment. Reconstructive procedures like transfer of the tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot can be done.

The AFO brace is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to your clinic with complaints of fever, arthralgia, and rash on her right thigh for the past week. She returned from a trekking and camping trip to the Himalayas, about five days ago. On examination, there is a 7 cm circular rash on the right thigh, as shown in the image below. What is the characteristic lesion shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows erythema migrans. This classical clinical finding, along with the given history, is strongly suggestive of Lyme disease. 

It is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms or forests. In India, Lyme disease is typically seen in the Himalayan regions.

Erythema migrans gets its name from the characteristic lesion that begins as a flat reddened area at the site of the tick bite and slowly expands with central clearing. Flu-like illness with fever, chills, myalgia, and headache also occur. Stage 2 occurs weeks to months later and presents as arthralgia, neurologic manifestations with meningitis, and facial nerve palsy. Conduction defects of the heart and myopericarditis are also seen. Stage 3 begins months to years later with chronic skin, nervous system, or joint involvement

The treatment includes doxycycline, amoxicillin, and cefuroxime.

Other options-

Option B- Erythema marginatum is seen in acute rheumatic fever. They appear as pink patches that clear centrally and have a serpiginous, spreading edge. It disappears only to reappear at another site. It is usually seen on the trunk, and on the limbs, but it is rarely seen involving the face.

 

Option C- Erythema nodosum is inflammation of the subcutaneous fat (panniculitis). It is associated with sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, and drug reactions.

 

Option D- Erythema multiforme is a hypersensitivity reaction usually triggered by infections, most commonly the herpes simplex virus (HSV). It presents with a skin eruption characterized by a typical target lesion.

questions.text: The enzyme succinate dehydrogenase, which catalyzes the removal of one hydrogen atom from each of the two methylene carbons of succinate, is inhibited by malonate. Which of the following graphs represents this inhibition?
questions.solution:
Inhibition of enzyme succinate dehydrogenase by malonate is an example of competitive inhibition represented by the graph in Image 1.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This competitive inhibition effect can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, following which it can achieve the maximum velocity. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the substrate concentration required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Thus, Km is increased in this condition.

The graph shows the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive inhibition.

Other options:

Image 2 corresponds to uncompetitive inhibition, where inhibitors bind with the enzyme-substrate intermediate complex, and inhibit it. This leads to a decrease in both Vmax and Km. An example is the inhibition of placental alkaline phosphate (ALP) by phenylalanine. 

Image 3 corresponds to a double reciprocal plot (Lineweaver-Burk plot) for non-competitive inhibition. Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes. The inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. An example is the inhibition of pyruvate by alanine.

Although image 4 also corresponds to non-competitive inhibition, the graph shows a plot of 1/V (reaction velocity) vs. inhibitor concentration. Here, the initial velocity is measured at several inhibitor concentrations but at a fixed concentration of the substrate. This is a Dixon Plot, and it is used to illustrate the comparative potency of competitive inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant
