questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and a rash on her face, as seen below. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are positive. Which of the following is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and image is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). C1, C2, and C4 complements are deficient in SLE patients.

The rash seen in the image is a malar rash (classically seen in SLE); it is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences, with sparing of the nasolabial folds. Anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of various complement components:

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other collagen vascular disorders
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Toxoplasmosis, bacteremia with gram-negative diplococci 
  • C3 and its regulatory protein or C3b inactivator deficiency - Severe recurrent pyogenic infections

questions.text: A woman from rural South America presents with fever, shortness of breath, and swelling of the eyelids. Echocardiography reveals biventricular dilatation, with massive cardiac enlargement. The image of the vector responsible for transmitting the disease is given below. Name the vector.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with echocardiography findings of dilated cardiomyopathy, are suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. The vector responsible for the transmission is the reduviid bug. 

Transmission occurs by the rubbing of the feces of the reduviid bug into bite wounds or eye, blood transfusion, and transplacental spread.

Chagas disease is endemic to North, Central, and South America. Trypanosoma cruzi exists in three forms:

  • Epimastigotes- in the reduviid bug
  • Trypomastigotes- in the bloodstream
  • Amastigotes- intracellular replicating form

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and the Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

The chronic phase is characterized by the following findings:

  • Chagasic dilated cardiomyopathy with marked bilateral ventricular enlargement. This may lead to congestive heart failure presenting as shortness of breath. Endomyocardial biopsy shows fibrosis and the presence of intracellular parasites.
  • Megaesophagus and megacolon. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating trypomastigotes on microscopy of blood smears or polymerase chain reactions during the acute phase. In the chronic phase, detection of anti-T. cruzi IgG or endomyocardial biopsy is helpful.

Treatment of Chagas disease is most effective when administered early in the course of infection and has a lesser efficacy in chronic Chagas. Benznidazole and nifurtimox can be used for the treatment.

The image below shows Romana's sign.

Other options:

Option A: Dermacentor tick is a type of hard tick responsible for transmitting rocky mountain spotted fever.

Option B: Soft ticks are known to transmit relapsing fever.

Option D: Tsetse fly is responsible for transmitting Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, which cause African sleeping sickness.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. The findings of oral cavity examination are shown below. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
This child with pseudomembrane over tonsil has diphtheria, in which the toxin inactivates the elongation factor EF-2.

Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa also produces toxins with a similar mechanism of action.

This infection presents as fever and sore throat, which progresses to dyspnea due to obstruction by the pseudomembrane. Bull's neck appearance is seen due to cervical lymphadenitis. Complications like damage to the heart (myocarditis), kidney (tubular necrosis), liver, and adrenal glands can develop due to the toxin.

Neisser's or Albert's stain will show the bacilli with metachromatic granules situated at the poles of the bacilli. Tellurite blood agar is the selective culture medium.

It is treated mainly by neutralizing with antitoxin and antibiotics to arrest more toxin production.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man underwent semen analysis as part of an infertility workup. The results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Sperm concentration - 16 million/mL
  • pH - 7.5
  • Volume - 2 mL
  • Agglutination is absent
  • Morphology - 10% normal forms and 60% motile sperms
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is normospermia.

Latest WHO standard for semen analysis - 2021:

Semen analysis Normal reference value
Semen volume  >1.5 mL
Sperm concentration 15 million/mL
pH >7.2
Total sperm number  >39 million/ejaculate
Total motility  >40%
Progressive motility  >32%
Vitality  >58% live sperm
Normal forms   >4%
Agglutination Particles <2

 

Disorders of sperm are as follows:

  • Aspermia is defined as the absence of semen.
  • Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL.
  • Severe oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of <5 million/mL.
  • Teratospermia is defined as the presence of abnormal sperm morphology.
  • Asthenospermia is defined as the absence of motile sperms or diminished sperm motility.
  • Necrospermia is defined as the presence of dead sperms.

Note: Morphology > motility is the most important marker in sperm analysis.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: You are a medical officer at a PHC. During the training, the PHC nursing staff asks you about the reuse of partially used vaccines. You explain the open vial policy. Which among the following vaccines does not come under this policy?
questions.solution:
The vaccine that does not fall under the open vial policy is the BCG vaccine.

The open vial policy ensures the reuse of partially used multidose vaccines that are given under the Universal Immunization Program (UIP) for up to four weeks (28 days). All open vials should have a date and time of opening recorded. It has to be made sure that:

  • The expiry date has not passed.
  • Vaccines are stored strictly under the proper temperature range during transport and storage at cold chain points.
  • The vaccine vial septum is not submerged in water.
  • Proper aseptic techniques have been followed.
  • The vaccine vial monitor (VVM), has not reached the discard point.

It is applicable for

  • DPT
  • TT
  • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • OPV
  • Pentavalent vaccine
  • Rotavirus vaccine
  • Japanese encephalitis vaccine

It is not applicable for

  • Measles/ MR vaccine
  • BCG vaccine

Note: Open vial policy does not apply to rotavirus vaccine with VVM on cap, it applies only to new rotavirus vaccine with VVM on label.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: A patient developed severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and restlessness after administration of drug 'X'. He is a known case of COPD and is currently on oral theophylline therapy. On evaluation, his plasma concentration of theophylline was 25 mg/L. Identify drug 'X'.
questions.solution:
The drug 'X' is cimetidine. Cimetidine is an inhibitor of cytochrome-p450 (CYP1A2, CYP2C9, etc.) and therefore increases the level of theophylline by decreasing its clearance.

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by the enzyme CYP1A2 enzyme (cytochrome-p450 enzymes). Various drug interactions of theophylline include:

  • Increased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme induction) by smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, and phenobarbitone.
  • Decreased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme inhibition) by erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, oral contraceptives, and allopurinol.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug used in the management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Its other mechanisms of action are as follows:

  • Non-selective inhibition of phosphodiesterase (PDE3, PDE4, and PDE5), thereby increasing cellular cAMP and cGMP and causing bronchodilation
  • Theophylline antagonizes adenosine receptors causing bronchodilation. Adenosine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine and leukotrienes.
  • Increases IL-10 release, which has an anti-inflammatory effect
  • Decreases gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • Promotes apoptosis of granulocytes, reducing the inflammatory load in the airways

Theophylline has a narrow range of therapeutic index of 5-15 mg/L. Adverse effects tend to occur at plasma concentrations of more than 15 mg/L. Important side effects of this drug due to PDE4 antagonism are nausea, vomiting, gastric discomfort, and restlessness and those due to adenosine A1 receptor antagonism are diuresis, cardiac arrhythmias (PDE3 inhibition also), and seizures.

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

PDE inhibitors Drugs Clinical application

Non-selective PDE inhibitors

 

Methylated xanthines, Caffeine, Theophylline

Asthma, COPD
 

Pentoxifylline

Peripheral artery disease  
PDE 2 inhibitor

Anagrelide

 Essential thrombocytosis
PDE 3 inhibitor

Cilostazol

 Peripheral artery disease
 

Milrinone, Amrinone

 Cardiac failure  
PDE 4 inhibitor

Roflumilast

 COPD
 

Drotaverine

 Antispasmodic drug
PDE 5 inhibitor

Sildenafil, Vardenafil, Tadalafil (Also inhibit PDE6)

 Erectile dysfunction Pulmonary hypertension

 

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with hereditary hyperlipoproteinemia is being treated with fenofibrate. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

LPL - Lipoprotein lipase; PPARα - Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha

choices.text: Bind to PPARα and increase LPL synthesis
Binds bile acids in the intestine

questions.solution:
Fenofibrate increases lipoprotein lipase activity through peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-α); hence, Option A is correct.

Fenofibrate is a fibric acid derivative. Fibrates bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) and reduce triglyceride levels by PPARα-mediated stimulation of fatty acid oxidation, increased LPL synthesis, and reduced expression of apo C-III. Fibrates increase the HDL by PPARα-mediated stimulation of apo A-I and apo A-II expression. Fibrates are the drugs of choice for treating type III hyperlipoproteinemia, as well as mild hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides <400 mg/dL).

Other options:

Option B: Niacin inhibits the lipolysis of triglycerides by hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. It leads to a reduction of the transport of free fatty acids to the liver, thereby decreasing hepatic triglyceride synthesis.

Option C: Statins cause a reduction of LDL levels by competitively inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase which is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis. Statins affect blood cholesterol levels by inhibiting hepatic cholesterol synthesis, which results in increased expression of the LDL receptor gene.

Option D: The bile acid sequestrants (Cholestyramine, Colestipol, Colesevelam) are highly positively charged and bind to negatively charged bile acids. The resins are not absorbed because of their large size, and the bound bile acids are excreted in the stool. Interruption in the process of reabsorption of bile acid leads to depletion of the pool of bile acids, and hepatic bile acid synthesis increases. As a result, hepatic cholesterol content declines, which stimulates the production of LDL receptors.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a lump in her left breast. The lump has been present for the past 1 month. Examination shows a 2 X 2 cm firm lump that moves easily under the finger.  Which of the following is the best initial investigation for the assessment of her breast lump?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of mobile breast lump points to a diagnosis of fibroadenoma. Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in a woman with features of fibroadenoma. 

Fibroadenomas are benign solid tumors composed of stromal and epithelial elements seen commonly in women below 30 years. They present as a firm mass which is mobile and may increase in size over several months and wax and wane with the menstrual cycle.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 35 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes. 

Other Options:

Option A: Mammography is the first-line imaging for women over 40 who present with a new breast mass. It is of little help in discriminating between cysts and fibroadenomas. 

Option B: MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.

Option D: Carcinoembryonic antigen is used to evaluate the prognosis of breast cancer.

Related Pearl: Breast Lump Evaluation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, with a history of myocardial infarction 1 year back, presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. The ECG strip obtained during his admission is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the PR segment remains the same in each successive cycle. However, some P waves are not followed by QRS complexes, which means that some of the P waves are not conducted due to an atrioventricular conduction block. This is typical of Mobitz type II block. The definitive long-term treatment is, therefore, a permanent pacemaker. 

This patient with a history of ischemic heart disease (previous history of inferior-wall MI) and signs of acquired Mobitz type II AV block will benefit most from a permanent pacemaker and it is recommended regardless of symptoms.

In the ECG below, the blue arrows show P waves, and the last P wave is not followed by a QRS complex. This missed QRS complex is marked by the red arrow. Mobitz type II is often a problem in the infra-nodal conduction system, and therefore, is associated with wide QRS complexes (in leads V1, V2, and V3 of the given ECG), as indicated by the red box.

Other options:

Option A - Amiodarone, a class III anti-arrhythmic agent, is the drug of choice in the acute treatment as well as prevention of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. It is a rate-control medication. 

Options B and D - Pharmacologic interventions such as atropine and isoproterenol serve as short-term supplementary treatment options until a pacemaker can be installed or if the AV block is transient in nature. Even in such instances, a temporary transcutaneous pacemaker is preferred until a permanent device is available. 

Related Pearl: Indication for Pacemaker in AV Conduction Defects

  • In any patient with symptomatic bradycardia
  • Irreversible second- or third-degree AV bloc
  • Pacing in patients with asymptomatic AV block should be individualized

With acquired CHB

Left ventricular dysfunction and

Waking heart rates 40 beats/min.
  • Asymptomatic second-degree AV block of either type, if the block is demonstrated to be intra- or infra-His or is associated with a wide QRS complex
  • Neuromuscular diseases having a predilection for the conduction system, such as myotonic dystrophy and other muscular dystrophies, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with excessive fatigue and an inability to carry out her day-to-day work. On examination, she appears pale and has a smooth tongue. Peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body?
questions.solution:
The patient has features and hypochromic anemia on the peripheral smear suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia. Measurement of serum ferritin level is the most reliable test to assess the iron stores in her body.

Free iron is toxic to the body. Therefore it is bound to a protein called apoferritin to form ferritin. Adult males have serum ferritin values averaging 100 μg/L, while adult females have levels averaging 30 μg/L. The serum ferritin level is the most convenient laboratory test to estimate iron stores. It is decreased in IDA.

The majority of the patients with iron deficiency anemia present with easy fatigability, tachycardia, palpitations, and dyspnea on exertion. Severe deficiency causes skin and mucosal changes like

  • smooth tongue
  • brittle nails
  • koilonychia- spooning of nails
  • cheilosis- fissures at the corner of the mouth
  • pica- craving for specific foods that are not rich in iron.

Laboratory investigation of iron deficiency anemia:

The peripheral smear will show small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic) cells with an increased area of central pallor. Poikilocytosis (variation in the shape of red cells), anisocy­tosis (variations in red blood cell size), and pencil-shaped cells can be seen.

Option A: Serum iron levels- It represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. The normal range for serum iron is 50–150 μg/dL. It is decreased in iron deficiency anemia.

Option B: Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)- It is an indirect measure of the circulating transferrin. The normal levels are 300–360 μg/dL. The levels are increased in IDA.

Option D: Evaluation of bone marrow iron stores- It can be done by performing a bone marrow biopsy and using the Prussian stain to stain the iron stores. It is rarely done these days due to the availability of serum ferritin estimation tests.

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Type of anemia

Microcytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Thalassemia trait

Basophilic stippling, target cells 

Iron-deficiency

Elliptocytes, target cells

Sideroblastic anemia

Pappenheimer bodies, RBC dimorphism, ringed sideroblasts (Perl’s stain) 

Macrocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Myelodysplastic syndrome

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis 

Megaloblastic anemia

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Polychromasia (purple reticulocyte) +/- spherocytes 

Chronic liver disease

Target cells 

Normocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Haemolytic anemia 

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells 

Hereditary spherocytosis

RBC lack central zone of pallor, reticulocytosis

Glucose-6-Phosphate-Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with a large, rapidly progressing abdominal mass, and ascites. He complains of night sweats and fatigue for 2 months. CT Scan of the abdomen shows a mesenteric enlargement of the abdomen. A lymph node biopsy is done, as shown below.  Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Increased MYC protein levels are seen in this condition
It can present with three distinct clinical forms
Characteristic "starry sky" pattern is seen in lymph node biopsy
Tumor cells are  negative for BCL6

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the lymph node biopsy are indicative of Burkitt lymphoma. Tumor cells are mature B cells that are positive for BCL6; hence, Option D is incorrect.

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation of the c-Myc gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14). (Option A )

It can occur in 3 forms which have distinct clinical characteristics:(Option B)

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. It can also spread to bone marrow and meninges.
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it has an abdominal presentation with massive disease, ascites, and renal, testis, and/or ovarian involvement. It can also spread to CNS and meninges.
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology: Tumor cells show round or oval nuclei, coarse chromatin, small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky). The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic “starry sky” pattern. (Option C)

The tumor cells are mature B cells that express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, a phenotype consistent with a germinal center B-cell origin. (Option D)

Related Pearl: Burkitt's Lymphoma

Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children < 15 years.

 Parameter  Features
Genetic factors

Translocations - t(8;14), t(2;8), t(8,22)
Clinical types

Endemic - affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated

Sporadic - in adults in western countries 

Immunodeficiency associated - HIV infection
Clinical features

Peripheral lymphadenopathy

Intrabdominal mass

Rapid CNS metastasis 
Histology

Starry sky pattern

Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (due to rapid proliferation)
Immunophenotype

B cell-associated antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a)

Germinal center-associated markers (CD10 & BCL-6)

CD43, BCL-2 in up to 20% of cases

Expression of CD21 (the EBV/C3d receptor) depends on EBV status of the tumors:

  • Endemic type (EBV+) - CD21
  • Non-endemic type (EBV-) - lack CD21
 Treatment

Started immediately after diagnosis

Intensive chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide
 Prognosis  Good - 70-80% cure rate

A variant of this condition with bone marrow involvement is called Burkitt's leukemia (ALL-L3). It is associated with c-myc dysregulation.

questions.text: A patient on heparin develops heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Heparin is stopped immediately. Which of the following drugs should be avoided as an alternate anticoagulant?
questions.solution:
Enoxaparin, a low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), should not be given as an alternate anticoagulant in cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) because they cross-react with heparin antibodies.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia occurs in about 0.5% of medical patients 5–10 days after initiation of heparin therapy. It refers to platelet count < 150,000/mL or a 50% decrease from the pretreatment value.

IgG antibodies are formed against complexes of heparin with platelet factor 4 are formed causing most of the symptoms. Venous thromboembolism occurs most commonly. Arterial thrombosis can also occur causing limb ischemia, myocardial infarction, or stroke.

Management: If unexplained thrombocytopenia or any of the clinical manifestations mentioned occur 5 or more days after the beginning of the therapy, regardless of the dose or route of administration, heparin or LMWH should be discontinued immediately. The diagnosis of HIT can be confirmed with a heparin-dependent platelet activation assay or an immunoassay for antibodies that react with heparin–platelet factor 4 complexes. An alternative anticoagulant such as bivalirudin, argatroban, or fondaparinux should be administered to patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia as thrombotic complications may occur after cessation of therapy. LMWHs such as enoxaparin and dalteparin should be avoided. (Option D)

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis requires second-line agents for his therapy. The physician decides to prescribe moxifloxacin. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the drug prescribed to the patient?

UTI- urinary tract infection; FQs- fluoroquinolones

choices.text: It is not approved for treatment of UTIs.
It is frequently used in the management of community-acquired pneumonia.
The drug is predominantly cleared by kidneys.
It carries the highest risk for QT prolongation among FQs.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding moxifloxacin is that it is predominantly cleared by kidneys (Option C). Moxifloxacin is metabolized predominantly by the liver and can therefore be used safely in patients with renal failure without dose adjustment. However, it should not be used in patients with hepatic failure.

Moxifloxacin does not accumulate in the urine, hence it is not approved for the treatment of urinary tract infections. (Option A) 

Moxifloxacin, levofloxacin, and gemifloxacin have excellent activity against Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae and atypical respiratory pathogens. Thus, these agents are frequently used in the management of community-acquired pneumonia (Option B). It is also used in upper respiratory tract infections such as sinusitis. Moxifloxacin is also used as part of multiple-drug regimens for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, atypical mycobacterial infections, and Mycobacterium avium complex infections in AIDS.

Among the quinolones, moxifloxacin is found to carry the highest risk for QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes arrhythmias (Option D). Gemifloxacin, levofloxacin, and ofloxacin appear to have a lower risk. Ciprofloxacin has the lowest risk.

Related Pearl: Withdrawn fluoroquinolones and the associated adverse events

 

Withdrawn Fluoroquinolones The Associated Adverse Events
Lomefloxacin and Gatifloxacin Phototoxicity, QTc prolongation
Trovafloxacin Hepatotoxicity
Gatifloxacin Hypoglycemia
Grepafloxacin Cardiotoxicity
Temafloxacin Immune hemolytic anemia
Clinafloxacin Phototoxicity

Related Pearl: Etiology of Torsade De Pointes

Acquired prolongation of QT interval

Electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Drugs

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
    • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
    • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade ventricular tachycardia is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant
  • Antibiotics

    • Fluoroquinolones: Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
    • Clindamycin
    • Pentamidine
    • Chloroquine
    • Antifungals: Ketoconazole, itraconazole
    • Antivirals
    • Antipsychotics
    • Antihistamines

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her 30th week of gestation came for a regular antenatal check-up. On sonographic imaging, her amniotic fluid index was found to be 4 cm. All the following findings can be seen, except ______.

choices.text: Abdominal wall is tense, with shiny skin
Single deepest pocket is found to be 1 cm
The uterus is palpated to be full of fetus

questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm suggests a diagnosis of oligohydramnios. A tense abdominal wall with shiny skin is associated with polyhydramnios and is not seen in oligohydramnios.

A deficiency of liquor amnii to an amount less than 200 mL is called oligohydramnios. It is diagnosed if AFI is <5 cm or the single deepest pocket is <2 cm on ultrasound.

The examination would show uterine size smaller than the period of gestation (Option A), and reduced fetal movements with uterus palpated to be full of fetus.

Fetal complications include abortion, intrauterine growth retardation, deformity due to intra-amniotic adhesions or due to compression (club foot, wry neck), fetal pulmonary hypoplasia, cord compression, and high fetal mortality.

Maternal complications include prolonged labor and increased operative interference due to malpresentation.

Related Pearl: Causes of oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child is diagnosed with tension pneumothorax after sustaining an injury to the chest. An emergency needle thoracocentesis is planned. Identify the site of thoracocentesis.
questions.solution:
The site of needle thoracocentesis for a child with tension pneumothorax is the second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line. Once the child is stable, a chest drain is placed in the fifth intercostal space, in the mid­axillary line.

In adults, needle thoracocentesis is done in the fourth or fifth intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line.

questions.text: A dead body was found in a forest. The postmortem change shown in the image below was prominently seen in the body. Which of the following features will not be present in the body at this time?

choices.text: A reddish frothy fluid coming out of nostrils and mouth

questions.solution:
The appearance shown in the image is marbling. Prominent marbling is seen in 36-48 hours after death. By this time, rigor mortis disappears.

Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours. It then passes off by 18-36 hours. 

Other changes which are seen in 36-48 hours after death:

  • Well distended abdomen
  • Features become bloated and distorted due to the accumulation of gases of decomposition
  • Breast, scrotum, and penis markedly distended
  • A reddish, frothy fluid may get forced out from the nostrils and mouth as the lungs are forced upwards due to the pressure of gases in the abdomen.
  • Appearance of maggots

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the enzyme that does not contain the mineral deficient in this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features along with the given clinical features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency. 

Of the options given, arginase is the enzyme that does not contain zinc. 

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, and night blindness. Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and perianal, perigenital, and perioral regions are commonly seen, as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

There are almost 3000 zinc-containing metalloproteins, a vast majority of which are transcription factors and other DNA- and RNA-binding proteins. Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes, including carboxypeptidase A, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, alkaline phosphatase, phospholipase C, leucine aminopeptidase, cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, and alcohol dehydrogenase.

questions.text: A child is able to perform the action shown in the given image. Which of the following milestones will also be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is the mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. At this age, the child can also speak 1-2 words with meaning.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

questions.text: A researcher aims to find the strength of association between smoking and lung cancer. He plans to do a cohort study. Which of the following is not related to cohort studies?
questions.solution:
Cross-product ratio (Option A) is not related to cohort studies. It is measured in a case-control study.

The odds ratio (OR) or cross-product ratio is measured in a case-control study. It is a measure of the strength of the association between the risk factor and outcome. It is a ratio of two sets of odds: the odds of the event occurring in an exposed group versus the odds of the event occurring in a non-exposed group. It helps identify how likely an exposure can lead to a specific event.

A cohort study is a type of analytical (observational) study that is done to determine whether or not a statistical association exists between a disease and a suspected factor. The study proceeds from cause to effect, meaning the exposure has occurred, but the disease has not. The following are the elements of the cohort study:

  1. Selection of study subjects
  2. Obtaining data on exposure- Information about exposure may be obtained directly from Cohort members, medical records, medical examinations/tests, or environmental surveys.
  3. Selection of comparison groups
  4. Follow-up: In the case of a prospective cohort study, the study population is followed up regularly to look for the effects of exposure. 
  5. Analysis is done at end of the study to determine
  • Incidence rates among exposed and unexposed are the ratio of the number of cohorts who develop the disease to the number of cohorts in the exposed and unexposed groups, respectively.
  • Estimation of risk- In terms of relative risk and attributable risk.

Relative risk is defined as the ratio of incidence of the disease (outcome) among exposed and unexposed groups. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease between an exposed group and an unexposed group. AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure. It also refers to the amount of disease that could be eliminated if the exposure is controlled or eliminated. (Option D)

 

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A patient presents to a surgeon with a complaint of bleeding per rectum. On examination, the following finding was seen. The mass did not reduce spontaneously or manually. What is the next step of management done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario with the image showing a reddish mass protruding out of the anal canal that does not reduce spontaneously or manually is suggestive of grade IV internal hemorrhoids. Surgery is indicated and open hemorrhoidectomy is done in this patient. 

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

  • Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improve with the addition of dietary fiber, stool softeners, increased fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.
  • Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.
  • Surgery is indicated in: 
    • Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
    • Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
    • Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids are:

  •  Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation
  • Open hemorrhoidectomy
  • Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy
  • Stapled hemorrhoidopexy

Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation) is best suited for patients with second and third-degree hemorrhoids. Here, circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence. The advantages are it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients presenting within 72 hours are treated with excision using an elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Related Pearl: Grading of hemorrhoids

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text: During thyroidectomy, the surgeon accidentally damages the nerve marked in the image below. The marked nerve is derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the 6th pharyngeal arch.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve and supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, except for the cricothyroid (external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

The image given below shows the nerves of the neck.

 

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis can be unilateral or bilateral. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is more commonly affected than the left in thyroid surgeries due to its variable relation with the inferior thyroid artery. During thyroid surgeries, the recurrent laryngeal nerve can be identified in Beahrs triangle, which is bounded by recurrent laryngeal nerve on one side, common carotid artery, and inferior thyroid artery on the other two sides.

Postoperatively, the injury can go unnoticed or the patient may complain of mild hoarseness in the voice. This hoarseness is because the paralyzed muscle cannot close the glottis during phonation.

Note: Overall, the most common nerve affected in thyroid surgeries is the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve because of its close relationship with the superior thyroid artery.

The image below shows Beahrs' triangle.

questions.text: Which of the following patients requires antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis?

choices.text: A 28-year-old man with successful repair of a cyanotic congenital heart defect 26 years ago, undergoing tooth extraction
A 30-year-old woman with a prosthetic aortic valve, undergoing replantation of the avulsed teeth
A 50-year-old woman who received a prosthetic mitral valve one year ago undergoing a screening colonoscopy
A 23-year-old man with no history of cardiovascular disease undergoing routine dental cleaning

questions.solution:
A prosthetic heart valve is one of the indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients undergoing dental procedures.

The American Heart Association and European Cardiac Society have recommended antibiotic prophylaxis for patients undergoing invasive dental procedures that involve the manipulation of gingival tissue or periapical region or perforation of the oral mucosa when performed on patients with high-risk cardiac lesions.

Some invasive dental procedures:

  • Tooth extraction
  • Periodontal surgery, subgingival scaling, and root planing
  • Replantation of avulsed teeth
  • Other surgical procedures such as implant placement or apicoectomy

High-risk cardiac lesions:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or prosthetic material used for valve repair    
  • History of endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits.
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the first 6 months after repair.
  • Incompletely repaired congenital heart disease with residual shunt or valvular regurgitation
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement.
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation (recommended only by the American Heart Association)

Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for patients undergoing gastrointestinal or genitourinary procedures; however, if there is a genitourinary tract infection, the infection is to be treated prior to the procedure.

Other options:

Option A: Antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated if the invasive dental procedure is done only within 6 months of complete repair. As the patient has undergone successful repair of the defect 26 years ago, antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed.

Option C: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not required for a screening colonoscopy (gastrointestinal procedure).

Option D: Dental cleaning does not routinely need antibiotic prophylaxis in patients without a history of cardiac disease.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with delayed puberty. On examination, you notice the characteristic finding shown in the picture below. Apart from this, she has a shield-shaped chest. Investigations revealed the presence of normal gonads and pulmonary valvular stenosis. Which of the following is not true regarding the condition?

choices.text: It is most commonly due to mutation of chromosome 12.
It is associated with right-sided cardiac lesions.
High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss is common.

questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis based on features of a short, webbed neck, shield chest, normal gonads, and pulmonary valvular stenosis is Noonan syndrome. Noonan syndrome affects both sexes with normal karyotypes.

Noonan syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It involves mutations of the components of the RAS mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway (RAS-MAPK) pathway. The most common of these mutations is that of PTPN11, which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12. (Option A)

Clinical features:

  • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum.
  • Hypertelorism
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Low levels of clotting factors 11 and 12.
  • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)
  • Typically involves right-sided cardiac lesions (Option B). The most common is pulmonary valve stenosis. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, Atrial septal defect, and Coarctation of the aorta are also seen.
  • High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss is common. (Option D)
  • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus (similarities with Turner syndrome)
  • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.

Difference between Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome:

Noonan syndrome

Turner syndrome

Normal karyotype (46XX/46XY)

45, X0 (60%)

Most common heart disease: Valvular pulmonary stenosis

Most common heart disease: Bicuspid aortic valve

Genitourinary:

Female: Fertile, delayed puberty

Male: Infertile due to cryptorchidism

Genitourinary:

Female: Infertile, streak ovaries

Turner syndrome is not seen in males

 

Related Pearl: Gene Defects Associated with Congenital Heart Disease

Syndrome

Cardiac defects

Char syndrome

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Alagille syndrome

Pulmonary artery stenosis or tetralogy of Fallot

CHARGE syndrome

Atrial septal defect (ASD), ventricular septal defect (VSD), PDA, or hypoplastic right side of the heart

Noonan syndrome

Pulmonary valve stenosis, VSD, or Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

DiGeorge syndrome

ASD, VSD, or outflow tract obstruction

Holt-Oram syndrome

ASD, VSD, or conduction defect

questions.text:
In an average-sized adult patient admitted to the emergency ward, the urobag was filled with 0.6 L of urine in one hour. Plasma inulin level is 2 mg/mL and urine inulin level is 10 mg/mL. Which of the following is true assuming GFR to be normal?

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, inulin clearance is less than GFR.

Inulin clearance is calculated by the formula:

As we have values expressed in milliliters per minute,  600 mL of urine in one hour gives a rate of 600/60= 10 mL/min. Substituting the values given,

  • Uinulin(Urine inulin concentration)= 10 mg/mL
  • V(Urine flow rate)= 10 mL/min
  • Pinulin(Plasma inulin concentration)=2 mg/mL

Thus, Inulin clearance<GFR (normal GFR= 125 mL/min)

Inulin clearance is used to measure the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Decreased inulin clearance is associated with decreased GFR. 

GFR is the amount of plasma ultrafiltrate formed each minute and can be measured by estimating the plasma level of a substance and the amount of that substance that is excreted. The substance used to measure GFR must be freely filtered through the glomeruli and must be neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the tubules. Eg. Inulin.

questions.text: Which of the following does not apply to a 15-year-old child, under the Factories Act, 1948?

choices.text: The child should not be made to work for more than 4 & 1/2 hours.
The child is allowed to take leave once every 15 days.
The child can work between 6AM and 7PM.
Children of this age are prohibited from working.

questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act of 1948, children of age 15 years are not prohibited from working; all other options are provisions for children aged 15 years.

Under the Factories Act of 1948, children below 14 years of age are prohibited from working.

  • Provisions of the Factories Act, 1948, for adolescents between 15 and 18 years:
    • They can work only between 6 AM and 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.
    • They are restricted from working in dangerous occupations.

For a detailed explanation, see the pearl below.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A 5-month-old girl child was brought to the clinic with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. On examination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. The chest radiograph of the infant is shown below. Which enzyme is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a chest x-ray image showing cardiomegaly is suggestive of Pompe disease. This disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme acid maltase.

Pompe disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiency. It causes lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells.

The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, cardiomegaly, and macroglossia.

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen, as shown below.

Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant acid α-glucosidase (alglucosidase alfa).

Other options

Option A- Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease. Patients present commonly at 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C- Myophosphorylase deficiency causes McArdle disease leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain, and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D- Muscle phosphofructokinase deficiency causes Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder). The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presents with high-grade fever, pain in the right knee joint for more than a week, and a recent episode of sore throat. Examination reveals swelling of the knee joint and tenderness. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP.  X-ray showed a faint extracortical outline in the proximal tibia. All of the following factors contribute to metaphyseal involvement in this infection, except _____.
questions.solution:
The complaints of fever, pain, and swelling of the knee following an episode of sore throat along with raised ESR, CRP, and leucocytosis in a child point to a diagnosis of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. A faint extracortical line on X-ray due to periosteal new bone formation is a classic sign of early pyogenic osteomyelitis. Slow growth is not a reason for metaphyseal involvement in this infection.

Osteomyelitis in children usually starts in the vascular metaphysis of a long bone and the following local factors are important causes that contribute to this:

  • The hairpin bend of the metaphyseal vessels slows down the circulation and allows organisms to escape out of the vessel. (Option A)
  • Metaphyseal hemorrhage occur due to microscopic trauma and the clot so formed acts as an excellent culture media for the bacteria to grow. (Option B)
  • Defective phagocytosis is present. WBCs remove the debris of the decalcification occurring in the growth process and their function of eliminating the offending organism is slightly impaired. (Option C)
  • The rapid growth of the metaphyseal cells makes them susceptible to the action of bacterial toxins as they are immature. (Option D)
  • Vasospasm arrests further bleeding from the traumatized vessels but cause anoxia and failure of antibiotics and other defense cells from reaching the area.

Related Pearl: Types of Bone sequestra seen in chronic osteomyelitis

Types of Bone sequestra seen in chronic osteomyelitis:

Type Disease
Tubular Pyogenic
Ring External fixator
Black/coke Actinomycosis
Coralliform Perthe's disease
Feathery Tuberculosis
Sandy- coarse Tuberculosis
Sandy- fine Viral
Ivory Syphilis

questions.text: While taking ward rounds, you come across the ECG of a patient, and changes include ST-depression, flat T waves, and prominent U waves. Which of the following can cause such an ECG?
questions.solution:
Based on the ECG changes described, the likely diagnosis is hypokalemia. Hypokalemia may be caused by a rapid infusion of insulin. Insulin promotes Na+/K+ATPase-mediated cellular uptake of K+, leading to hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia is defined as a plasma concentration of K+ <3.5 meq/L. Common causes include metabolic alkalosis, insulin infusions, diarrhea, use of diuretics, starvation, and β2-agonists. It can also be seen after massive blood transfusions and in cystic fibrosis. It affects the cardiac, skeletal, and intestinal cells. It can lead to arrhythmias and intestinal ileus and increase the risk for rhabdomyolysis.

ECG changes include ST depression, prominent U waves, and prolonged repolarization.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin A can cause hypercalcemia. It will show a shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration in ECG. 

Options B and C: ACE inhibitors and non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis cause hyperkalemia. Acidemia is associated with cellular uptake of H+ and an associated efflux of K+; it is thought that this effective K+/H+ exchange serves to help maintain extracellular pH.

ECG changes in hyperkalemia. Different changes are seen according to the levels of potassium.

  • Tall peaked T waves are present when the serum potassium levels are 5.5–6.5 mmol/L. 
  • Loss of P waves is seen when the concentration is between 6.5–7.5 mmol/L.
  • Widened QRS complex is seen when the concentration is between 7.0–8.0 mmol/L
  • Sine wave pattern when concentration is >8.0 mmol/L

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with fever and colicky right upper quadrant pain and tenderness in the same area. Levels of bilirubin, transaminases, and ALP are normal. An ultrasound is done, and no changes in the gallbladder are noted. What is the next best step?

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The next step in this patient with suspected cholecystitis is to do a hydroxyiminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan.

Acute cholecystitis is usually due to mechanical obstruction of the cystic duct or gallbladder neck by a gall- stone. It presents as fever, nausea, vomiting, and pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back. On examination, Murphy's sign—pain caused by inspiration while applying pressure to the right upper abdomen, causing the patient to stop breathing—is seen.

Ultrasonography (USG) is the initial investigation of choice. USG showing gallstones, pericholecystic fluid, and gallbladder wall thickening is diagnostic.

In cases where USG is normal, a HIDA scan is done to confirm the diagnosis. Failure to visualize the gallbladder 2 hours after injection demonstrates obstruction of the cystic duct, which definitively diagnoses acute cholecystitis. Filling of the gallbladder during a HIDA scan essentially eliminates the diagnosis of cholecystitis.

Treatment including cholecystectomy done within 72 hours has better outcomes that interval surgery

The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder and biliary tree are visualized:

 

Other options:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) involves the use of a side-viewing duodenoscope, which is passed through the pylorus and into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is both a diagnostic and curative procedure in the management of biliary tree pathologies.

Magnetic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is involved in the non-invasive imaging of the biliary tree.

Cholecystectomy is the surgical removal of gall bladder

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Gall Bladder

  • Gallbladder Ultrasound: Investigation of choice for detection of gall stones
  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

Abbreviations:

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: A 35-year-old gentleman presents to the clinic with bloody diarrhea, tenesmus, and crampy abdominal pain for the past week. The colonoscopy image is given below. Which of the following is commonly not associated with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the endoscopic image point to a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. Urethritis is not an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosa of the colon and rectum. It presents with chronic diarrhea, tenesmus, mucus and blood passage per rectum, and crampy abdominal pain.

Sigmoidoscopy shows severe colon inflammation with erythema, friability, and exudates. Active disease is associated with a rise in acute-phase reactants (C-reactive protein), platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and a decrease in hemoglobin. Diagnosis is based on the patient’s clinical symptoms, sigmoidoscopic appearance, and histology of rectal or colonic biopsy specimens.

Extraintestinal manifestations of ulcerative colitis 

  • Musculoskeletal -
    • Arthritis
    • Sacroiliitis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Eye -
    • Uveitis/Iritis
    • Episcleritis
  •  Skin -
    • Erythema nodosum
    • Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Hepatobiliary -
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
    • Fatty liver
    • Cholelithiasis
  • Hematopoietic/coagulation -
    • Venous and arterial thromboembolism
  • Cardiopulmonary -
    • Interstitial lung disease
    • pleuropericarditis
    • endocarditis
    • myocarditis
  • Urologic -
    • Calculi
    • Ureteral obstruction
    • Ileal bladder fistula

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

questions.text: A 78-year-old diabetic male patient presents with a week-long history of severe pain in and discharge from the right ear and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination reveals exquisite tenderness, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and granulation tissue on the floor of the external auditory canal. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?

choices.text: Continue topical therapy for one week
Intravenous anti-pseudomonas drugs along with ear toileting
Biopsy of granulation tissue and topical steroid therapy for one week

questions.solution:
The appropriate management for the given condition is initiating intravenous anti-pseudomonal drugs along with ear toileting. 

The given clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic developing severe pain, whitish discharge from the right ear associated with pain while chewing, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and the finding of granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal, is suggestive of malignant otitis externa. This is a life-threatening condition; the patient must be admitted and started on intravenous ciprofloxacin (anti-pseudomonal agents). 

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC. Bony erosion aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common. Multiple cranial nerve palsies can occur when the infection spreads to the skull base and jugular foramen. The infection can spread anteriorly into the temporomandibular fossa. 

Diagnosis: Severe ear pain associated with granulation tissue in the external auditory canal in a diabetic patient should raise the suspicion of malignant otitis externa. CT scan helps in detecting bony erosions and demineralization of the bones. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but cannot be used to monitor the disease as the test remains positive for a year or so.

Treatment: The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

Other options:

Option B- Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections which were done previously for this condition.

questions.text: Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to which kind of carrier?
questions.solution:
Diseases in which clinical recovery does not coincide with bacteriological recovery give rise to the convalescent carrier.

In cases of typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amebic), cholera, diphtheria, and whooping cough, patients continue to shed the disease agent during the period of recovery following an illness (convalescence). They pose a serious threat to unprotected household members and those in the immediate environment.

Other options:

Option A: Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for poliovirus.

Option B: Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period and can carriers transmit the disease before the onset of symptoms. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria, and hepatitis B.

Option D: Healthy carriers acquire the infectious agent but do not develop any symptoms of disease and keep shedding the agent. Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child presented with yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Laboratory investigations showed a mild increase in conjugated bilirubin levels. Total serum bilirubin was 3 mg/dL.  A urine examination showed increased excretion of coproporphyrin.  A liver biopsy was performed, and no abnormal pigmentation was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with a rise in the level of conjugated bilirubin and increased excretion of coproporphyrin, points to the diagnosis of rotor syndrome.

Inherited conjugated hyperbilirubinemia:

Dubin-Johnson syndrome Rotor syndrome
Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
The absent function of multiple drug-resistant proteins (MRP-2) Defects in anion transport
Black liver on biopsy (due to accumulation of epinephrine metabolite) No abnormal liver pigmentation.
Normal levels of coproporphyrin in urine Increased levels of coproporphyrin in urine 
The gall bladder is not visualized on oral cholecystography The gall bladder is visualized on oral cholecystography

Option A: Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, that presents as yellowish discoloration of the sclera.

Clinical features are intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration. Administration of phenobarbital shows normalization of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome.

Crigler-Najjar Type 1 Crigler-Najjar Type 2
Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
UDPGT is absent UDPGT is reduced
Severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia Less severe
Pale stools Normal-colored stools
May proceed to kernicterus Does not proceed to kernicterus and is responsive to phenobarbitone

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient comes with multiple musculoskeletal complaints. Urine examination revealed blackish discoloration of urine on standing. Which of the following is not consistent with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Calcification of the intervertebral discs is seen on imaging.
It is a disorder of tryptophan metabolism.
Bluish-black pigmentation of the connective tissue is seen.
It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of alkaptonuria, which is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism. Hence, Option B is not consistent with the diagnosis. 

Alkaptonuria develops due to a defect in homogentisate oxidase, an enzyme that oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Hartnup disease is due to impaired intestinal and renal transport of tryptophan. The availability of tryptophan for the synthesis of niacin is reduced, which leads to pellagra-like manifestations.

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs (Option A) are pathognomonic.

Ochronosis is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue (Option B) that generally occurs after the third decade of life. It occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Alkaptonuria is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner (Option D).

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria (shown below). The ferric chloride test will be positive.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs.
