questions.text: A 30-year-old gentleman with a history of severe depression was brought to the casualty ward following the consumption of unknown plant seeds. The patient party had also brought the seeds, which appear as shown in the below image. Which of the following signs/symptoms do you expect to see in the patient on examination?
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in this image are of the datura plant. Datura poisoning is characterized by mydriasis (dilated pupil).

Toxic manifestations of Datura:

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises up to 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated)
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

Treatment:

Physostigmine is given in severe toxicity at 1-2 mg IM/IV after every hour as required. It is a physiological antidote. Pilocarpine may also be given.

The following are images of the Datura plant and seeds:

questions.text: A young female patient came with complaints of joint pain, a butterfly-shaped rash on her face, fever, and weight loss. On investigation, ANA, anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive. Which of the following is the immunofluorescence pattern most likely to be associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and Image A, which shows homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining, is the immunofluorescence pattern associated with it.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia accompanied by early morning stiffness. The other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis.

ANA, anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. Homogenous or diffuse staining and peripheral staining pattern are most commonly seen in SLE.

The image below shows the homogenous or diffuse immunofluorescence staining pattern seen in SLE:

Other options:

Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands. Patients present with dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) due to fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary gland, respectively.

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies are positive in Sjogren's syndrome. ANA and RF (rheumatoid factor) can also be seen. The centromeric pattern and speckled pattern of staining are seen in Sjogren's syndrome.

Image 1 below shows a speckled pattern, and image 2 shows a centromeric pattern of staining.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in fibrosis of the skin, vasculature, and internal organs. It is of two types, namely diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis and limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. 

Nucleolar pattern of ANA staining in immunofluorescence is most commonly seen in systemic sclerosis. A centromeric pattern is also seen.

The image below shows nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence seen in systemic sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

 

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease
Antinuclear (ANA)

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-Smith SLE
Anti-histone Drug-induced Lupus
Anti-U1 RNP Mixed connective tissue disease
Rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP Rheumatoid arthritis
Anti-Ro/SSA, Anti-La/SSB Sjögren’s syndrome
Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma
Anticentromere CREST syndrome
Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis
p-ANCA/MPO Churg Strauss syndrome
c-ANCA Wegener (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

questions.text:
A young patient is brought to the casualty ward by paramedics 30 minutes after a road traffic accident. On the way to the hospital, an IV cannula was secured and a normal saline infusion was started. His vitals now are given below. What is the next best step in his management?

BP: 90/60 mmHg

Pulse: 113 bpm

Oxygen saturation: 96%
questions.solution:
The next best step for this patient with hypovolemic shock is to secure another IV line.

This patient with an RTA, low BP, and tachycardia has a hypovolemic shock. The basic management principle is to stop the bleeding and replace the volume loss. In all cases of shock, regardless of classification, hypovolemia must be addressed before other treatments are started. Obtaining vascular access is best accomplished by inserting two IV catheters. Short, large-caliber peripheral IV lines are preferred for the rapid infusion of fluids, rather than longer, thinner catheters.

Severely hypovolemic trauma patients should be resuscitated using blood and blood products. But crystalloids are the initial management to maintain BP until blood is available. All traumatized patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid as soon as possible. Catheterization of the bladder is done to monitor urine output and evaluation of renal perfusion.

Starting inotropes will empty the heart and deplete the myocardium of oxygen stores, reducing coronary perfusion. Patients will enter the non-resuscitable stage of shock as the myocardium becomes ischemic and unresponsive to resuscitative attempts.

questions.text: You notice the following finding at the limbus of the cornea during the ophthalmic examination of a 10-year-old boy diagnosed with vernal keratoconjunctivitis. These white dots usually consists of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Horner–Trantas seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

  • Vernal conjunctivitis is also called as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects young boys

VKC can clinically manifest as

  • Limbal VKC shows opacification of the limbus with nodules ( Horner–Trantas spots) or a wall of gelatinous thickening at the limbus. Presence of Horner–Trantas dots at the limbus is a very characteristic feature of Limbal VKC.
  • Palpebral VKC shows hypertrophied papillae over the upper palpebral conjunctiva. Eosinophilic leucocytes are present in them in great numbers. The color is bluish-white (like milk), and this appearance may also be seen over the lower palpebral conjunctiva.
  • Mixed form

Treatment of VKC:

  • Topical anti-inflammatory therapy:
    • Topical steroids
    • Mast cell stabilizers
    • Antihistaminics
    • Topical cyclosporins
    • Tacrolimus
    • NSAID eye drops
  • Topical lubricating and mucolytics
  • Systemic therapy with antihistaminic and steroids

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the casualty ward complaining of vomiting and chest pain following binge drinking at a farewell party. His chest pain is associated with subcutaneous emphysema. What is the contrast material used for investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history and presentation of the patient, it is a suspected case of esophageal perforation. Hence, iohexol is the contrast medium used for the diagnostic work-up.

When a tear, perforation, or anastomotic leak is suspected, a water-soluble contrast medium is used to obtain fluoroscopic images. Low-osmolar agents such as iohexol should always be used so as to prevent pulmonary edema, which can occur following the aspiration of high-osmolar agents such as Gastrograffin (Option A).

Option C: Gadolinium is the contrast agent used for MRI. It acts by reducing both the T1/T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1-weighted image. Since gadolinium ion is toxic Gd-DTPA is used.

Option D: Barium contrast is not used in esophageal perforation since it causes barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum causing granuloma and occasionally fatal reactions.

Given below is plain chest radiography with a water-soluble contrast swallow, showing contrast leakage in a patient with spontaneous rupture of the esophagus.

questions.text: You are a physician at a primary health center. A 2-year-old child weighing 12 kg is brought to you. He appears lethargic and is not taking food or fluids orally. On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 45/min, and stridor is heard. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Give a dose of IV chloramphenicol and urgently refer to the hospital
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.solution:
The child in this case has features of severe pneumonia with the presence of danger signs like lethargy, inability to drink, and stridor. Therefore, pre-referral treatment like the first dose of injectable chloramphenicol should be given and urgently referred to a hospital. If chloramphenicol is not available, oral amoxicillin can be given.

This is based on the revised WHO classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia at health facilities. Pneumonia with general danger signs like inability to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargy or unconscious, stridor in a calm child, or severe malnutrition needs antibiotics with urgent referral to a higher center.

The following image shows the IMNCI Guidelines for the treatment of pneumonia.

questions.text: A primigravida diagnosed with pre-eclampsia presents with a BP of 168/110 mmHg. Drug X is administered to her, following which loss of knee jerk is noticed. Which of the following is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Drug X used in pre-eclampsia is magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and loss of knee-jerk following administration implies toxicity of the drug. MgSO4 toxicity is treated using calcium gluconate.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.

Loss of knee jerk reflex is the first sign of MgSO4 toxicity and occurs when the plasma magnesium level reaches 10 mEq/L. 

Other signs suggestive of magnesium toxicity:

  • Decreased respiratory rate <16/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

Magnesium therapy should be stopped and slow infusion of IV calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) is given. Fluid loading and forced diuresis with estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels are done.

Repeat injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only if the patellar reflex is present, respiratory rate is >12, and urine output is >30 mL/h.

Other options:

Option B: Disodium calcium edetate is used to treat acute lead poisoning.

Option C: Glucagon is used in beta-blockers toxicity.

Option D: Flumazenil is used in the toxicity of benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. What would be the initial management in this case?
questions.solution:
The initial management of a patient presenting with Stanford type B aortic dissection is the administration of anti-hypertensives.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear and most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients. Clinically, patients present with tearing intrascapular pain.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified in two ways: the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, and the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of the aorta Type II Type A

Descending aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Imaging: 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta. 

Treatment options:

Ascending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.

Descending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type B (DeBakey Type III) is initially best managed nonoperatively by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about criminal negligence?

choices.text: Contributory negligence constitutes as a defense
A case between the state and the accused doctor
Accused doctor is liable to punishment with imprisonment or fine or both
Even the risk of injury is punishable, even if nobody is hurt

questions.solution:
Contributory negligence can be cited as a defense in civil negligence and not in criminal negligence cases.

Contributory negligence is used to describe the plaintiff's contribution towards the damage caused by the negligent act of the accused doctor (defendant). In such a case, the accused doctor must prove that the plaintiff neglected to take sufficient care of his own health and safety, which in turn contributed to their suffering.  

 Factor Civil negligence  Criminal negligence 
Negligence  Lack of competent care and skill in the professional behavior Gross carelessness and lack of regard for patient's welfare
Contributory Negligence It may be cited as a defense for the doctor Does not constitute a defense for the doctor
Litigation  Between two parties   Between state and doctor  (option B)
Criteria for punishment  No action if the act has not resulted in harm/damage Bare negligence with risk of injury is punishable, despite nobody being hurt (option D)
Trial by Civil court   Criminal court  
Evidence    Strong evidence is sufficient    Guilt must be proved beyond reasonable doubt  
Punishment   Liable to pay damages Imprisonment  or fine or both (option B)

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding the phenomenon depicted in the image below?

choices.text: Seen in influenza B and C

questions.solution:
The given image depicts an antigenic shift, which results in a pandemic.

Antigenic variation in the influenza virus is of 2 types: antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

Antigenic shift is a major and drastic change caused by genetic reassortment between human, swine, and avian influenza viruses, which results in the emergence of a new subtype of virus. It is seen in influenza A virus and absent in B and C as only a few related viruses are present in animals. It is a unique property of influenza virus because of its segmented genome.

Antigenic drift is a gradual change caused by the accumulation of point mutation in protein-encoding genes. All 3 types of influenza virus exhibit the antigenic drift.

Antigenic shift Antigenic drift

Occur in type A

 Occurs in type A and to less extent in type B

Results in pandemic and major epidemics

 Results in periodic epidemic and sporadic cases

Due to genetic reassortment

 Due to point mutation

Occurs every 20-30 years

 Occurs every 2-3 years

questions.text: Which of the following points of differentiation between diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) is false?

choices.text: DKA has a higher anion gap
Serum bicarbonate levels are lower in DKA
Blood glucose levels are higher in DKA
DKA is more common in type 1 diabetes

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about the differentiation between the two conditions is statement 3. Blood glucose levels are typically much higher in hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS).

HHS is commonly seen in older adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients can present with polyuria, altered sensorium, coma, polydipsia, lethargy, seizures, and severe dehydration.

Laboratory tests show the following in HHS: 

  • Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/dL
  • Serum osmolality >350 mOsm/L
  • Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration
  • Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia
  • Normal pH and absence of ketones

The mainstay of managing HHS comprises fluid replacement, IV administration of regular insulin, and correction of serum electrolytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not homologous to the structure marked X in the image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as X in the image is Gartner's cyst, and the appendix of the testis is not homologous to it in origin.

Gartner's cyst arises from the Gartner's duct—an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. Gartner's duct is located in the uterine broad ligament. In males, the mesonephric duct gives rise to the epididymis, seminal vesicles, ductus deferens, and ejaculatory duct.

The prostatic utricle and the appendix of the testis are remnants of the paramesonephric duct/Mullerian duct in males.

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Ovary Genital ridge Testis

questions.text: In a woman in active labor, the occiput of the baby is found to lie in the posterior part of the maternal pelvis towards the left side. Which of the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
The relation of the denominator (occiput, here) to the different quadrants of the pelvis as mentioned refers to the position of the fetus.

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the uterus or pelvic brim
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation that overlies the internal os
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis

The fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to your clinic complaining of hair loss. Your examination findings are shown in the images below. Which of the following statements regarding the underlying condition is incorrect?

choices.text: It is a T-cell mediated disease
Oral corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Short, easily extractable broken hairs, known as exclamation mark hairs, are seen in the trichoscopy image above, and the scalp image shows circumscribed, hairless, smooth patch. This is characteristic of alopecia areata. Oral corticosteroids are the second line of therapy. Intralesional corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice in alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss (Option A). It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease (Option B). It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by smooth circumscribed patches of hair loss.  It affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. Alopecia extension along the scalp's back is known as ophiasis. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the entire body (alopecia universalis). Fine, superficial geometrical nail pitting is seen. (Option D)

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be helpful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional corticosteroids are the initial treatment of choice in alopecia areata. A depot steroid (hydrocortisone acetate 25 mg/mL or triamcinolone acetonide 5–10 mg/mL), administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis or by a needleless device, will stimulate hair growth at the site of injection. Oral corticosteroids are used as second-line treatment if the initial treatment fails. Contact immunotherapy is the third-line treatment and it is the most effective and best-documented method for alopecia areata.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: In which of the following conditions can thiazide diuretics be safely used?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics can be safely used in calcium oxalate kidney stones as they reduce urinary Ca2+ excretion.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter in the DCT. The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia and reduces urinary Ca2+ excretion. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia. Hence it cannot be used in conditions with already increased uric acid levels such as gout, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, and tumor lysis syndrome.

Thiazide diuretics can thus cause hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, and hypercalcemia as adverse effects as it increases Na+ and K+ excretion and decreases Ca2+ excretion. 

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension. Other indications for use include treatment of edema associated with diseases of the heart, liver, and kidney, Ca2+ nephrolithiasis, and osteoporosis. Thiazides are the mainstay for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Diuretics Sodium Potassium Calcium
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors ↑ ↑↑ No change
Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.text: The ECG of a 62-year-old hypertensive patient is as given below. What does his ECG show?
questions.solution:
His ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). 

In this patient, the height of the S wave in V1 is 25 and the R wave in V5 is 21. The sum of the two is 46. 

ECG findings suggestive of LVH are as follows: 

  • SV1 + [RV5 or RV6] >35mm
  • RaVL + SV3 >20 mm in women and >28 mm in men
  • ST depression with T wave inversion 

The causes of LVH can be divided into pressure overload or volume overload. Examples of pressure overload are hypertension and aortic stenosis leading to concentric hypertrophy. Volume overload can occur due to valvular regurgitation leading to ventricular dilation. 

Pathological cardiac conditions leading to increased cardiac workload result in compensatory mechanisms to maintain perfusion and arterial pressure. They include increasing contractility and stroke volume (Frank-Starling law), activation of neurohormonal systems like the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, and release of hormones like norepinephrine and atrial natriuretic peptide. Myocardial adaptations can also occur resulting in cellular hypertrophy of the myocytes. 

LVH occurs due to increased mechanical work. However, the increased muscle mass has increased metabolic demands as well leading to a further increase in oxygen demand. This makes patients with LVH susceptible to ischemia and heart failure. 

Other options:

Option B - Right ventricular hypertrophy is characterized by tall R waves in lead V1, where R is bigger than the S wave, right axis deviation. ST depression and T wave inversion in right to mid-precordial leads can be present.

Option C - Acute myocardial infarction is characterized by localized ST-segment depressions or elevations with T-wave inversions. 

Option D - Acute pericarditis is characterized by widespread ST-segment elevations and T-wave inversions. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a mass below his tongue as shown in the image. On examination, mass is transilluminating and the neck appears to be normal. Which of the following best describes the mass?

choices.text: Mucous retention cyst from a minor salivary gland
Mucous extravasation cyst from sublingual gland
Mucous retention cyst that arises from a sublingual gland

questions.solution:
The image and the clinical scenario of transilluminating swelling at the floor of the mouth with a normal-appearing neck point to a diagnosis of an oral ranula. Oral ranula is a mucous extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland.

Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog. It is of two types:

  • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managed by marsupialisation. Definitive management is excision of the cyst. Some may resolve spontaneously.
  • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes excision of  sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.

Note: Oral ranulas located in the floor of the mouth can often be confused with an epidermoid cyst.

The below image shows ranula:

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with marked ascites. An ascitic tap is performed, and the serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated to be 1.5 g/dL. Which of the following conditions will not be considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In tubercular peritonitis, the serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is low, i.e., <1.1 g/dL; the patient in the given case has a high SAAG of 1.5 g/dL. Therefore, tuberculous peritonitis will not be considered in the differential diagnosis in this case.  

The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

The SAAG is calculated by measuring the albumin concentration of serum and ascitic fluid specimens and subtracting the ascitic fluid value from the serum value. 

If the SAAG is 1.1 g/dL or more, the patient has portal hypertension; a SAAG of <1.1 g/dL is consistent with the absence of portal hypertension.

Conditions associated with high SAAG (≥1.1 g/dL): 

  • Cirrhosis
  • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Cardiac failure
  • Massive liver metastases
  • Fulminant hepatic failure
  • Budd-Chiari syndrome
  • Portal vein thrombosis

Conditions associated with low SAAG (<1.1 g/dL):

  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis 
  • Tuberculous peritonitis
  • Pancreatic ascites
  • Biliary ascites
  • Nephrotic syndrome

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: A young male patient is admitted with sudden onset of loss of vision, restricted movements, and severe pain in his right eye, following a penetrating injury. Slit-lamp examination shows a cloudy cornea and pus in the anterior chamber. Visual acuity shows no light perception. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient presenting with sudden loss of vision and severe eye pain following a penetrating eye injury, along with features of restricted eye movements, pus in the anterior chamber, and cloudy cornea, is suggestive of panophthalmitis. The treatment of choice for panophthalmitis is evisceration.

In evisceration, the contents of the eyeball are removed, leaving behind the sclera. It is done to avoid the risk of intracranial dissemination of infection. 

Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the entire eyeball, including the Tenon’s capsule. Infection can occur as a result of exogenous penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcers, hematogenous spread of infections, or direct spread of infection from surrounding structures (e.g. orbital cellulitis). 

Clinical features include

  • Severe ocular pain and headache
  • Complete loss of vision
  • Marked redness and swelling of eyes
  • Profuse watering, purulent discharge
  • Constitutional symptoms - fever, malaise

Ocular examination:

  • Vision - no perception of light
  • Lids - edematous, hyperemia
  • Eyeball - proptosis
  • Ocular motility - grossly restricted, painful
  • Conjunctiva - chemosis, congestion
  • Cornea - cloudy, edematous
  • Anterior chamber - hypopyon
  • Intra-ocular pressure - raised

Treatment

  1. Anti-inflammatory drugs and analgesics to relieve pain
  2. Broad-spectrum antibiotics
  3. Evisceration is the definitive surgical procedure and the treatment of choice since it has superior long-term cosmetic outcomes and faster recovery when compared with enucleation.

Other options:

Option B: Enucleation - This procedure involves the removal of the entire eyeball with the major part of the optic nerve, leaving behind the extraocular muscles. It is done in cases of retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma. It can be done with a painful blind eye but evisceration is the treatment of choice.

Option C: Exenteration- This is a mutilating surgery in which all the orbits' contents and periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball.

Option D: Debulking- This procedure is done for the reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.text: Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome is observed during the DNA sequencing study of a patient. The histopathology section of the liver is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome and the histopathology section of the liver showing golden yellow hemosiderin granules are suggestive of hemochromatosis.

Hereditary hemochromatosis is caused due to mutation of the homeostatic iron regulator gene (HFE) leads to excessive absorption of iron, which gets deposited in the liver, and pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Histopathology shows golden yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes which stain positive with Prussian blue stain. Serum iron level is raised. Serum ferritin level is significantly increased.

Hepatomegaly will be present in the majority of the patients with symptoms. Skin shows bronze pigmentation due to the increased deposition of iron and melanin over the dermis. Diabetes mellitus is seen in advanced diseases due to the direct damage of the pancreatic islet cells by the deposition of iron. Arthropathy develops in some patients. The joints of the hands, especially the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints, are usually the first joints involved. Congestive cardiac failure is the most common cardiac manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hypogonadism due to failure of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis by deposition of iron. This may manifest as testicular atrophy or amenorrhea

It is managed by weekly or twice weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. Chelating agents like subcutaneous deferoxamine and oral deferasirox are effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to the mutation in the ATP7B gene. This leads to deficiency of ATP7B protein deficiency causing impaired excretion of biliary copper into bile. This results in copper toxicity primarily involving the liver, brain, and eyes. 

Option B: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This is due to the mutation of the canalicular membrane protein transporter gene, multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2). The liver may appear grossly black due to the accumulation of dark, coarsely granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes. 

Option C: Rotor syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This is due to a deficiency of canalicular membrane protein transporter organic acid transporter protein (OATP).

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with fever and neck stiffness since one week. He has a positive Kernig's sign. CSF analysis shows normal glucose level, increased protein level, increased lymphocyte count, and increased opening pressure. Which of the following stains would help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, India ink stain would help in the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.

The diagnosis is made by the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with Indian ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination. Indian ink is a type of negative stain that is not picked up by the capsule, making it evident.

Initiation with amphotericin B with flucytosine, which is followed by oral fluconazole as maintainance treatment is the standard of care.

Other options.

Option A: Gram stain can identify Streptococcus pneumoniae or Neisseria meningitidis, which has elevated neutrophils, decreased glucose level, and increased protein level.

Option B: Gomori methenamine silver stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii which causes fungal pneumonia.

Option C: Acid-fast stain is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis which has lymphocyte predominance, decreased glucose, and elevated proteins.

questions.text: The X-ray view shown in the image is ____.
questions.solution:
The x-ray view shown in the image is the Caldwell view.

  • The nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film.
  • The x-ray beam is projected 15 degrees caudally.

Structures seen are

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)

  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea

The other options are explained in the pearl given below:

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a term baby vaginally, followed by normal expulsion of the placenta. After labor, she continued to bleed profusely. USG showed retained placental tissue, and it was diagnosed as placenta succenturiata. Which of the following complications is not associated with this type of placenta?
questions.solution:
Placenta succenturiata is not associated with polyhydramnios.

Placenta succenturiata is characterized by one or more small lobes/cotyledon of the placenta located distant from the main placental margin connected by blood vessels. If it is retained following the delivery of the placenta, it may lead to postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution, uterine sepsis, and polyp formation. If diagnosed, exploration of the uterus and removal of the missing lobe under general anesthesia should be done to avoid complications.

Placenta spuria is the condition in which separated lobes are not connected by blood vessels.

questions.text:
A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations reveal a blood sugar level of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. Her pulse is 98 bpm, BP is 120/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 36 breaths/min. Which of the following ABG analysis sets will be seen in this patient?
 ABG result pH pCO2 (mmHg) HCO3- (mEq/L)
1 7.35 50 25
2 7.00 45 15
3 7.29 30 15
4 7.18 46 16
questions.solution:
ABG set 3 would reflect the ABG findings in this patient with diabetic ketoacidosis and respiratory compensation, which is indicated by the elevated respiratory rate. 

Normal values in an arterial blood gas are as follows:

  • pH: 7.35-7.45
  • PaCO2: 35-45 mmHg
  • HCO3: 22-26 mEq/L
  • PaO2: 75-100 mmHg

A patient with DKA will have a low pH (7.29), and low HCO3- (15 mEq/L). Here, the primary disorder is metabolic acidosis. Compensatory responses for primary metabolic disorders move the PCO2 in the same direction as the change in [HCO3-]. Therefore, the hyperventilation response leading to compensatory respiratory alkalosis causes a decrease in the PCO2 (30 mmHg), which is in line with the decrease in HCO3-. The pH, however, remains acidic as compensatory responses only bring the pH closer to normal and usually do not completely normalize it.

In general, PCO2 and HCO3- move in the same direction for compensation in metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders, respectively. A change in the two parameters in opposite directions points to a mixed acid-base disturbance. 

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Identify the suturing technique shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The suturing technique in the given image is a subcuticular suture.

It is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. Both absorbable and non-absorbable suture materials can be used in this technique. A buried knot is secured with the ends of absorbable sutures when used. In the case of non-absorbable sutures, a collar and bead are used to secure the ends of the suture.

In interrupted sutures, the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and should exit at a right angle with the skin. If 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. 

The following image shows an interrupted suture.

In the continuous suture technique, the first suture is inserted in a similar way to an interrupted suture. The rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the end of the wound is reached. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

The image below shows continuous sutures. 

Mattress sutures can be vertical or horizontal. They are used to create either an eversion or inversion of the wound edges. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it produces an accurate approximation of wound edges.

The following image shows the mattress suture technique.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the medical device shown in the image below?

choices.text: Its use can be continued in cases of conjunctivitis .
It has a specific use in cases of glaucoma.
It is indicated in cases of unilateral aphakia, anisometropia, and irregular astigmatism.
It can be classified into the hard, rigid gas permeable, or soft type, based on the material used for manufacturing.

questions.solution:
The image shows a contact lens which are artificial devices that act as a substitute for the anterior surface of the cornea. Its use is contraindicated in the active inflammation of the eye like conjunctivitis, uveitis, episcleritis, scleritis, and dacryocystitis.

Contact lenses are of 3 types:

Hard lenses  Rigid gas permeable/ Semisoft lenses Soft lenses

Rarely used 

   Most commonly used

O2 impermeable

 O2 permeable O2 permeable

Manufactured from PMMA (polymethyl

methacrylate)

Manufactured from silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)

Manufactured from HEMA (hydroxyethyl

methacrylate)

 

Contact lenses are absolutely indicated in anisometropia, unilateral aphakia, high myopia, keratoconus, and irregular astigmatism.

Contact lenses can be used in cases of glaucoma as a drug delivery system.

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: While recording a patient's blood pressure, you observe a 15-mmHg drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. In which of the following conditions will such a drop not be observed?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon being described here is the pulsus paradoxus. It is not seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). HCM may present with a bisferiens/bifid pulse.

Pulsus paradoxus is characterized by a fall of > 10 mmHg in systolic blood pressure (SBP) during inspiration.

Both ventricles share an incompressible pericardial covering due to the fluid in a patient with cardiac tamponade. As the right ventricle enlarges during inspiration, the interventricular septum bulges into the left ventricle, reducing the left ventricular volume. This results in reduced stroke volume and hence reduced systolic arterial pressure. As a result, there is a greater than normal fall in systolic arterial blood pressure during inspiration, producing pulsus paradoxus.

It is seen in patients with

  • Pericardial tamponade,
  • Massive pulmonary embolism,
  • Hemorrhagic shock,
  • Severe obstructive lung disease, and
  • Tension pneumothorax. 

Pulsus bisferiens is a pulse wave with two peaks separated by a distinct mid-systolic dip. Rapid left ventricular ejection results in an early component percussion wave. The late component tidal wave represents a reflected wave from the periphery due to an artery's recoil effect. It can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: All of the following statements about the stab wounds are true, except ______.

choices.text: Force is along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object
Depth is greater than the length and width of the wound
Fish-tail appearance occur in single edged weapon
Swallow tails occur at angles of the main wound

questions.solution:
Swallow-tails occuring at angles of the main wound is a characteristic of laceration wound (not stab wound).

A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc into the depth of the body. (Option A)

Characteristics of stab wound:

  • Margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. In full penetration of the blade, the hilt mark can be produced by the hilt guard.
  • The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. 
  • The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade.
  • The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface (Option B). The internal depth is usually equal to or less than the length of the blade used to produce it. 
  • The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc.
    • In single-edged weapon- triangular/wedge-shaped with one end sharp and other 2 sides blunt. Splits may occur at the blunt end of the wound at each corner giving a fish-tail appearance. (Option C)
    • In double-edged weapon- elliptical in shape with both sides sharp angles.
    • Screwdriver- a slit-like stab wound 
    • Fork- produces clusters of 2-3 wounds
  • The wound will have a bevelled margin if the object penetrates at an angle, thus indicating the direction of penetration.

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.

Option D- Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails. It is seen in lacerated wounds.

Below is the image showing swallow tails of a lacerated wound.

Related Pearl: Difference between incised, lacerated and stab wound

Trait Incised wound Lacerated wound Stabwound
Manner of production By sharp objects or weapons By blunt  objects or weapons  By pointed sharp or blunt weapons
Site Anywhere Usually over the bony prominences Anywhere, usually chest and abdomen
margins Smooth, even, clean cut and everted Irregular and often undermined Cleancut, parallel edges, lacerated if weapon is blunt pointed
Abrasion and edges Absent Usually present Absent
Bruising No adjacent bruising of soft tissues Bruising of surrounding and underlying tissue rare
shape Linear or spindle shaped Varies usually irregular Linear or irregular
Depth of wound Structures cleanly cut to the depth of the wound Small strands of tissue at the bottom bridge across margins Structures cleanly cut

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with severe pain over the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe. He had a history of similar episodes in the past. Synovial fluid aspirate showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. The physician prescribed him a drug that catalyzes the conversion of uric acid into allantoin. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario shows that the patient has chronic gout. The drug that catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which was prescribed by the physician, is pegloticase.

Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase) used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated. The efficacy of this drug gets lowered if antibodies are produced against the drug, which occurs in many patients. This also increases the risk of infusion reactions. 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase. It is indicated for the initial management of elevated plasma uric acid levels in patients with malignancies who are on chemotherapy. The efficacy is limited by the production of antibodies to the drug.

Management of gout:

  • Reduction of pain and inflammation: NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids
  • Inhibition of the formation of urate: Allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Promotion of urate excretion: Probenecid, lesinurad

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin. This reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol acts by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme preventing the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following is the adverse effect of the drug that is activated by catalase-peroxidase enzyme inside the mycobacteria?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It then gets activated to its toxic form by the enzyme catalase-peroxidase encoded by the kat gene. It acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid. Peripheral neuritis is the side effect of isoniazid.

Side effects of isoniazid:

  • Peripheral neuritis - It occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10 mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis - Isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anemia
  • Arthralgia

Toxicity of isoniazid results in metabolic acidosis, seizures, and coma.

Other options:

Option B: Optic neuritis is an important side effect of ethambutol. It results in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination. Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This results in disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis.

Option C: Pyrazinamide causes hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity. Pyrazinamide is a prodrug, it is converted into an active metabolite pyrazinoic acid, which makes the intracellular environment acidic, thereby killing the bacteria.

Option D: Flu-like illness is associated with rifampin. It binds to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis. Other side effects of rifampin are hepatitis and orange-red discoloration of urine and body secretions.

Related Pearl: General properties of the first line drugs in TB

First-line drugs
Isoniazid
Rifampicin
Pyrazinamide
Ethambutol
Mechanism
Bactericidal
Bactericidal
(Maximum)
Bactericidal
Bacteriostatic
Location of Mycobacteria
Intracellular +  Extracellular
Intracellular +  Extracellular
Intracellular
Extracellular
Metabolism
Liver
Liver
(Maximum)
Liver
Kidney

 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below, and choose the false statement regarding the procedure done using it.

choices.text: It is performed for the diagnosis and staging of lymphoma.
Postoperative bleeding is a common complication.

questions.solution:
The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not an absolute contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. If the platelet count falls below 20,000 cells/μL, or if clinically warranted, platelet transfusion is performed before the procedure.

Indications:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and myelodysplastic syndrome
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of infections such as histoplasmosis, leishmaniasis, cryptococcosis, and Q fever
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin

Contraindications: 

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

Postoperative bleeding is a common complication. It is due to the high vascularity of the sampled tissue. Manual pressure and pressure bandaging can be done until the bleeding subsides.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with hematuria. An image of the abdomen is given below. Which of the following is not a common association of the given condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has polycystic kidney disease, which is not commonly associated with subdural hemorrhage.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is characterized by multiple bilateral renal cysts. It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in PKD1/PKD2 gene expressing polycystin-1 and polycystin-2 protein.

Hypertension is the most common manifestation. Other features include abdominal pain, mass, and hematuria. Renal stones and urinary tract infections are also seen and renal failure occurs in the end stages.

Extrarenal manifestations include

  • Hepatic cyst (most common), and cysts in pancreas
  • Intracranial aneurysm that can rupture resulting in subarachnoid or intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolase
  • Colonic diverticula
  • Abdominal wall and inguinal hernias

A diagnosis is made from a positive family history and multiple kidney cysts bilaterally seen on USG or CT.

questions.text: A patient who sustained blunt abdominal trauma after a road accident is admitted to the ICU overnight. He is hemodynamically stable. On abdominal examination, he now has tenderness, rigidity, and rebound tenderness. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
In this patient with trauma and signs of peritonitis, the next best step is to perform an exploratory laparotomy.

The management of abdomen trauma depends on the hemodynamic status and the examination findings. Some major indications for laparotomy:

  • Peritonitis
  • Hemodynamic instability with positive FAST
  • Hollow organ injury
  • Stab wound with evisceration
  • Shock from uncontrolled bleeding

In a patient with hemodynamic instability and no signs of peritonitis, focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is performed. If FAST is not available, then a diagnostic peritoneal lavage is done. The presence of intraabdominal bleeding on either necessitates further exploration.

If the patient is hemodynamically stable with no signs of peritonitis, then a contrast-enhanced CT scan is done to look for intra-abdominal injuries and decide on the need for operative, nonoperative, or angiographic therapy.
